Contents of file 57110
I have a 42 yr old male friend, misdiagnosed as havin osteopporosis for two years, who recently found out that hi illness is the rare Gaucher's disease.Gaucher's disease symptoms include: brittle bones (he lost 9 inches off his hieght); enlarged liver and spleen; interna bleeding; and fatigue (all the time). The problem (in Type 1) i attributed to a genetic mutation where there is a lack of th enzyme glucocerebroside in macrophages so the cells swell up This will eventually cause deathEnyzme replacement therapy has been successfully developed an approved by the FDA in the last few years so that those patient administered with this drug (called Ceredase) report a remarkabl improvement in their condition. Ceredase, which is manufacture by biotech biggy company--Genzyme--costs the patient $380,00 per year. Gaucher\'s disease has justifyably been called "the mos expensive disease in the world"NEED INFOI have researched Gaucher's disease at the library but am relyin on netlanders to provide me with any additional information**news, stories, report**people you know with this diseas**ideas, articles about Genzyme Corp, how to get a hold o   enough money to buy some, programs available to help wit   costs**Basically ANY HELP YOU CAN OFFEThanks so very muchDeborah

>>>Another uncommon problem is maternal hemorrhage.  I don't remember th>>incidence, but it is something like 1 in 1,000 or 10,000 births.  It is har>>to see how you could handle it at home, and you wouldn't have very much time>>>thing you might consider is that people's risk tradeoffs vary.  I conside>>a 1/1,000 risk of loss of a loved one to require considerable effort i>>the avoiding>Mark, you seem to be terrified of the birth procesThat's ridiculous>and unable t>believe that women's bodies are actually designed to do itThey aren't designed, they evolved.  And, much as it discomforts us, ihumans a trouble-free birth process was sacrificed to increased brain ancranial size.  Wild animals have a much easier time with birth than humans doDomestic horses and cows typically have a worse time.  To give you an ideamy family tree is complicated because a few of my pioneer great-greatgrandfathers had several wives, and we never could figure out which wifhad each child.  One might ask why this happened.  My great-greatgrandfathers were, by the time they reached their forties, quite prosperoufarmers.  Nonetheless, they lost several wives each to the rigors ochildbirth; the graveyards in Spencer, Indiana, and Boswell, North Dakotacontain quite a few gravestones like "Ida, wf. of Jacob Liptrap, anbaby, May 6, 1853.>You wante>to section all women carrying breech in case one in a hundred or >thousand breech babies get hung up in second stageMore like one in ten.  And the consequences can be devastating; I havdirect experience of more than a dozen victims of a fouled-up breech birth>and now you wan>all babies born in hospital based on a guess of how likely materna>hemorrhage is and a false belief that it is fatalIt isn't always fatal.  But it is often fatal, when it happens out oreach of adequate help.  More often, it permanently damages one's healthClearly women's bodies _evolved_ to give birth (I am no believer in divindesign); however, evolution did not favor trouble-free births for humans. >You have your kids where you want. You encourage your wife t>get six inch holes cut through her stomach muscles, expose hersel>to anesthesia and infection, and whatever other "just in case" measure>you think are necessaryMy, aren't we wroth!  I haven't read a more outrageous straw man attacin months!  I can practically see your mouth foamWe're statistically sophisticated enough to balance the risks.  AlthougI can't produce exact statistics 5 years after the last time we lookethem up, rest assured that we balanced C-section risks against other risksI wouldn't encourage my wife to have a Caesarean unless it was clearlindicated; on the other hand, I am opposed (on obvious grounds) to waitinuntil an emergency to give inAnd bear this in mind: my wife took the lead in all of these decisionsWe talked things over, and I did a lot of the leg work, but the maidecisions were really hers>But I for one am bothered by your continue>suggestions, especially to the misc.kidders pregnant for the firs>time, that birth is dangerous, even fatal, and that all thes>unpleasant things are far better than the risks you run just doin>it naturallyI don't know of very many home birth advocates, even, that think thaa first-time mother should have her baby at home>I'm no Luddite. I've had a section. I'm planning a hospital birt>this time. But for heaven's sake, not everyone needs thatBut people should bother to find out the relative risks.  My wife waunwilling to take any significant risks in order to have nice surroundingsIn view of the intensity of the birth experience, I doubt surroundinghave much importance anyway.  Somehow the values you're advocating seeall lopsided to me: taking risks, even if fairly small, of serioupermanent harm in order to preserve something that is, after allan esthetic consideration--Mark A. > >I have been taking prednisone 5mg twice a day for a while to contro> >Ulcerative Colitis. It seems like if I reduce the dosage, the proble> >becomes worse. At this point, i see myself taking prednisone for a lon> >long time, perhaps for ever. I was wondering about long term major sid> >effects, things like potential birth defects, arthritis etc. I have bee> >putting on weight, my face looks puffed and round, experience sudden moo> >swings. As I understand, these are all short termI second what Spenser Aden said in reply.  Additionally, it is hard to sawhat type of response you ar3e having to prednisone since you did not sahow long you have been on it.  Patients are generally kept on steroids fomonths before thinking about tapering.  Alternatives to daily dosing areevery other day dosing, in your case 20mg every other day would be a startAnother option if it is not possible to get you off prednisone is to starazathioprine.  Like Spenser said, you should generally be on another druin addition to your prednisone, like asulfidine.  A lot of the specificabout options, though, depends on severity, location, and duration ofdisease, as well as histology, so take advice off the net for what iis worth. I treat patients with UC and Crohn's.  An educated patient is a goodpatient, but let your doctor know where the advice came from so thingcan be put in context.  You should also be a member of the Crohn's anColitis Foundation of America.  1-800-932-2423 office / 1-800-343-363info hotlineBest of Luck to youSteve Hollandgila005@uabdpo.dpo.uab.ed

        I am looking for publically accessible sources of data depicting braiand neuron functions.  Especially interesting would be volumetric data frobrain scans, electromicographs, and so forth.  Please email me and let me knoif you know of such-------------------------------------------------------The HumBio Project is a CD-ROM-based curriculum tool for sixth-, seventh-, aneigth-graders, studying the function of the human brain and the effects oneurotransmitters, alcohol, and drugs.  The will be a special focus in depictinthe effects of neurotransmitters on behavior        Volotta Interactive Video is producing this project for Stanford UniverityWe are currently in a pre-production phase and we are looking for data sets anvisualizations depicting brain function on the whole brain, neuron and moleculalevels.  We intend to use state-of-the-art visualization tools to rendeinstructive visualizations from two-, three-, and four-dimensional data sets awell as using already-completed visualizations to their best effect
Contents of file 58053
The HumBio Project:  Call for Data and VisualizationThe HumBio Project is a CD-ROM-based curriculum tool for sixth-, seventh-, aneigth-graders, studying the function of the human brain and the effects oneurotransmitters, alcohol, and drugs.  The will be a special focus in depictinthe effects of neurotransmitters on behavior\tVolotta Interactive Video is producing this project for Stanford UniversityWe are currently in a pre-production phase and we are looking for data sets anvisualizations depicting brain function on the whole brain, neuron and moleculalevels.  We intend to use state-of-the-art visualization tools to rendeinstructive visualizations from two-, three-, and four-dimensional data sets awell as using already-completed visualizations to their best effect\tIf you're interested in sharing your data for the purpose of education ansupporting the introductions of CD-ROM and scientific visualization technologieinto our schools, please e-mail phughes@igc.org.  Include your nameorganization, and type and format of data you might be willing to provide.  Ware eager to begin production in the next few months and will be excited to heafrom youSincerelyPeter HugheThe HumBio Projec(The HumBio Project is not in any way affiliated with Apple Computer or IGC.

Contents of file 58058
>How long does it take a smoker's lungs to clear of the tar after quitting?>Does your chances of getting lung cancer decrease quickly or does it tak>a considerable amount of time for that to happenThe answer to your first question is rather difficult to answer withoudoing a lot of autopsies.  The second question is something that's beeknown for some time.  It appears that within about 15 years of quittinsmoking a person's risk for developing lung cancer drops to that of thperson who never smoked (assuming you do not get lung cancer in thinterim!).  The risk to someone who smoked the equivalent of a pack peday for 40 years is around 20 times as high as a non-smoker.  Stilrather low overall, but significant.  Personally, I'd be more concerneabout heart disease secondary to smoking -- it's much more common, aneven a small increase in risk is significant there--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=  Kenneth Gilbert              __|__        University of Pittsburgh   =  General Internal Medicine      |      "...dammit, not a programmer!  =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

kxgst1+@pitt.edu (Kenneth Gilbert) writes>Unfortunately it was rather poorly researched, and would not be availabl>today if it were just invented.  Keep in mind however that those wer>the days when a bottle of Coca Cola really did contain coca extract an>a certain amount of active cocaine.  Times have changed, and our attitude>need to change with them Well, yes.  That was a part of my point.  Aspirin has its problems, buin some situations it is useful.  Ditto stuff like licorice root.  Takinanything as a drug for theraputic purposes implicitly carries the ideof taking a dose where the benefits are not exceeded by any unwantedadditional effects.  Taking any drug when the potential ill-effects arnot known is a risk assumed by the parties involved, and it may be thain a given situation the risk is worthwhile   Like Prozac, for instance; Prozac has been shown to be theraputic isome cases where the tri-cyclics fail.  But Prozac hasn't been in usthat long, and it really isn't clear what if any effects it may havwhen taken over long periods of time, even though it has been testeby present day standards.  Should Prozac be taken off the market becauslong-term effects, if any, are not known?  IMHO, i'd say noeucli>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=->=  Kenneth Gilbert                |          University of Pittsburgh   >=  General Internal Medicine    --*--        Pittsburgh, PA             >=  kxgst1+@pitt.edu               |      "...dammit, not a programmer!  >=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=->-->=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=->=  Kenneth Gilbert                |          University of Pittsburgh   >=  General Internal Medicine    --*--        Pittsburgh, PA             >=  kxgst1+@pitt.edu               |      "...dammit, not a programmer!  -Euclid K.       standard disclaimers appl"It is a bit ironic that we need the wave model [of light] to understand thpropagation of light only through that part of the system where it leaves ntrace."  --Hudson & Nelson (_University_Physics_

Noise hurt, light hurtJL> thinking hurt. Othetherapies may be more specific: beta-blockers such as propranolowork better in migraine than tension-type headacheThe most important thing, from your perspective, is that you gorelief.  Also, please understand that a diagnosis other thamigraine does not necessarily mean "psychogenic"; I suspect thaorganic factors play as large a role in tension-type headache as imigraine-- . Th>>fact that you know a few people who have been overweight and ar>>now stable at a lower (normal or just less?) weight does no>>contradict the observation that only 5-10 per cent can maintai>>ideal weight with current technology>Actually, the observation is that only 5-10% of those who seek hel>from your so-called "diet evangelists" can maintain their weight.  >happen to agree with Keith Lynch that there are many people who ca>and do lose weight on their own, and who are not reflected in th>dismal failure rate that is often quoted>Wasn't there a study where a researcher asked a more general population>perhaps some part of a university community, about weight loss and he/sh>found that a much higher percentage had lost and maintained?In fact Adiposity 101 mentions a similar study (search for "lifevents" in any recent version of Adiposity 101)The problem with anecdotal reports about individuals who havlost weight and kept it off is that we don't know what causethe weight gain in the first place.  This is critical becaussomeone who gains weight because of something temporary (drueffect, life event, etc.) may appear successful at dieting whethe weight loss was really the result of reversing the temporarcondition that caused the weight gain--Chuck Forsberg WA7KGX          ...!tektronix!reed!omen!cafAuthor of YMODEM, ZMODEM, Professional-YAM, ZCOMM, and DS  Omen Technology Inc    "The High Reliability Software17505-V NW Sauvie IS RD   Portland OR 97231   503-621-340

Contents of file 58083
On 5 Apr 93 23:27:26 GMT, vida@mdavcr.mda.ca (Vida Morkunas) saidVida> Can one develop inner-ear problems from too much flying?  I heaVida> that pilots and steward/esses have a limit as to the maximuVida> number of flying hours -- what are these limits?  What are thVida> main problems associated with too many long-haul (over 4 hoursVida> tripsThe crew rest requirements are to prevent undue fatigue.  The cockpicrew (pilot) limits are somewhat more stringent than the cabin crelimits for this reason.  Crew rest requirements address amount of timon duty plus rest time.  A tired crew is an accident-prone crewThe only limits I know of for inner-ear problems are in militaraircraft, which are frequently unpressurized or less reliablpressurized.  Not being able to clear the ears renders aircrew memberDNIF (duties not involving flying) or grounded until the ears clearFlying can accentuate problems if ears don't clear.  If you don't havbig pressure changes, you may not know that you've got a problem.  Buif you zip up to 5,000 or 6,000 ft (the usual cabin altitude in aairliner) and then back down to sea level, you may discover a problemEars don't clear readily because of allergies, colds, infections, ananatomical problems.  The last won't change; the first three canMedication (decongestants or antihistimines, usually) can helpChewing gum, sucking hard candy (or a bottle for babies)yawning--these will help all four causes-Mary Shafer  DoD #0362 KotFR NASA Dryden Flight Research Facility, Edwards, Cshafer@rigel.dfrf.nasa.gov                    Of course I don't speak for NAS "A MiG at your six is better than no MiG at all."  Unknown US fighter pilo
Contents of file 58084
jec@watson.ibm.com wrote: A very simple question : it seems to me that the contraceptiv: pill just prevents the ovule to nest in the vagina and forces it t: fall every month. But it does not prevent the fertilzation of the: ovule. Is it true ? If yes, is there a risk of extra-uterin: pregnancy, that is the development of the ovule inside the Fallopia: tube Actually that is not how the pill works, but it *is* how the IUD worksThe oral contraceptive pill actually *prevents* ovulation from occurinby providing negatve feedback to the pituitary gland, and thus preventinthe LH surge that normally occurs at the time of ovulation.  With the IUwhat happens is that fertilization may occur, but the device preventimplantation within the wall of the uterus (*not* the vagina)-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=  Kenneth Gilbert              __|__        University of Pittsburgh   =  General Internal Medicine      |      "...dammit, not a programmer!  =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do realize that since this is a relatively ne>disorder (first documented in 1974 in a fertility clinic in Scandanavia>and is therefore "controversial"I do not know a lot about this, except from seeing one patient wit"Kartagener\'s syndrome", which is a form of immotile cilia syndromin which there is situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chroniinfections. "Situs inversus" means that organs are on the wronside of the body, and can be complete or partial. It is interestinmedically because the normal location of organs is caused in parby the "normal" rotation associated with ciliary motion, so that iabsence of this, laterality can be "random." People with situinversus are quite popular at medical schools, because of theirarity, and the fact that most doctors get a bit upset when thecan't find the patient's heart sounds (because they're on the wronside).According to Harrison's, immotile cilia syndrom is an autosomarecessive, which should imply that on average one child in fouin a family would be affected. But there may be much more curreninformation on this, and as usual in medicine, we may be talkinabout more than one conditiion. I would suggest that you ask youpediatrician about contacting a medical geneticics specialist, owhich there is probably one at NCSU-k
Contents of file 58101
>Can anyone out there enlighten me on the relationship betwee>lung disorders and "clubbing", or swelling and widening, of th>fingertips?  What is the mechanism and why would a physicia>call for chest xrays to diagnose the cause of the clubbingPurists often distinguish between "true" clubbing and "pseudoclubbing, the difference being that with "true" clubbing thangle of the nail when viewed from the side is constantlnegative when proceeding distally (towards the fingertip)With "pseudo" clubbing, the angle is initially positive, thenegative, which is the normal situation. "Real" internistcan talk for hours about clubbing. I'm limited to a couplof minutesWhether this distinction has anything to do with reality ientirely unclear, but it is one of those things that internistlove to paw over during rounds. Supposedly, only "true" clubbinis associated with disease. The problem is that the list odiseases associated with clubbing is quite long, and includeboth congenital conditions and acquired disease. Since many othese diseases are associated with cardiopulmonary problemleading to right to left shunts and chronic hypoxemia, it ivery reasonable to get a chest xray. However, many of thecongenital abnormalities would only be diagnosed with a cardiacatheterization.The cause of clubbing is unclear, but presumably relates tsome factor causing blood vessels in the distal fingertip tdilate abnormally.Clubbing is one of those things from an examination which ia tipoff to do more extensive examination. Often, howeverthe cause of the clubbing is quite apparent-k

Contents of file 58103
>This past weekend a friend of mine lost his 13 month ol>daughter in a matter of hours to a form of menangitis.  Th>person informing me called it 'Nicereal Meningicocis' (sp?)>In retrospect, the disease struck her probably sometime on>Friday evening and she passed away about 2:30pm on Saturday>The symptoms seemed to be a rash that started small an>then began progressing rapidly. She began turning blu>eventually which was the tip-off that this was seriou>but by that time it was too late (this is all second hand info.)>My question is>Is this an unusual form of Menangitis?  How is it transmitted>How does it work (ie. how does it kill so quickly)There are many organisms, viral, bacterial, and fungal, which cacause meningitits, and the course of these infections variewidely. The causes of bacterial meningitis vary with age: in adultpneumococcus (the same organism which causes pneumococcal pneumoniais the most common cause, while in children Hemophilus influenzais the most common causeWhat you are describing is meningitis from Neisseria meningitidiswhich is the second most common cause of bacterial meningitis iboth groups, but with lower incidence in infants. This organisis also called the "meningococcus", and is the source of thcommon epidemics of meningitis that occur and are popularized ithe press. Without prompt treatment (and even WITH it in some cases)the organism typically causes death within a day.This organism, feared as it is, is actually grown from the throatof many normal adults. It can get to the meninges by differenways, but blood borne spread is probably the usual case.Rifampin (an oral antibiotic) is often given to family and contactof a case of meningococcal meningitis, by the waySorry, but I don't have time for a more detailed reply. Meningitiis a huge topic, and sci.med can't do it justice-k

Contents of file 58109
I noticed several years ago that when I took analgesics fairly regularly(motrin at the time), I seemed to get a lot of migraines.  But haforgotten about that until I started reading some of the posts hereI generally don't take NSAIDS or Tylenol for headaches, because I'vfound them to be ineffective.  However, I have two other pain sourcethat force me to take NSAIDS (currently Naprosyn).  First, is sompelvic pain that I get at the beginning of my period, and then mucworse at midcycle.  I have had surgery for endometriosis in the pas(~12 years ago), so the Drs. tell me that my pain is probably duto the endometriosis coming back.  I've tried Synarel, it reducethe pain while I took it (3 mos), but the pain returned immediatelafter I stopped.  Three doctors have suggested hysterectomy as thonly "real solution" to my problem.  Although I don\'t expect to havany more children, I don't like the idea of having my uterus anone remaining ovary removed (the first ovary was removed when I hathe surgery for endometriosis).  One of the Drs that suggesteI get a hysterectomy is an expert in laser surgery, but perhaps thinkthat type of procedure is only worthwhile on women who still plato have children.  So basically all I'm left with is toughing outhe pain.  This would be impossible without Naprosyn (or somethinsimilar - but not aspirin, that doesn't work, and Motrin gave mhorrible gastritis a few years ago, so I'm through with it).  Ifact, Naprosyn works very well at eliminating the pain if I takit regularly as I did when I had severe back pain (and pain in bothlegs) as I'll discuss in a moment.  Generally though, I wait untiI have the pain before I take the Naprosyn, but then it takeseveral hours for it reduce the pain (it's actually quite effectivat reducing the pain, it just takes quite a while).  In the meantimI'm frequently in severe painThe other pain source I have is chronic lower back pain resulting ibilateral radiculopathy.  I've had MRIs, Xrays, CT scan, and EMG(I've had 2 of them, and don't intend to ever do that again) witnerve conduction tests.  The tests have not been conclusive as twhat is causing my back and leg pain.  The MRI reports both say I havseveral bulging, degeneratig disks, and from the Xrays (and MRI, I thinkit is apparent that I have arthritis.  The reading on the CT scawas that there are two herniations (L3-L4, and L4-L5), but otherhav looked at the films and concluded that there are no herniationsThe second EMG and nerve conduction studies shows significant denervatiocompared to the first EMG.  Oh yeah, I had some other horrible testcalled something like Somatic Evoked Response which showed that th"internal nerves" are working fine.   Anyway, the bottom line is thaI sometimes have severe pain in both legs and back pain.  The back paiis there all the time, but I can live with it.  When the leg pain is thereI need some analgesic/anti-inflammatory medication to reduce the paito a level where I can work.  So I took Naprosyn regulary for 6-months (every time I tried to stop the leg pain got worse, so I'dalways resume).  Since last November I have taken it much less frequentlyand primarily for the pelvic pain.  I have been going to physicatherapy for the last 8 months (2-3 times a week).  After the first montor so, my therapist put me on pelvic traction (she had tried it earlierbut it had caused a lot of pain in my back, this time she tried it aa lower weight).  After a month or two, the pain in my legs began goinaway (but the traction aways caused discomfort in my lower back, whiccould be reduced with ultrasound and massage).  So now, I don't havnearly as much pain in my legs, in fact my therapist took me oftraction about 2 weeks agoGetting back to my original reason for this post...  Even if I can avoitaking analgesic for headaches, I really can't avoid them entirely becausI have other pain sources, that "force" me to use them (Oh, I forgoto mention that it has been suggested to me that I have back surgerybut I'm avoiding that too).  I find the migraines difficult to deal withoccassionally I have to take off work, but usually I can work, but aa reduced capacity (I'm a systems engineer and do a lot of readinand writing).  When the pelvic pain is bad, I can't concentrate muchI usually end up jumping out of my chair every few minutes, becausthe pain is so bothersome.  When the pain in my back is bad, it cacause severe burning in both legs, shooting pains in my legs, electrishock type of pain in my feet and toes, and basically when it gets baI can't really sit at all.  Then I end up spending most of my time homand in bed.  So even if the analgesics contribute to the migraines, thmigraines are more tolerable than the other pain sources.  I get a loof migraines, an average of 3 to 4 a month, which last 1-3 daysI've taken cafergot (the first time the caffiene really got to me sI reduced the dosage), but I don't like the side effects (if I takmore than two I get diahrea).  If I get a very bad headache, I wileventually take the cafergot.  My neurologist wasn't very helpful wheI told him my problems with cafergot, he said that when sumatriptabecomes available, I should try that.  I've tried several other medication(fiornal, midrin, fiornal with codeine, tegretol, and inderal) buthey either didn't work, or I couldn't tolerate them.  So what can I doMy doctor's seem to be satisfied with me just trying to tolerate thpain, which I agree with most of the time, but not when I have a lot opain.  I've had some bad experiences with surgery (my heart stoppeonce from the anesthesia - I was told that it was likely thsuccinylcholine), and I've already had surgery several timesAnyway, the point of what I'm saying is that even if analgesics can contributto migraines, some people NEED to take them to tolerate other painJanice Rathman

jfare@53iss6.Waterloo.NCR.COM (Jim Fare) writes>A friend of mine has a trouble with her ears ringing. [etc.A.  Folks, do we have an FAQ on tinnitus yetB.  As a lo-o-o-ong time sufferer of tinnitus and as a neuroscientiswho has looked over the literature carefully I believe the followinare reasonable conclusions1. Millions of people suffer from chronic tinnitus2. The cause it not understood3. There is no accepted treatment that cures it4. Some experimental treatments may have helped some people a bit, buthere have be no reports--even anecdotal--of massive good results witany of these experimental drugs5. Some people with chronic loud tinnitus use noise blocking to get to sleep6. Sudden onset loud tinnitus can be caused by injuries and sometimeabates or goes away after a few months7. Aspirin is well known to exacerbate tinnitus in some people8. There is a national association of tinnitus sufferers in the US9. One usually gets used to it.  Especially when concentrating osomething else the tinnitus becomes unnoticed10.  Stress and lack of sleep make tinnitus more annoying, sometimes11.  I'm sure those of us who have it wish there was a cure, but theris notMark dubithe ol' professo
Contents of file 58112
I may not be the world's greatest expert on chiggers (a type omite indigenous to the south), but I certainly have spent a loof time contemplating the little buggers over the past six year(since we moved to N.C.).  Here are some observations gained fropainful experience  1. Reactions to chiggers vary greatly from person to person     Some people get tiny red bites.  Others (like me) are mor     sensitive and get fairly large swollen sore-like affairs  2. Chigger bites are the gift that keeps on giving.  I swea     that these things will itch for months  3. There is a lot of folklore about chiggers.  I think most o     it is fiction.  I have tried to do research on the critters     since they have such an effect on me.  The only book I coul     find on the subject was a *single* book in UNC's specia     collections library.  I have not yet gone through what i     required to get it  4. Based on my experience and that of my family members, the ol     folk remedy of fingernail polish simply doesn't work.  I recal     reading that the theory upon which it is based (that the chigger     burrow into your skin and continue to party there) is false.       think it is more likely that the reaction is to toxins of som     sort the little pests release.  But this is speculation  5. The *best* approach is prevention.  A couple of things work well     A good insect repellent (DEET) such as Deep Woods Off liberall     applied to ankles, waistband, etc. is a good start.  There i     another preparation called "Chig Away" that is a combination o     sulfur and some kind of cream (cortisone?) that originally wa     prepared for the Army and is not commercially available.  I     the summer I put this on my ankles every morning when I ge     up on weekends since I literally can't go outside where w     live (in the country) without serious consequences.  (The     apparently don't like sulfur much at all.  You can use sulfu     as a dust on your body or clothing to repel them.  6. No amount of prevention will be *completely* successful.  Forge     the fingernail polish.  I have finally settled upon a treatmen     that involves topical application of a combination of cortison     creme (reduces the inflamation and swelling) and benzocain     (relieves the itch).  I won't tell you all the things I've tried     Nor will I tell you some of the things my wife does since thi     counts as minor surgery and is best not mentioned (I also thin     it gains nothing)  7. The swelling and itching can also be significantly relieve     by the application of hot packs, and this seems to speed recover     as wellDoctors seem not to care much about chiggers.  The urban and suburbadoctors apparently don't encounter them much.  And the rural doctorseem to regard them as a force of nature that one must endure.  suspect that anyone who could come up with a good treatment for chiggerwould make a *lot* of money--Gary H. >I would like any information available on this rare disease.  I understan>that an operation referred to as POLLIDOTOMY may be in order.  Does anyon>know of a physician that performs this procedure. Some of them probabldidn't even come back for followup because they didn't want to admithey wouldn't take the drug or thought I was trying to kill them osomething.  What people don't understand about the inserts is that thereport every adverse side effect ever reported, without substantiatinthat the drug was responsible.  The insert is a legal document to slougliability from the manufacturer to the physician if something was thappen.  If patients want to have the most useful and reliable informatioon a drug they would be so much better off getting hold of one of thAMA drug evaluation books or something similar that is much more scientificThere are very few drugs that someone hasn't reported a death from takingPatients don't realize that and don't usually appreciate the riskto themselves properly. >>>>>> Explain.  I thought there were 3 types of cones, equivalent to RGB>>>You're basically right, but I think there are just 2 types.  One i>>sensitive to red and green, and the other is sensitive to blue and yellow.>>This is why the two most common kinds of color-blindness are red-green an>>blue-yellow>>Yes, I remember that now.  Well, in that case, the cones are indee>color sensitive, contrary to what the original respondent had claimed\tI\'m not sure who the "original respondent" was but treiterate cones respond to particular portions of the spectrum, jusas _rods_ respond to certain parts of the visible spectrum (bluegreein our case, reddish in certain amphibia), just as the hoseshoe cra_Limulus polyphemus_ photoreceptors respond to a certain portion othe spectrum etc.  It is a common misconception to confound wavelengtspecificity with being color sensitive, however the two are nosynonymous\tSo in sum and to beat a dead horse\t(1) When the outputs of a cone are matched for number oabsorbed photons _irrespective_ of the absorbed photons wavelengththe cone outputs are _indistinguishable_\t(2) Cones are simply detectors with different spectrasensitivities and are not any more "color sensitive" than are rodsommatidia or other photoreceptors\t(3) Color vision arises because outputs of receptors whicsample different parts of the spectrum (cones in this case) ar"processed centrally".  (The handwave is intentional\tI've worked and published research on rods and cones for ove10 years so the adherence to the belief that cones can "detect coloris frustrating.  But don't take my word for it.  I'm reposting a feexcellent articles together with two rather good but oldish colovision textsThe textsRobert Boynton (1979) _Human Color Vision_ Holt, Rhiehart and WinstoLeo M. Hurvich (1981) _Color Vision_, Sinauer AssociatesThe original articlesBaylor and Hodgkin (1973) Detection and resolution of visual stimuli bturtle phoreceptors, _J. Physiol._ 234 pp163-198Baylor Lamb and Yau (1978) Reponses of retinal rods to single photons_J. Physiol._ 288 pp613-634Schnapf et al. (1990) Visual transduction in cones of the monke_Macaca fascicularis_. J. Physiol. 427 pp681-713--Edwin Barkdolbarkdoll@lepomis.psych.upenn.edeb3@world.std.co--Edwin Barkdoleb3@world.std.co

DISCLAIMER: This list was compiled from unorthodox sources          that have shown themselves to be reliable.  The compiler of          this list is NOT a doctor of any kind, but is exercising his          First Amendment Constitutional RIGHT of FREE SPEECH on the          subjects of his choice.          ( MOST of these Remedies can be found in ANY Grocery Store.           MOST of the rest of them can be found in ANY Health Food          Store.  What is important is HOW they are used, and what          else is EXCLUDED DURING their use.           (1) THE 7-DAY FAST.               1st day: Eat as much fresh fruit as you want, one kind          at a time, preferably grapes.               2nd day: Eat all the vegetables you want, at least half          raw, including GARLIC; also, whole kernel corn to help scrape          clean the intestinal linings.               3rd day: Drink all the fresh fruit and vegetable juice          you want.  Preferably start with 16 to 32 ounces of prune          juice WITH PULP, followed by a gallon of pure (NOT from          concentrate) apple juice, then grape juice.  (Stay close to          your home bathroom.)               4th day: Eat all the UN-salted nuts (NO peanuts) and          dried fruit you want, preferably raisins and almonds (ALMONDS          CONTAIN LAETRILE.).               5th day: ONE GALLON OF LEMONADE.  Squeeze the juice from          two lemons into a gallon of water (preferably distilled), and          add 2 to 4 tablespoons of locally-made honey, (NO sugar).           Drink one glass per hour          [EVERYone, including healthy people, should do this one day          every week, preceded by a large glass of prune juice WITH          PULP.]               6th day: Same as 5th day.               7th day: Same as 6th day.               All 7 days, eat ONLY the foods listed above for each          day, along with your usual vitamin and mineral supplements,          plus as much DISTILLED WATER as you want.          (2) THE GRAPE DIET.               Eat 2 to 3 ounces of fresh grapes every 2 hours, 8 AM to          8 PM, every day for six days.  Eat NOTHING else during the          six days, but drink as much DISTILLED WATER as you want.               (3) APPLE CIDER VINEGAR               Mix a teaspoon of pure apple cider vinegar (NOT apple          cider "flavored" vinegar.  Regular vinegar is HARMFUL.) in a          glass of water (preferably distilled) and drink all of it.           Do this 3 or 4 times per day, for 3 weeks; then stop for a          week.  Repeat if desired.  Do this along with a normal          healthy diet of natural foods.  This remedy is especially          effective against those types of cancer that resemble a          FUNGUS, as well as against other kinds of fungus infections.                 (4) THE SEA-SALT & SODA BATH.  [Please keep an OPEN MIND.               Fill a bathtub with moderately warm water so the level          comes up almost to the overflow drain when you get in.           Immerse yourself in it for a minute, and then completely          dissolve in the bath water 1 pound of SUN-evaporated SEA-salt          (regular salt won't work.) and 1 pound of fresh baking-soda.               Soak in this bath for 10 to 20 minutes, while exercising          your fingers, toes, and limbs, turning sideways and onto your          stomach, dunking your head, sitting up and laying back down,          chomping your teeth together, etc..               Among other things, the SEA-salt & Soda Bath neutralizes          the accumulated effects of X-rays, etc., as described in the          book "Born To Be Magnetic, Vol. 2", by Frances Nixon, 1973.               PRECAUTIONS: Only the ONE person using each bath should          prepare it and drain it          For at least 30 minutes after taking the bath, stay away          from, and even out of sight of, other people.  (Your greatly          expanded Aura energy-field during that time could disrupt          other people's fields.)  Two hours after the bath, eat at          least 8 ounces of yogurt containing ACTIVE Yogurt Cultures.           (The bath may kill FRIENDLY bacteria also.)  Better yet, take          a 2-Billion-bacteria "Acidophilus" capsule, which is also an          EXCELLENT DAILY REMEDY AGAINST THE EFFECTS OF "A.I.D.S."          (because it kills all kinds of harmful bacteria in the          digestive tract, taking a big load off the remaining immune          system).  [Because this external bath can kill IN-ternal          bacteria, it may also be a CURE for "Lyme disease".          Do NOT take this bath within a few hundred miles of a thunder          storm, within 3 days of a full moon, nor during "Major" or          "Minor Periods" as listed in the "Solunar Tables" published          bimonthly in "Field & Stream" Magazine, (because of the          measurable disruptive ambient environmental energy-fields          present at those times)          Do NOT take this bath more than four times per year.                (5) MISCELLANEOUS NATURAL ANTI-CANCER REMEDIES:                     For skin cancer, apply STABILIZED Aloe Vera Jel to the               affected skin twice daily, and take 2 to 4 tablespoons               per day of STABILIZED Aloe Vera Juice internally, for               about 2 months. Do this once or twice per day,               hours before or after eating or drinking anything else.                Apply 3% hydrogen-peroxide directly to skin cancers               several times per day               Use hydrogen-peroxide ONLY if you are taking a good               daily dose of some of the various anti-oxidants               described above.               VITAMIN & MINERAL SUPPLEMENTS are more effective, and               much less expensive, when COMBINED together in MEGA               doses into SINGLE tablets made from NATURAL sources.               Cancer cells can NOT live in a strong (100,000 Maxwell)               NORTH MAGNETIC FIELD, especially if it is pulsating on               and off.  [A strong south magnetic field is an               aphrodisiac.]  In my opinion, ALL types of ionizing               radiation treatments for cancer should be REPLACED with               daily 30-minute doses of pulsating 100,000-Maxwell NORTH               magnetic fields. >>>My biggest resentment is the doctor who makes it seem like mos>>people with dizziness can be cured.  That's definitely not th>>case.  In most cases, like I said above, it is a long, tediou>>process that may or may not end up in a partial cure. >>Be sure to say "chronic" dizziness, not just dizziness.  Mos>patients with acute or subacute dizziness will get better>The vertiginous spells of Meniere's will also eventually g>away, however, the patient is left with a deaf earAll true.  And all good points>>To anyone suffering with vertigo, dizziness, or any variatio>>thereof, my best advice to you (as a fellow-sufferer) is this..>>just keep searching...don't let the doctors tell you there'>>nothing that can be done...do your own research...and let you>This may have helped you, but I'm not sure it is good genera>advice.  The odds that you are going to find some miracle wit>your own research that is secret or hidden from general knowledg>for this or any other disease are slim.  When good answers to thes>then, spending a great deal of time and energy on the medica>problem may divert that energy from more productive thing>in life.  A limited amount should be spent to assure yoursel>that your doctor gave you the correct story, but after it become>clear that you are dealing with a problem for which medicin>has no good solution, perhaps the best strategy is to joi>the support group and keep abreast of new findings but not t>make a career out of itWell, making a career out of it is a bit strong.  I still believthat doing your own research is very, very necessary.  I woulnot have progressed as much as I have today, unless I had spenthe many hours in Stanford's Med Library as I have doneAnd 5 years ago, it was clear that there was no medicine thatwould help me.  So should I have stopped searching.  Thangoodness I didn't.  Now I found that there is indeed medicinthat helps me. I think that what you've said is kind of idealistic.  That yowould go to one doctor, get a diagnosis, maybe get a seconopinion, and then move on with your lifeJust as an example... having seen 6 of the top specialists inthis field in the country, I have received 6 different diagnosesThese are the top names, the ones that people come to from all ovethe country.  I have HAD to sort all of this out myself.  Gointo a support group (and in fact, HEADING that support group) washelpful for a while, but after a point, I found it verunproductive.  It was much more productive to do library researchmake phone calls and put together the pieces of the puzzle myselfA recent movie, Lorenzo's Oil, offers a perfect example of whaI'm talking about.  If you haven't seen it, you should.  It's noa put down of doctor's and neither is what I'm saying.  Doctors aronly human and can only do so much.  But there are those of uout here who are intelligent and able to sometimes find a missinpiece of the puzzle that might have otherwise gone unnoticedI guess I'm biased because dizziness is one of those weird thingthat is still so unknown.  If I had a broken arm, or a weak heartor failing kidneys, I might not have the same opinion.  That's becausethose things are much more tangible and have much more concisedefinitions and treatments.  With dizziness, you just have tdecide to live with it or decide to live with it while trying tfind your way out of itI have chosen the latterLindlindae@netcom.netcom.co>-->--------------------------------------------------------------------------->Gordon Banks  N3JXP      | "Skepticism is the chastity of the intellect, an>geb@cadre.dsl.pitt.edu   |  it is shameful to surrender it too soon.">---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spoofing a keyboard over the serial por        2. X terminal        3. NeX        4. Silicon Graphic        5. IBM RS/600\t6. Other stuf    1. Spoofing a keyboard over the serial por\tIf you've got a proprietary computer which uses its own keyboar\t(Sun, HP, DEC, etc.) then you're going to have a hard time findin\ta vendor to sell you a compatible keyboard.  If your workstatio\truns the X window system, you're in luck.  You can buy a cheap use\tPC, hook your expensive keyboard up to it, and run a serial cabl\tto your workstation.  Then, run a program on the workstation to rea\tthe serial port and generate fake X keyboard events\tThe two main programs I've found to do this are KT and A2X\ta2x is a sophisticated program, capable of controlling the mouse, an\teven moving among widgets on the screen.  It requires a serve\textension (XTEST, DEC-XTRAP, or XTestExtension1).  To find out if you\tserver can do this, run 'xdpyinfo' and see if any of these string\tappear in the extensions list.  If your server doesn't have this\tyou may want to investigate compiling X11R5, patchlevel 18 or later\tor bugging your vendor\tkt is a simpler program, which should work with unextended X servers\tAnother program called xsendevent also exists, but I haven't seen it\tBoth a2x and kt are available via anonymous ftp from soda.berkeley.edu    2. X terminal\tAlso, a number of X terminals (NCD, Tektronics, to name a few) us\tPC-compatible keyboards.  If you have an X terminal, you may be al\tset.  Try it out with a normal PC keyboard before you go through th\ttrouble of buying an alternative keyboard.  Also, some X terminals ad\textra buttons -- you may need to keep your original keyboard aroun\tfor the once-in-a-blue-moon that you have to hit the Setup key    3. NeX\tNeXT had announced that new NeXT machines will use the Apple Deskto\tBus, meaning any Mac keyboard will work.  Then, they announced the\twere cancelling their hardware production.  If you want any kind o\tupgrade for an older NeXT, do it now    4. Silicon Graphic\tSilicon Graphics has announced that their newer machines (Indigo^2 an\tbeyond) will use standard PC-compatible keyboards and mice.  I don'\tbelieve this also applies to the Power Series machines.  It's no\tpossible to upgrade an older SGI to use PC keyboards, except b\tupgrading the entire machine.  Contact your SGI sales rep for mor\tdetails    5. IBM RS/600\tIBM RS/6000 keyboards are actually similar to normal PC keyboards.  |\tUnfortunately, you can't just plug one in.  You need two things: a  |\tcable converter to go from the large PC keyboard connector to the   |\tsmaller PS/2 style DIN-6, and a new device driver for AIX.  Believe |\tit or not, IBM wrote this device driver recently, I used it, and it |\tworks.  However, they don't want me to redistribute it.  I've been  |\ttold Judy Hume (512) 823-6337 is a potential contact.  If you learn |\tanything new, please send me e-mail.\t\t\t\t    |       6. Other stuf\tSome vendors here (notably: Health Care Keyboard Co. and AccuCorp\tsupport some odd keyboard types, and may be responsive to you\tqueries regarding supporting your own weird computer.  If you ca\tget sufficient documention about how your keyboard works (eithe\tfrom the vendor, or with a storage oscilloscope), you may be i\tluck. Archive-name: typing-injury-faq/softwarVersion: 1.8, 7th December 199This FAQ is actually maintained by Richard Donkin <richardd@hoskyns.co.uk>I post it, along with the other FAQ stuff.  If you have questions, you wanto send mail to Richard, not me.  -- Da\t\t    Software Tools to help with RS\t\t    ------------------------------This file describes tools, primarily software, to help prevent or manage RSIThis version now includes information on such diverse tools as calendaprograms and digital watches..Please let me know if you know any other tools, or if you have informatioor opinions on these ones, and I will update this FAQI am especially interested in getting reviews of these products from peoplwho have evaluated them or are using them. Richard Donkin                          Internet mail: richardd@hoskyns.co.uk             Tel: +44 71 814 5708 (directFax: +44 71 251 285Changes in this version     Added information on StressFree, another typing management tool     for WindowsTYPING MANAGEMENT TOOLS: these aim to help you manage your keyboard useby warning you to take a break every so often.  The better ones also includadvice on exercises, posture and workstation setup.  Some use sound hardware twarn of a break, others use beeps or screen messagesOften, RSI appears only after many years of typing, and the pain haa delayed action in the short term too: frequently you can be typinall day with little problem and the pain gets worse in the eveningThese tools act as an early warning system: by listening to theiwarnings and taking breaks with exercises, you don't have to wait for yourbody to give you a more serious and painful warning - that is, getting RSI    Tool: At Your Service (commercial software    Available from\tBright Sta\tTel: +1 (206) 451 369    Platforms: Mac (System 6.0.4), Window    Description\tProvides calendar, keyboard watch, email watch, and system info.\tWarns when to take a break (configurable).  Has a few recommendation\ton posture, and exercises.  Sound-oriented, will probably work best\twith sound card (PC) or with microphone (Mac).  Should be possibl\tto record your own messages to warn of break    Tool: AudioPort (sound card and software    Available from\tMedia Visio\tTel: +1 (510) 226 256    Platforms: P    Description\tA sound card to plug into your PC parallel port\tIncludes 'At Your Service'    Tool: Computer Health Break (commercial software    Available from\tEscape Ergonomics, In\t1111 W. El Camino Rea\tSuite 10\tMailstop 40\tSunnyvale, C\tTel: +1 (408) 730 841    Platforms: DO    Description\tAimed at preventing RSI, this program warns you to tak\tbreaks after a configurable interval, based on clock time, o\tafter a set number of keystrokes -- whichever is earlier\tIt gives you 3 exercises to do each time, randomly selected fro\ta set of 70.  Exercises are apparently tuned to the type of wor\tyou do - data entry, word processing, information processing\tExercises are illustrated and include quite a lot of text o\thow to do the exercise and on what exactly the exercise does\tCHB includes hypertext information on RSI that you can use\tto learn more about RSI and how to prevent it.  Other informatio\ton non-RSI topics can be plugged into this hypertext viewer\tA full glossary of medical terms and jargon is included\tCHB can be run in a DOS box under Windows, but does not the\twarn you when to take a break; it does not therefore appea\tuseful when used with Windows\tCost: $79.95; quantity discounts, site licenses    Comments\tThe keystroke-counting approach looks good: it seems bette\tto measure the activity that is causing you problems than t\tmeasure clock time or even typing time.  The marketing stuf\tis very good and includes some summaries of research papers\tas well as lots of arguments you can use to get your company\tto pay up for RSI management tools.     Tool: EyerCise (commercial software    Available from\tRAN Enterprise\tOne Woodland Park Dr\tHaverhill, MA  01830, U\tTel: 800-451-4487 (US only    Platforms: Windows (3.0/3.1), OS/2 PM (1.3/2.0) [Not DOS    Description\tAimed at preventing RSI and eye strain, this program warns you to tak\tbreaks after a configurable interval (or at fixed times). Optionall\tdisplays descriptions and pictures of exercises - pictures ar\tanimated and program beeps you to help you do exercises at th\tcorrect rate.  Includes 19 stretches and 4 visual training\texercises, can configure which are included and how many repetition\tyou do - breaks last from 3 to 7 minutes.  Also includes online help\ton workplace ergonomics. \tQuote from their literature\t"EyerCise is a Windows program that breaks up your day with periodi\tsets of stretches and visual training exercises.  The stretches wor\tall parts of your body, relieving tension and helping to preven\tRepetitive Strain Injury.  The visual training exercises will improv\tyour peripheral vision and help to relieve eye strain.  Together thes\thelp you to become more relaxed and productive.\t"The package includes the book _Computers & Visual Stress_ by Edward C\tGodnig, O.D. and John S. Hacunda, which describes the ergonomic setu\tfor a computer workstation and provides procedures and exercises t\tpromote healthy and efficient computer use.\\tCost: $69.95 including shipping and handling, quantity discount\tfor resellers.  Free demo ($5 outside US)    Comments\tI have a copy of this, and it works as advertised: I would sa\tit is better for RSI prevention than RSI management, because i\tdoes not allow breaks at periods less than 30 minutes.  Also, i\tinterrupts you based on clock time rather than typing time, whic\tis not so helpful unless you use the keyboard all day.  Worked OK o\tWindows 3.0 though it did occasionally crash with a UAE - not sur\twhy. Also refused to work with the space bar on one PC, and ha\tone window without window controls.  Very usable though, and does no\trequire any sound hardware    Tool: Lifeguard (commercial software    Available from\tVisionary Softwar\tP.O. Box 6944\tPortland, OR  97201, U\tTel: +1 (503) 246-620    Platforms: Mac, DOS (Windows version underway    Description\tAimed at preventing RSI.  Warns you to take a brea\twith dialog box and sound.  Includes a list of exercise\tto do during breaks, and information on configuring you\tworkstation in an ergonomic manner.  Price: $59\tquantity discounts and site licenses.  The DOS product i\tbought in from another company, apparently; not sure ho\tequivalent this is to the Mac version\\tThe Mac version got a good review in Desktop Publisher\tMagazine (Feb 1991).  Good marketing stuff with useful\t2-page summaries of RSI problems and solutions, with\treferences    Tool: StressFree (commercial software, free usable demo    Available from\tLifeTime Softwar\tP.O. Box 8752\tHousto\tTexas 77287-7522, U\tTel: 800-947-2178 (US only\tFax: +1 (713) 474-206\tMail: 70412.727@compuserve.co\tDemo (working program but reduced functions) available from\t    Compuserve: Windows Advanced Forum, New Uploads section, or\t\t\tHealth and Fitness Forum, Issues At Work section.\t    Anon FTP:   ftp.cica.indiana.edu (and mirroring sites    Platforms: Windows (3.0/3.1) (Mac and DOS versions underway    Description\tAimed at preventing RSI, this program warns you to tak\tbreaks after a configurable interval (or at fixed times).\tDisplays descriptions and pictures of exercises - pictures ar\tanimated and program paces you to help you do exercises at th\tcorrect rate.  Quite a few exercises, can configure which one\tare included to some extent.  Online help\tVersion 2.0 is out soon, Mac and DOS versions will be base\ton this\tCost: $29.95 if support via CompuServe or Internet, otherwise $39.95.               Site license for 3 or more copies is $20.00 each\t      (NOTE: prices may have gone up for V2.0)    Comments\tI have had a play with this, and it works OK.  Its user interfac\tdesign is much better in 2.0, though still a bit unusual\texpensive tool around and it does the job.  It is also the onl\ttool with a redistributable demo, so if you do get the demo, post i\ton your local bulletin boards, FTP servers and Bitnet servers\tDoes not include general info on RSI and ergonomics, but it does\thave the ability to step backward in the exercise sequence\twhich is good for repeating the most helpful exercises    Tool: Typewatch (freeware), version 3.8 (October 1992    Available from\tEmail to richardd@hoskyns.co.u\tAnonymous ftp: soda.berkeley.edu:pub/typing-injury/typewatch.sha    Platforms: UNIX (tested on SCO, SunOS, Mach; character and X Window mode    Description\tThis is a shell script that runs in the background and warns yo\tto stop typing, based on how long you have been continuousl\ttyping.  It does not provide exercises, but it does chec\tthat you really do take a break, and tells you when yo\tcan start typing again. \tTypewatch now tells you how many minutes you have been typin\ttoday, each time it warns you, which is useful so yo\tknow how much you *really* type.  It also logs informatio\tto a file that you can analyse or simply print out. \tThe warning message appears on your screen (in character mode)\tin a pop-up window (for X Windows), or as a Zephyr messag\t(for those with Athena stuff).   Tim Freeman <tsf@cs.cmu.edu>\thas put in a lot of bug fixes, extra features and support for\tX, Zephyr and Mach\tNot formally supported, but email richardd@hoskyns.co.u\t(for SCO, SunOS, character mode) or tsf@cs.cmu.edu (for Mach\tX Window mode, Zephyr) if you have problems or want to give\tfeedback    Tool: Various calendar / batch queue program    Available from\tVarious source    Platforms: Variou    Description\tAny calendar/reminder program that warns you of an upcomin\tappointment can be turned into an ad hoc RSI management tool\tOr, any batch queue submission program that lets you submi\ta program to run at a specific time to display a message t\tthe screen\tUsing Windows as an example: create a Calendar file, an\tinclude this filename in your WIN.INI's 'load=' line s\tyou get it on every startup of Windows.  Suppose yo\twant to have breaks every 30 minutes, starting from 9 am\tPress F7 (Special Time...) to enter an appointment, ente\t9:30, hit Enter, and type some text in saying what the brea\tis for.  Then press F5 to set an alarm on this entry, and repeat\tfor the next appointment\tBy using Windows Recorder, you can record the keystroke\tthat set up breaks throughout a day in a .REC file.  Put thi\tfile on your 'run=' line, as above, and you will then, wit\ta single keypress, be able to set up your daily appointment\twith RSI exercises\tThe above method should be adaptable to most calendar programs.\tAn example using batch jobs would be to submit a simple jo\tthat runs at 9:30 am and warns you to take a break; this wil\tdepend a lot on your operating system\tWhile these approaches are not ideal, they are a good way of forcing\tyourself to take a break if you can't get hold of a suitable RSI\tmanagement tool.  If you are techie enough you might want t\twrite a version of Typewatch (see above) for your operatin\tsystem, using batch jobs or whatever fits best    Tool: Digital watches with count-down timer    Available from\tVarious sources, e.g. Casio BP-100    Description\tMany digital watches have timers that count down from a settabl\tnumber of minutes; they usually reset easily to that number, eithe\tmanually or automatically. \tWhile these are a very basic tool, they are very useful if yo\tare writing, reading, driving, or doing anything away fro\ta computer which can still cause or aggravate RSI.  The grea\tadvantage is that they remind you to break from whatever yo\tare doing\    Comments\tMy own experience was that cutting down a lot on my typing led t\tmy writing a lot more, and still reading as much as ever, whic\tactually aggravated the RSI in my right arm though the lef\tarm improved.  Getting a count-down timer watch has bee\tvery useful on some occasions where I write a lot in a day\tI have tried an old fashioned hour-glass type egg timer, bu\tthese are not much good because they do not give an audibl\twarning of the end of the time periodKEYBOARD REMAPPING TOOLS: these enable you to change your keyboard mappinso you can type one-handedly or with a different two-handed layout. One-handed typing tools may help, but be VERY careful about howyou use them -- if you keep the same overall typing workload yoare simply doubling your hand use for the hand that you use for typingand may therefore make matters worse    Tool: hsh (public domain    Available from\tAnonymous ftp: soda.berkeley.edu:pub/typing-injury/hsh.sha    Platforms: UNIX (don't know which ones    Description\tAllows one-handed typing and other general keyboard remappings\tOnly works through tty's (so, you can use it with a terminal o\tan xterm, but not most X programs)    Tool: Dvorak keyboard tools (various    Available from\tAnonymous ftp: soda.berkeley.edu:pub/typing-injury/xdvorak.\tAlso built into Windows 3.x.    Description\tThe Dvorak keyboard apparently uses a more rational layou\tthat involves more balanced hand use.   It *may* help preven\tRSI a bit, but you can also use it if you have RSI, since\tit will slow down your typing a *lot* :-) --Dan Wallach               "One of the most attractive features of a Connectiodwallach@cs.berkeley.edu  Machine is the array of blinking lights on the faceOffice#: 510-642-9585     of its cabinet." -- CM Paris Ref. >-*---->I wrote>>> ... Or, to use a phrasing that I think is more accurate, science>>> is the investigation of phenomena that avoids methods and reasoning>>> that are known to be erroneous from past foul-ups.>> I can agree with this if you are talking about the less fundamenta>> aspects of scientific method. ..>    ..>> ... In fact, I don't see the alternative, as I don't think that the>> fundamentals are capable of experimental investigation.  In sayin>> this I am agreeing with the work of people like Kuhn (1970),>> Feyerabend (1981) and Lakatos (1972)>      ...>While methodology cannot be subject to the same kind of "experimenta>investigation," as that to which it is applied, it *can* be criticall>appraised.  Methodologies can be compared to each other, sometimes b>the conflicting results they produce.  This kind of critical appraisa>and comparison, together with the inappropriateness of existin>methodologies for new fields of study, is what drives the evolution o>methodologies and how we think about them. As usual, you are missing the whole point, Russell, because you are nowilling to even consider questionning your basic article of faith, whicis that science is merely a matter of methodology and that the highespurpose of science is to avoid making mistakes. This is like saying that the most important aspect of business managemenis accurate bookkeeping. If science were no more than methodology and not making mistakes, iwould be a poor thing indeed.  What was the methodology of Darwin?  Whawas the methodology of Einstein?  What was, for that matter, thmethodology of Jenner and Pasteur? In an earlier article, Russell Turpin writes: >None of the foregoing should be read as meaning that we shoul>open the door to practitioners of quackery and psuedo-science>Modern advocates of homeopathy, chiropracty, and traditiona>Chinese medicine receive little respect because, for the mos>part, they use methods and reasoning that the kind of researc>Lee Lady recommends has shown to be terribly faulty.  (This doe>*not* imply that all their treatments are ineffective.  It *does>imply that those who rely on faulty methodology and reasoning ar>incapable of discovering *which* treatments are effective an>which are not.First of all, I think you are arguing against a straw man, because don't think that anyone here is arguing that quackery, pseudo-sciencehomeopathy, chiropracty, and traditional Chinese medicine should baccepted as science.  I, in particular, think the basic ideas ohomeopathy and chiropracty seem extremely flaky. What some of us do believe, however, is that some of these thing(including some of the flaky ideas) are deserving of serious scientifiattention. If in fact it were true, as you have stated above, that those who do nouse the currently fashionable methodology can have no idea what ieffective and what is not, then science today would not exist.  For alof current science is based on the past work of scientists whosmethodology, by current standards, was seriously flawed. It is certainly true that as methodology improves, we need to re-examinthose results derived in the past using less perfect methodologies.  It ialso true that the results obtained by people today who still rely onthose early methodologies needs to be re-examined in a more rigorousfashion by those qualified to do so credibly. But to say that nobody who fails to do elaborate double-blind studies icapable of knowing their ass from a hole in the ground and to say that nideas that come from outside the scientific establishment could possiblbe worthy of serious investigation ... this truly marks one's attitude adoctrinaire, cultist.  This attitude is not compatible with a belief ireason. -In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne

Archive-name: typing-injury-faq/generaVersion: $Revision: 4.28 $ $Date: 1993/04/13 04:17:58 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------         Answers To Frequently Asked Questions about Typing Injurie------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Typing Injury FAQ -- sources of information for people with typininjuries, repetitive stress injuries, carpal tunnel syndrome, etcCopyright 1992,1993 by Dan Wallach <dwallach@cs.berkeley.eduMany FAQs, including this one, are available on the archive sitpit-manager.mit.edu (alias rtfm.mit.edu) [18.172.1.27] in the directorpub/usenet/news.answers.  The name under which a FAQ is archived appearin the Archive-name line at the top of the article.  This FAQ is archiveas typing-injury-faq/general.There's a mail server also.  Just e-mail mail-server@pit-manager.mit.edwith the word 'help' on a line by itself in the bodyThe opinions in here are my own, unless otherwise mentioned, and do norepresent the opinions of any organization or vendor.  I'm not a medicadoctor, so my advice should be taken with many grains of salt[Current distribution: sci.med.occupational, sci.med, comp.human-factors {news,sci,comp}.answers, and e-mail to c+health@iubvm.ucs.indiana.edu sorehand@vm.ucsf.edu, and cstg-L@vtvm1.cc.vt.eduChanges since previously distributed versions are marked with change        |bars to the right of the text, as is this paragraph.                        |Table of Contents    ==1== Mailing lists, newsgroups, etc    ==2== The soda.berkeley.edu archiv    ==3== General info on injurie    ==4== Typing posture, ergonomics, prevention, treatmen    ==5== Requests for more inf    ==6== Reference==1== Mailing lists, newsgroups, etcUSENET News----------comp.human-factors occasionally has discussion about alternative input devicescomp.risks has an occasional posting relevant to injuries via computerssci.med and misc.handicap also tend to have relevant trafficThere's a Brand New newsgroup, sci.med.occupational, chartered specificallto discuss these things. If you can't uncompress a fillocally, soda will do it.  Just ask for the file, without the .Z extensionIf you're unable to ftp to soda, send me e-mail and we'll see what wcan arrange==3== General info on injurieFirst, and foremost of importance: if you experience pain at all, theyou absolutely need to go see a doctor.  As soon as you possibly can.  Thdifference of a day or two can mean the difference between a short recoverand a long, drawn-out ordeal.  GO SEE A DOCTOR.  Now, your garden-varietdoctor may not necessarily be familiar with this sort of injury.  Generallyany hospital with an occupational therapy clinic will offer specialists ithese kinds of problems.  DON'T WAIT, THOUGH.  GO SEE A DOCTORThe remainder of this information is paraphrased, without permission, froa wonderful report by New Zealand's Department of Labour (OccupationaSafety and Health Service): "Occupational Overuse Syndrome. Treatment anRehabilitation: A Practitioner\'s Guide"First, a glossary (or, fancy names for how you shouldn't have your hands)(note: you're likely to hear these terms from doctors and keyboard vendors :  RSI: Repetitive Strain Injury - a general term for many kinds of injurie  OOS: Occupational Overuse Syndrome -- synonym for RS  CTD: Cumulative Trauma Disorder -- another synonym for RS  WRULD: Work-Related Upper Limb Disorders -- yet another synonym for RS  CTS: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (see below  Hyperextension:  Marked bending at a joint  Pronation: Turning the palm down  Wrist extension: Bending the wrist up  Supination: Turning the palm up  Wrist flexion: Bending the wrist down  Pinch grip: The grip used for a pencil  Ulnar deviation: Bending the wrist towards the little finger  Power grip: The grip used for a hammer  Radial Deviation: Bending the wrist toward the thumb  Abduction: Moving away from the body  Overspanning: Opening the fingers out wideNow then, problems come in two main types: Local conditions and diffusconditions.  Local problems are what you'd expect: specific musclestendons, tendon sheaths, nerves, etc. being inflamed or otherwise hurtDiffuse conditions, often mistaken for local problems, can involve muscldiscomfort, pain, burning and/or tingling; with identifiable areas otenderness in muscles, although they\'re not necessarily "the problem.--- Why does Occupational Overuse Syndrome occur?  Here's the theoryNormally, your muscles and tendons get blood through capillaries whicpass among the muscle fibers.  When you tense a muscle, you restricthe blood flow.  By the time you're exerting 50% of your full poweryou're completely restricting your blood flowWithout fresh blood, your muscles use stored energy until they run outthen they switch to anaerobic (without oxygen) metabolism, which generatenasty by-products like lactic acid, which cause painOnce one muscle hurts, all its neighbors tense up, perhaps to relieve thload.  This makes sense for your normal sort of injury, but it only makethings worse with repetitive motion.  More tension means less blood flowand the cycle continuesAnother by-product of the lack of blood flow is tingling and numbness froyour nerves.  They need blood tooAnyway, when you're typing too much, you're never really giving a changfor the blood to get back where it belongs, because your muscles neverelax enough to let the blood through.  Stress, poor posture, and pooergonomics, only make things worse--- Specific injuries you may have heard of(note: most injuries come in two flavors: acute and chronic.  Acutinjuries are severely painful and noticable.  Chronic conditions havless pronounced symptoms but are every bit as real.Tenosynovitis -- an inflamation of the tendon sheath.  Chronic tenosynovitioccurs when the repetitive activity is mild or intermittent: not enough tcause acute inflamation, but enough to exceed the tendon sheath's abilitto lubricate the tendon.  As a result, the tendon sheath thickens, getinflamed, and you've got your problemTendonitis -- an inflammation of a tendon.  Repeated tensing of a tendocan cause inflamation.  Eventually, the fibers of the tendon start separatingand can even break, leaving behind debris which induces more friction, morswelling, and more pain.  "Sub-acute" tendonitis is more common, which entaila dull ache over the wrist and forearm, some tenderness, and it gets worswith repetitive activityCarpal Tunnel Syndrome -- the nerves that run through your wrist into youfingers get trapped by the inflamed muscles around them.  Symptoms includfeeling "pins and needles", tingling, numbness, and even loss of sensationCTS is often confused for a diffuse conditionAdverse Mechanical Tension -- also known as 'neural tension', this is wherthe nerves running down to your arm have become contracted and possiblcompressed as a result of muscle spasms in the shoulders and elsewhereAMT can often misdiagnosed as or associated with one of the other OOSdisorders.  It is largely reversible and can be treated with physiotherapy(brachial plexus stretches and trigger point therapy)Others: for just about every part of your body, there's a fancy name foa way to injure it.  By now, you should be getting an idea of how OOconditions occur and why.  Just be careful: many inexperienced doctormisdiagnose problems as Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, when in reality, yomay have a completely different problem.  Always get a second opiniobefore somebody does something drastic to you (like surgery)==4== Typing posture, ergonomics, prevention, treatmenThe most important element of both prevention and recovery is to reductension in the muscles and tendons.  This requires learning how to relaxIf you're under a load of stress, this is doubly important.  Tune outhe world and breath deep and regular.  Relaxing should become a guidinprinciple in your work: every three minutes take a three second breakEVERY THREE MINUTES, TAKE A THREE SECOND BREAK.  Really, do it everthree minutes.  It's also helpful to work in comfortable surroundingscalm down, and relaxIf you can't sleep, you really need to focus on this.  Rest, sleep, anrelaxation are really a big dealThere are all kinds of other treatments, of course.  Drugs can reducinflamation and pain.  Custom-molded splints can forcefully prevent baposture.  Surgery can fix some problems.  Exercise can help strengtheyour muscles.  Regular stretching can help prevent injury.  Good posturand a good ergonomic workspace promote reduced tension.  Ice or hot-colcontrast baths also reduce swelling.  Only your doctor can say what's besfor you--- Posture -- here are some basic guidelines.  [I so liked the way this wawritten in the New Zealand book that I'm lifting it almost verbatim froAppendix 10. -- dwallach. Let your shoulders relax. Let your elbows swing free. Keep your wrists straight. Pull your chin in to look down - don't flop your head forward. Keep the hollow in the base of your spine. Try leaning back in the chair. Don't slouch or slump forward. Alter your posture from time to time. Every 20 minutes, get up and bend your spine backwardSet the seat height, first.  Your feet should be flat on the floor.  Thereshould be no undue pressure on the underside of your thighs near the kneesand your thighs should not slope too muchNow, draw yourself up to your desk and see that its height is comfortablto work at.  If you are short, this may be impossible.  The beest remedis to raise the seat height and prevent your legs from dangling by using footrestNow, adjust the backrest height so that your buttocks fit into the spacbetween the backrest and the seat pan.  The backrest should support you ithe hollow of your back, so adjust its tilt to give firm support in thiareaIf you operate a keyboard, you will be able to spend more time leaninback, so experiment with a chair with a taller backrest, if available[Now, I diverge a little from the textA good chair makes a big difference.  If you don't like your chair, gfind a better one.  You really want adjustments for height, back angleback height, and maybe even seat tilt.  Most arm rests seem to get ithe way, although some more expensive chairs have height adjustable arrests which you can also rotate out of the way.  You should find a goostore and play with all these chairs -- pick one that's right for youIn the San Francisco Bay Area, I highly recommend "Just Chairs."  Thname says it all--- Keyboard drawers, wrist pads, and keyboard replacementsThere is a fair amount of controvery on how to get this right.  For sompeople, wrist pads seem to work wonders.  However, with good posture, yoshouldn't be resting your wrists on anything -- you would prefer youkeyboard to be "right there".  If you drop your arms at your side and thelift your hands up at the elbow, you want your keyboard under your handwhen your elbows are at about 90 degrees.  Of course, you want to avoipronation, wrist extension, and ulnar deviation at all costs.  Wrist padmay or may not help at this.  You should get somebody else to come anlook at how you work: how you sit, how you type, and how you relax.  It'often easier for somebody else to notice your hunched shoulders odeviated handsSome argue that the normal, flat keyboard is antiquated and poorldesigned.  A number of replacements are available, on the market, todayCheck out the accompanying typing-injury-faq/keyboards for much detail==5== Requests for more infClearly, the above information is incomplete.  The typing-injury archivis incomplete.  There's always more information out there.  If you'd likto submit something, please send me mail, and I'll gladly throw it inIf you'd like to maintain a list of products or vendors, that would bwonderful!  I'd love somebody to make a list of chair/desk vendors.  I'love somebody to make a list of doctors.  I'd love somebody to edit thabove sections, looking for places where I've obviously goofed==6== ReferenceI completely rewrote the information section here, using a wonderfuguide produced in New Zealand by their Occupational Safety & HealtService, a service of their Department of Labour.  Special thankto the authors: Wigley, Turner, Blake, Darby, McInnes, and HardingSemi-bibliographic reference    . Occupational Overuse Syndrom    . Treatment and Rehabilitation      A Practitioner's Guid       Published by the Occupational Safety and Health Servic    Department of Labou    Wellington    New Zealand    First Edition: June 199    ISBN 0-477-3499-    Price: $9.95 (New Zealand $'s, of courseThanks to Richard Donkin <richardd@hoskyns.co.uk> for reviewing this posting--Dan Wallach               "One of the most attractive features of a Connectiodwallach@cs.berkeley.edu  Machine is the array of blinking lights on the faceOffice#: 510-642-9585     of its cabinet." -- CM Paris Ref. Manual, v6.0, p48
