    (Michael Holloway) writes    (Lee Lady) writes>>I would also like to point out that most of the arguments about scienc>>in sci.med, sci.psychology, etc. are not about cases where people ar>>rejecting scientific argument/evidence/proof.  They are about cases wher>>no adequate scientific research has been done.   (In some cases, there i>>quite a bit of evidence, but it isn't in a format to fit doctrinair>>conceptions of what science is.) >Here it is again.  This indicates confusion between "proof" and the proces>of doing science. You are making precisely one of the points I wanted to makeI fully agree with you that there is a big distinction between th*process* of science and the end result. As an end result of science, one wants to get results that arobjectively verifiable.  But there is nothing objective about th*process* of science. If good empirical research were done and showed that there is some merito homeopathic remedies, this would certainly be valuable informationBut it would still not mean that homeopathy qualifies as a science.  Thiis where you and I disagree with Turpin.  In order to have science, onmust have a theoretical structure that makes sense, not a mercollection of empirically validated random hypothesesExperiment and empirical studies are an important part of science, buthey are merely the culmination of scientific research.  The mosimportant part of true scientific methodology is SCIENTIFIC THINKING. Without this, one does not have any hypotheses worth testing.  (Nohypotheses do not just leap out at you after you look at enough dataNor do they simply come to you in a flash one day while you're shaving olooking out the window.  At least not unless you've done a lot of reallgood thinking beforehand.) The difference between a Nobel Prize level scientist and a mediocrscientist does not lie in the quality of their empirical methodology. It depends on the quality of their THINKING. It really bothers me that so many graduate students seem to believe thathey are doing science merely because they are conducting empiricastudies.  And it bothers me even more that there are many fields, such acertain parts of psychology, where there seems to be no thinking at all,but mere studies testing ad hoc hypotheses. And I'm especially offended by Russell Turpin's repeated assertion thascience amounts to nothing more than avoiding mistakes.  Simply avoidinmistakes doesn't get you anywhere. -In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne

In patients witAMN (a less acute form of the same disease) there is some improvemenseen in the ability of nerve fibres to conduct impulses. I am posting to this group in hopes of finding someone out there inetwork newsland who has heard of something similar to what I am gointo describe here.  I have a fourteen year old daugter who experiencea seizure on November 3, 1992 at 6:45AM after eating Kellog's FrosteFlakes.  She is perfectly healthy, had never experienced anything likthis before, and there is no history of seizures in either side of thfamily.  All the tests (EEG, MRI, EKG) came out negative so the decisiowas made to do nothing and just wait to see if it happened againWell, we were going along fine and the other morning, April 5, she haa bowl of another Kellog's frosted kind of cereal, Fruit Loops (I aembarrassed to admit that I even bought that junk but every oncin a while...) So I pour it in her bowl and think "Oh, oh, this is thsame kind of junk she was eating when she had that seizure."  Tenminutes later she had a full blown seizures. This was her first exposurto a sugar coated cereal since the last seizureWhen I mentioned what she ate the first time as a possible reason fothe seizure the neurologist basically negated that as an idea.  Noafter this second episode, so similar in nature to the first, evehe is scratching his head.  Once again her EEG looks normal which understand can happen even when a person has a seizureOnce again we are waiting. I have been thinking that it would be gooto get to as large a group as possible to see if anyone has anexperience with this kind of thing.  I know that members of the medicacommunity are sometimes loathe to admit the importance that diet anfoods play in our general health and well-being.  Anyway, as you caguess, I am worried sick about this, and would appreciate any ideaanyone out there has.  Sorry to be so wordy but I wanted to really geacross what is going on hereThanks-Sharon Paulson                      s.s.paulson@larc.nasa.goNASA Langley Research CenteBldg. 1192D, Mailstop 156           Work: (804) 864-224Hampton, Virginia.  23681           Home: (804) 596-236

Contents of file 58764
>What about Kekule's infamous derivation of the idea of benzene ring>from a daydream of snakes in the fire biting their tails?  Is thi>specific enough to count?  Certainly it turns up repeatedly in basi>phil. of sci. texts as an example of the inventive component o>hypothesizing.And has been rather thoroughly demolished as myth by Robert Scott RootBernstein.  See his book, "Discovering".  Ring structures for benzenhad been proposed before Kekule', after him, and at the same time as himThe current models do not resemble Kekule's.  Many of the predecessorof Kekule's structure resemble the modern model moreI don\'t think "extra-scientific" is a very useful phrase in a discussioof the boundaries of science, except as a proposed definiens.  Extra-rationais a better phrase.  In fact, there are quite a number of well-known caseof extra-rational considerations driving science in a useful directionFor example, Pasteur discovered that racemic acid was a mixture oenantiomers (the origin of stereochemistry) partly because he liked friend's crank theory of chemical action.  The friend was wrong, buPasteur's discovery stood.  A prior investigator (Mitscherlich), lookinat the same phenomenon, had missed a crucial detail; presumably because hlacked Pasteur's motivation to find something that distinguished racemiacid from tartaric (now we say: d-tartaric) acidAgain, Pasteur discovered the differential fermentation of enantiomer(tartaric acid again) not because of some rational conviction, but becaushe was trying to produce yeast that lived on l-tartaric acid.  His notebookcontained fantasies of becoming the "Newton of mirror-image life," whiche never admitted publicallyPerhaps the best example is the discovery that DNA carries genes.  Averstarted this work because of one of his students, and ardent Anglophiland Francophobe Canadian, defended Fred Griffiths' discoveries in miceMost of Griffiths' critics were French, which decided the issue for thstudent.  Avery told him to replicate Griffiths' work in vitro, which thstudent eventually did, whereupon Avery was convinced and started thresearch program which, in 15 or so years, produced the famous discover(Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty, JEM 1944)--Mark A. Fulk\t\t\tUniversity of RochesteComputer Science Department\tfulk@cs.rochester.ed

Here is a press release from the Natural Resources Defense Council New Data Show About 100 Major U.S. Water Supplies Vulnerable TMilwaukee-Type Disease Outbrea To: National Desk, Environment Write Contact: Erik Olson or Sarah Silver, 202-783-7800, bot          of the Natural Resources Defense Counci   WASHINGTON, April 14  -- Internal EPA data releasetoday by the Natural Resources Defense Council reveals that abou100 large water systems -- serving cities from Boston to SaFrancisco -- do not filter to remove disease-carrying organismleaving those communities potentially vulnerable to a diseasoutbreak similar to the one affecting Milwaukee   The EPA list is attached   "These internal EPA documents reveal that the safety of watesupplies in many American cities is threatened by inadequatpollution controls or filtration," said Erik Olson, a senioattorney with NRDC.  "Water contamination isn\'t just a problem iBangladesh, it\'s also a problem in Bozeman and Boston.   "As of June 29, 1993, about 100 large surface water systems oEPA's list probably will be breaking the law.  The 1986 SafDrinking Water Act requires all surface water systems to eithefilter their water or fully protect the rivers or lakes they usfrom pollution," Olson continued.  Some systems are movintowards eventually implementing filtration systems but arexpected to miss the law's deadline   Olson pointed out that the threat of contamination is alreada reality in other cities.  A 1991 survey of 66 U.S. surfacwater systems by water utility scientists found that 87 percenof raw water samples contained the Milwaukee organiscryptosporidium, and 81 percent contained a similar parasitcalled giardia   Adding to the level of concern, a General Accounting Officstudy released today by House Health and Environment SubcommitteChairman Henry Waxman indicates serious deficiencies in thnation's system for conducting and following through on sanitarsurveys of water systems   "This new information raises a huge warning sign that millionof Americans can no longer simply turn on their taps and bassured that their water is safe to drink.  We must immediatelput into place programs to protect water sources frocontamination and where this is not assured, filtration equipmenmust be installed to protect the public," Olson noted.  "The timhas come for many of the nation's water utilities to stodragging their feet and to aggressively protect their water frocontamination; consumers are prepared to pay the modest costneeded to assure their water is safe to drink.   NRDC is a national non-profit environmental advocacy organization   Systems EPA Indicates Require Filtration and Do Not AdequatelProtect Watershed CONNECTICU Bridgeport            Bridgeport Hydraulic Co MASSACHUSETT Boston                H2O Resource Author (MWRA Medford               MWRA-Medford Water Dep Melrose               MWRA-Melrose Water Dep Hilton                MWRA-Hilton Water Dep Needham               MWRA-Needham Water Divisio Newtoncenter          MWRA-Newton Water Dept Marblehead            MWRA-Marblehead Water Dep Quincy                MWRA-Quincy Water Dep Norwood               MWRA-Norwood Water Dep Framingham            MWRA-Framingham Water Di Cambridge             MWRA-Cambridge Water Dep Canton                MWRA-Canton Water Div-DP Chelsea               MWRA-Chelsea Water Dep Everett               MWRA-Everett Water Dep Lexington             MWRA-201 Bedford (PUO WRKS Lynn                  MWRA-Lynn Water & Sewer C Malden                MWRA-Malden Water Divisio Revere                MWRA-Revere Water Dep Woburn                MWRA-Woburn Water Dep Swampscott            MWRA-Swampscott Water Dep Saugus                MWRA-Saugus Water Dep Somerville            MWRA-Somerville Water Dep Stoneman              MWRA-Stoneman Water Dep Brookline             MWRA-Brookline Water Dep Wakefield             MWRA-Same as Abov Waltham               MWRA-Waltham Water Divisio Watertown             MWRA-Watertown Water Divisio Weston                MWRA-Weston Water Dep Dedham                MWRA-Dedham-Westwood Distric Winchester            MWRA-Winchester Water & Sewe Winthrop              MWRA-Winthrop Water Dep Boston                MWRA-Boston Water & Sewer C S. -*----> What about Kekule's infamous derivation of the idea of benzene ring> from a daydream of snakes in the fire biting their tails?  Is thi> specific enough to count?  Certainly it turns up repeatedly in basi> phil. of sci. texts as an example of the inventive component o> hypothesizing.I think the question is: What is extra-scientific about this? It has been a long time since anyone has proposed restrictions owhere one comes up with ideas in order for them to be considerelegitimate hypotheses.  The point, in short, is this: hypotheses anspeculation in science may come from wild flights of fancy,daydreams, ancient traditions, modern quackery, or anywhere elseRussel

Gordon Banks>a lot to keep from going back to morbid obesity.  I think al>of us cycle.  One's success depends on how large the fluctuation>in the cycle are.  Some people can cycle only 5 pounds.  Unfortunately>I'm not one of themThis certainly describes my situation perfectly. For me there ia constant dynamic between my tendency to eat, which appears tbe totally limitless, and the purely conscious desire to noput on too much weight. When I get too fat, I just diet/exercismore (with varying degrees of success) to take off thextra weight. Usually I cycle within a 15 lb range, busmaller and larger cycles occur as well. I'm always afraithat this method will stop working someday, but usuallI seem to be able to hold the weight gain in checkThis is one reason I have a hard time accepting the notioof some metabolic derangement associated with cycle dietin(that results in long-term weight gain). I have been cycledieting for at least 20 years without seeing such a changeI think a vigorous exercise program can go a long way towarkeeping the cycles smaller and the baseline weight lowBria

-*---> The difference between a Nobel Prize level scientist and a mediocr> scientist does not lie in the quality of their empirical methodology. > It depends on the quality of their THINKING. > It really bothers me that so many graduate students seem to believe tha> they are doing science merely because they are conducting empirica> studies. ..> And I'm especially offended by Russell Turpin's repeated assertion tha> science amounts to nothing more than avoiding mistakes.  Simply avoidin> mistakes doesn't get you anywhere. I think that Lee Lady and I are talking at cross purposesAbove, Lady seems concerned with the contrast between greascience that makes big advances in our knowledge and mediocrscience that makes smaller steps.  In most of this thread, I havbeen concerned with the difference between what is science anwhat is not.Lee Lady is correct when she asserts that the difference betweeEinstein and the average post-doc physicist is the quality otheir thought.  But what is the difference between Einstein and genius who would be a great scientist but whose great thoughtare scientifically screwy?  (Some would give Velikovsky oKorzybski as examples.  If you don't like these, choose youown.)  I say it is the same as the difference between the mediocrphysicist and the mediocre proponent of qi.  Both Einstein anthe mediocre physcists have disciplined their work from thcumulative knowledge of how previous researchers went wrongBoth Velikovsky and the mediocre proponent of qi have failed tdo this. Let me approach this from a second direction.  When one is asketo review a paper for a journal or conference, there are mankinds of criticism that one can make.  One kind of criticism ithat the work is just wrong or misinformed.  Another kind ocriticism is that the work, while technically correct, is eithenot important or not interesting.  The first difference is thone that I have been pointing to.  The second difference is thone that Lee Lady seems to be discussing.> If good empirical research were done and showed that there is some meri> to homeopathic remedies, this would certainly be valuable information> But it would still not mean that homeopathy qualifies as a science.  Thi> is where you and I disagree with Turpin. I have often pointed out that for homeopathy to be consideredscientific, what is needed is a test of its theoretical claimsnot just of some of its proposed remedies.  Similarly, I suspecthat traditional Chinese medicine has many remedies that workwhat it lacks (as one example) is any experiment that tests thpresence of qi> ... In order to have science, one must have a theoretica> structure that makes sense, not a mere collection of empiricall> validated random hypothesesCertainly a "theoretical structure that makes sense" is the goalIn areas where we do not yet have this, I see nothing wrong witforming and testing smaller hypotheses.  Let's face it: we cannoalways wait for an Einstein to come along and make everythinclear for us.  Sometimes those of us who are not Einstein have tplug along and make small amounts of progress as best we can.Russel

>> The difference between a Nobel Prize level scientist and a mediocr>> scientist does not lie in the quality of their empirical methodology. >> It depends on the quality of their THINKING. \t\t\t...................>Lee Lady is correct when she asserts that the difference betwee>Einstein and the average post-doc physicist is the quality o>their thought.  But what is the difference between Einstein and >genius who would be a great scientist but whose great thought>are scientifically screwyThis example is probably wrong.  There is the case of one famouphysicist telling another that he was probably wrong.  As I recalthe quote\tYour ideas are crazy, to be sure.  But they are not craz\tenough to be rightThe typical screwball is only somewhat screwy--Herman Rubin, Dept. of Statistics, Purdue Univ., West Lafayette IN47907-139Phone: (317)494-605hrubin@snap.stat.purdue.edu (Internet, bitnet) {purdue,pur-ee}!snap.stat!hrubin(UUCP
Contents of file 58788
>|> I don\'t think "extra-scientific" is a very useful phrase in a discussio>|> of the boundaries of science, except as a proposed definiens>|> Extra-rationa>|> is a better phrase.  In fact, there are quite a number of well-known case>|> of extra-rational considerations driving science in a useful direction>Yeah, but the problem with holding up the "extra-rational" examples a>exemplars, or as refutations of well founded methodology, is that yo>run smack up against such unuseful directions as Lysenko.  Such "extra>rational" cases are curiosities -- not guides to methodologyAs has been noted before, there is the distinction between _motivationand _method_.  No experimental result should be accepted unless it idescribed in sufficient detail to be replicated, and the replicationdo indeed reproduce the result.  No theoretical argument should baccepted unless it is presented in sufficient detail to be followed, anreasonable, knowlegeable, people agree with the force of the logicBut people try experiments, and pursue arguments, for all sorts of crazreasons.  Irrational motivations are not just curiousities; they are large part of the history of scienceThere are a couple of negative points to make here1) A theory of qi could, conceivably, become accepted without direcverification of the existence of qi.  For example, quarks are an acceptepart of the standard model of physics, with no direct verification.  Whawould be needed would be a theory, based on qi, that predicted medicareality better than the alternatives.  The central theoretical claim coullie forever beyond experiment, as long as there was a sufficient body oexperimental data that the qi theory predicted better than any other(I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for the triumph of qi, thoughI don't think that there is even a coherent theory based on it, much lesa theory that explains anything at all better than modern biology.  And iis hard to imagine a qi theory that would not predict some way of rathedirectly verifying the existence of qi.2) Science has not historically progressed in any sort of rationaexperiment-data-theory sequence.  Most experiments are carried out, aninterpreted, in pre-existing theoretical frameworks.  The theoreticacontroversies of the day determine which experiments get done.  Overallthere is a huge messy affair of personal jealousies, crazy motivationspetty hatreds, and the like that determines which experiments, and whiccomputations, get done.  What keeps it going forward is the criticafunction of science: results don't count unless they can be replicatedThe whole system is a sort of mechanism for generate-and-test.  The generatpart can be totally irrational, as long as the test part works properlyPasteur could believe whatever he liked about chemical activity and crystalsbut even Mitscherlich had to agree that racemic acid crystals were handedthat when you separate them by handedness, you get two chemicals that rotatpolarized light in opposite directions; and the right-rotating version waindistinguishable from tartaric acid.  Pasteur's irrational motivation haled to a replicable, and important, resultThis is where Lysenko, creationists, etc. fail.  They have usually noeven produced coherent theories that predict much of anything.  When theitheories do predict, and are contradicted by experiment, they do noconcede the point and modify their theories; rather they try to suppresthe results (Lysenko) or try to divert attention to other evidence thethink supports their position (creationists)--Mark A. Fulk\t\t\tUniversity of RochesteComputer Science Department\tfulk@cs.rochester.ed

It came "out of nowhere."  The connectioKekule saw between it and his problem is fortunate but not extraordinaryI, for example, often receive/conjure solutions (hypotheses for solutions)to my everyday problems at moments when I appear to myself to be occupiedwith activities quite removed.  Algorithms for that new software feature comwhen I trample the meadow on my occasional runs.  Alternative (better>) waysto instruct and rear my sons arrive while I weed the garden.  I'll swear I amnot thinking about any of it when ideas come.  These ideas are not the stuff of "great" discoveries, of course, but mconnecting them to particular problems is fraught with deliberation anoccasional fits of rationality> Surely it wasn't the *only* daydream [Kekule] had. Contents of file 58792
Avoiding mistakes is certainly highly desirable.  However it is alsowidely acknowledged that perfectionism is inimicable to creativity.And in ordinary life, perfectionism carried beyond a certain point isindicative of a psychological disorder.  In the extreme case, a perfectionist becomes so paralyzed by all the possible mistakes he mightmake that he is unable to even leave the house. In science, we want to discover as much truth about the world as possibleand we also want to have as much certainty as possible about thesediscoveries.  Usually there is some trade-off between these two desiderata--- the search for scope and the search for certainty. If 18th century mathematicians had demanded total rigor from Newton andLeibniz then there would probably be no calculus today, because neitherof the two could explain calculus in a way that really made sense, sincethey lacked the concept of a limit.  And in fact, because of the lack ofa rigorous foundation, they made a number of errors in their use of calculus.It was only a hundred years later that Weistrass was able to give a solidgrounding for the ideas of Newton and Leibniz.  Nonetheless, what Newtonand Leibniz did was undoubtedly science and mathematics gained a greatdeal more from the application of their important ideas than it lostthrough the mistakes they made.     (Dick King) writes>  [ Somebody writes: >>I doubt if Einstein used any formal methodology.  ...>  ...>He also proposed numerous experiments which if performed would distinguish >universe in which special relativity holds from one in which it does not>         ...>Einstein played by the rules, which demand that hypotheses only be put ou>there if there exists a specific experiment that could disprove themThese are not the rules according to many who post to sci.med ansci.psychology.  According to these posters  "If it\'s not supported bcarefully designed controlled studies then it\'s not science.Taken to the extreme, I believe that the attitude that empirical studiesare everything and ideas are nothing results in a complete stultificationof science. For one thing, an insistence on an elaborate and expensive methodologyresults in a sort of scientific trade-unionism, where those outsidethe establishment and lacking institutional or corporate support haveno chance to obtain a hearing.  (I don't in the least believe that thisis the intention of the arbiters of scientific methodology.  Nonetheless,it is one of the results.)   And although institutional science hascertainly produced many wonderful results, I think it is a foolisharrogance for scientists to believe that no one outside the establishment--- and using less than perfect empirical methodology --- will ever comewith anything worthwhile. Furthermore, the big bucks approach to science promotes what I think ione of the most significant errors in science:  choosing to investigatquestions because they can be readily handled by the currentlfashionable methodology (or because one can readily get institutionaor corporate sponsorship for them) instead of directing attention tthose questions which seem to have fundamental significanceFor instance, certain questions cannot be easily investigated witstatistical methods because the relevant factors are not quantitative(One could argue that this is the case for almost all questions in manareas of psychology.  In my opinion, a perusal of many of the paperresulting from the attempt by psychologists to force these questioninto a statistical framework gives the lie to Russell Turpin'assertion that current scientific methods "avoid all known errors."I think that asking the wrong question is probably the most fundamentalerror in science.  (Ignoring potentially valuable ideas is one of theothers.)  And I think that scientific journals are full of alltoo many studies done with impeccable empirical methods but which areworthless because the wrong question was asked in the first place. -In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne
Contents of file 58793
>               ... the other day I played tennis during my lunc>hour.  I'm out of tennis shape so it was very intense exercise.  >got overheated, and dehydrated.  Afterwards, I noticed a tinglin>sensation all over my head then about 2 hours later, I could fee>a migraine start.  (I continued to drink water in the afternoon.>I took cafergot, but it didn't help and the pain started althoug>it wasn't as intense as it usually is and about 9pm that night, th>pain subsided>This isn't the first time that I've had a migraine occur after exercise>I'm wondering if anyone else has had the same experience and I wonde>what triggers the migraine in this situation (heat buildup? dehydration?)>I'm not giving up tennis so is there anything I can do (besides get into>shape and don't play at high noon) to prevent thisHi JanetSounds exactly like mine.  Same circumstance, same onset symptoms,same cafergot uselessness, same duration.  In fact, of all the peoplI know who have migraines, none have been so similar.  There is suca wide variation between people with respect to what causes theiheadaches, that I generally don't bother sharing what I've learneabout mine, but since ours seem to be alike, here are my observationsI don't think it's heat, per se (I've had more in winter than summer)Dehydration could conceivably figure, though.  Try tanking up beforplaying rather than afterBeing in shape doesn't seem to help me much, eitherI've identified four factors that do make a difference (listed indescending order of importance)1) Heavy exercis2) Sleep deprivatio3) Fasting\t\t(e.g., skipped breakfast4) Physical trauma\t(e.g., head bonkHeavy exercise has preceded all of my post-adolescent migraines, but Idon't get migraines after every heavy exercise session.  One or more ofthe other factors *must* be present (usually #2).  Since I discoveredthis, I've been nearly migraine-free -- relapsing only once every twoor three years when I get cocky ("It\'s been so long, maybe I just don\'tget them anymore") and stop being carefulHope this is helpfulJohn

A friend of mine has been diagnosed with Psoriatic Arthritis, as a result otrauma sustained in a car accident several years ago.  The psoriasis is undecontrol but the arthritis part of the illness is notAnsaid (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory) worked pretty well for three years buisn't helping much now.  My friend is now taking Meclomen (another NSAID) buthis isn't helping control the pain at all.  In the past two months my frienhas also started taking Azulfadine along with the NSAID medicines, but theffects of the combined drugs aren't supposed to be realized for several monthsAs a result of the pain, my friend is having problems sleeping.  Staying ione position too long is an ordeal.  Another major contributor to pain is thatendonitis has now developed (left thumb and hand with numbness at the base othe palm; bottom of feet; shoulders and outer thighs).  The tendonitis iquite painful yet my friend's doctor has not recommended any form of treatmento relieve itThe latest twist is that the doctor has dropped the anti-inflammatories and inow recommending Prednisone.  The hope is that the Prednisone will relieve somof the pain from the tendonitisMy friend is a 41 year old male who feels like he's 80 (his words, not mine)If anyone is aware of any new treatments for Psoriatic Arthritis, alternativcourses of action, support groups or literature on it, I would be extremelgrateful if you could e-mail to me. >Is erythromycin effective in treating pneumoniaIt depends on the cause of the pneumonia.  For treating bacteriapneumonia in young otherwise-healthy non-smokers, erythromyciis usually considered the antibiotic of choice, since it coverthe two most-common pathogens: strep pneumoniae and mycoplasmpneumoniae--David Rinrind@enterprise.bih.harvard.ed

   I have a BACK MACHINE and have had one since January.  While I have notfound it to be a panacea for my back pain, I think it has helped somewhat.It MAINLY acts to stretch muscles in the back and prevent spasms associatewith pain.  I am taking less pain medication than I was previously.    The folks at BACK TECHNOLOGIES are VERY reluctant to honor their returnpolicy.  They extended my "warranty" period rather than allow me to returnthe machine when, after the first month or so, I was not thrilled with it.They encouraged me to continue to use it, abeit less vigourously.   Like I said, I can't say it is a cure-all, but it keeps me stretched ouand I am in less pain-**********************************************************************Dale M. Contents of file 58818
|> 2) Science has not historically progressed in any sort of rationa|> experiment-data-theory sequence.  Most experiments are carried out, an|> interpreted, in pre-existing theoretical frameworks.  The theoretica|> controversies of the day determine which experiments get done.  Overall|> there is a huge messy affair of personal jealousies, crazy motivations|> petty hatreds, and the like that determines which experiments, and whic|> computations, get done.  What keeps it going forward is the critica|> function of science: results don't count unless they can be replicated|>|> The whole system is a sort of mechanism for generate-and-test.  The generat|> part can be totally irrational, as long as the test part works properlyI think we agree on much.  However the paragraphs above seem to repeauncritically the standard Kuhn/Lakatos/Feyerabend view of "progress" an"rationality" in science.  Since I\'ve addressed these issues in thinewsgroup in the not too distant past, I won't go into them again nowWhat is wrong with the above observation is that it explicitly gives thimpression (and you may not in fact hold this view) that the common (perhapeven the "correct") approach for a scientist to follow is to sit arounhaving flights of fancy and scheming on the basis of his jealousies anpetty hatreds.  It further at least implicitly advances the position thasciences goes "forward" (and it is not clear what this means given thcontext in which it occurs) by generating in a completely non-rationaand even random way a plethora of hypotheses and theories that are theweeded out via the "critical function" of science.  (Though why this criticafunction should be less subject to the non-rational forces is a mysteryIf experimental design, hypotheses creation, and theory construction arsubject to jealousies and petty hatreds, then this must be equally truof the application of any "critical function" concerning replicationThis is what leads one (ala Feyerabend) to an "anything goes" view.True, the generation part *can* be totally irrational.  But typically it i*not*.  Anecdotes concerning instances where a hypothesis seems to havresulted in some way from a dream or from one's political views simpldo not generalize well to the actual history of science--Gary H. >\tI was kind of half watching Street Stories last nigh>\tand one of the segments was about this doctor i>\tS.F. who provides a service of investigating treatmen>\tfor various diseases. I'm pretty sure his name i>\tDr. Mark Renniger (sp?) or close to that.>\tDid anyone else watch this? I'd like to get hi>\tcorrect name and address/phone number if possible>\tThanks    INTENSIVE JAPANESE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH THIS SUMME    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^The University of Pittsburgh is offering two intensive Japanese languagcourses this summer.  Both courses, Intensive Elementary Japanese andIntensive Intermediate Japanese, are ten week, ten credit courseseach equivalent to one full year of Japanese language study.  They beginJune 7 and end August 13.  The courses meet five days per week, five hoursper day.  There is a flat rate tuition charge of $1600 per course. Fellowships available for science and engineering students.  ContactSteven Brener, Program Manager of the Japanese Science and TechnologManagement Program, at the University of Pittsburgh at the number oaddress below. ALL INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY, THIS IS NOT LIMITED TOUNIVERSITY STUDENTS #######################################################################################   New Program Announcement   #############################################################################################            JAPANESE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAThe Japanese Science and Technology Management Program (JSTMP) is a neprogram jointly developed by the University of Pittsbugh and Carnegie MellonUniversity.  Students and professionals in the engineering and scientificcommunitites are encouraged to apply for classes commencing in June 1993 andJanuary 1994PROGRAM OBJECTIVEThe program intends to promote technology transfer between Japan and theUnited States.  It is also designed to let scientists, engineers, and managerexperience how the Japanese proceed with technological development.  This isfacilitated by extended internships in Japanese research facilities anlaboratories that provide participants with the opportunity to develolong-term professional relationships with their Japanese counterpartsPROGRAM DESIGTo fulfill the objectives of the program, participants will be required todevelop advanced language capability and a deep understanding of Japan anits culture.  Correspondingly, JSTMP consists of three major components1. TRAINING IN THE JAPANESE LANGUAGSeveral Japanese language courses will be offered, including intensive coursedesigned to expedite language preparation for scientists and engineers in relatively short time2. EDUCATION IN JAPANESE BUSINESS AND SOCIAL CULTURA particular enphasis is placed on attaining a deep understanding of thcultural and educational basis of Japanese management approaches inmanufacturing and information technology.  Courses will be available in avariety of departments throughout both universities including AnthropologySociology, History, and Political Science.  Moreover, seminars and colloquiumwill be conducted.  Further, a field trip to Japanese manufacturing orresearch facilities in the United States will be scheduled3. AN INTERNSHIP OR A STUDY MISSION IN JAPAUpon completion of their language and cultural training at PITT and CMU,participants will have the opportunity to go to Japan and observeand participate in the management of technology.  Internships in Japawill generally run for one year; however, shorter ones are possibleFELLOWSHIPS COVERING TUITION FOR LANGUAGE AND CULTURE COURSES, AS WELL ASTIPENDS FOR LIVING EXPENSES ARE AVAILABLE        FOR MORE INFORMATION AND APPLICATION MATERIALS CONTACSTEVEN BRENER\t\t\t\tSUSIE BROWJSTMP\t\t\t\t\tCarnegie Mellon University, GSIUniversity of Pittsburgh\t\tPittsburgh, PA 15213-3894E25 Forbes Quadrangle\t\t\tTelephone: (412) 268-780Pittsburgh, PA 15260\t\t\tFAX:\t   (412) 268-816Telephone: (412) 648-7414\t\FAX:       (412) 648-2199\t\#######################################################################################################################################################Interested individuals, companies and institutions should respond by phone omail. >>>Is there such a thing as MSG (monosodium glutamate) sensitivity>>>I saw in the NY Times Sunday that scientists have testified before>>>an FDA advisory panel that complaints about MSG sensitivity ar>>>superstition. Anybody here have experience to the contrary?>>>>>I'm old enough to remember that the issue has come up at leas>>>a couple of times since the 1960s. Then it was called th>>>"Chinese restaurant syndrome" because Chinese cuisine ha>>>always used it>So far, I've seen about a dozen posts of anecdotal evidence, bu>no facts.  I suspect there is a strong psychological effect at>work here.  Does anyone have results from a scientific stud>using double-blind trials? Check out #27903, just some 20 posts before your own. Maybe you misseit amidst the flurry of responses? Yet again, the use of thinewsgroup is hampered by people not restricting their posts to matterthey have substantial knowledge ofFor cites on MSG, look up almost anything by John W. Olney, toxicologist who has studied the effects of MSG on the brain and odevelopment.  It is undisputed in the literature that MSG is aexcitotoxic food additive, and that its major constituent, glutamatis essentially the premierie neurotransmitter in the mammalian brai(humans included).  Too much in the diet, and the system gets throwoff.  Glutamate and aspartate, also an excitotoxin are necessary ismall amounts, and are freely available in many foods, but the amountadded by industry are far above the amounts that would normally bencountered in a ny single food.  By eating lots of junk foodpackaged soups, and diet soft drinks, it is possible to jack youblood levels so high, that anyone with a sensitivity to thescompounds will suffer numerous *real* physi9logical effects.Read Olney's review paper in Prog. Brain Res, 1988, and check *hissources. They are impecable. There is no dispute                    --Dianne Murray    wcsbeau@ccs.carleton.c
Contents of file 58827
>What is wrong with the above observation is that it explicitly gives th>impression (and you may not in fact hold this view) that the common (perhap>even the "correct") approach for a scientist to follow is to sit aroun>having flights of fancy and scheming on the basis of his jealousies an>petty hatredsFlights of fancy, and other irrational approaches, are common.  The cruciathing is not to sit around just having fantasies; they aren't of any usunless they make you do some experiments.  I've known a lot of scientistwhose fantasies lead them on to creative work; usually they won't admiout loud what the fantasy was, prior to the consumption of a few beers(Simple example: Warren Jelinek noticed an extremely heavy band on a DNelectrophoresis gel of human ALU fragments.  He got very excited, hoping thahe'd seen some essential part of the control mechanism for eukaryotigenes.  This fantasy led him to sequence samples of the band and carry oubinding assays.  The result was a well-conserved, 400 or so bp, sequencthat occurs about 500,000 times in the human genome.  Unfortunately foWarren's fantasy, it turns out to be a transposon that is present iso many copies because it replicates itself and copies itself back intthe genome.  On the other hand, the characteristics of transposons wermuch elucidated; the necessity of a cellular reverse transcriptase warecognized; and the standard method of recognizing human DNA was createdOther species have different sets of transposons.  Fortunately for meWarren and I used to eat dinner at T.G.I. Fridays all the time.>It further at least implicitly advances the position tha>sciences goes "forward" (and it is not clear what this means given th>context in which it occurs) by generating in a completely non-rationa>and even random way a plethora of hypotheses and theories that are the>weeded out via the "critical function" of scienceI'm not sure that it's random.  But there is no known rational mechanisfor generating a rich set of interesting hypotheses.  If you are reallworking in an unknown area, it is unlikely that you will have much sensof what might or might not be true; under those circumstances, the besthing to do is just follow whatever instincts you have.  If they are wrongyou will find out soon enough; but at least, you will find out _something_If you try to do experiments at random, with no prior conceptions at alin mind, you will probably get nowhere>(Though why this critica>function should be less subject to the non-rational forces is a mysteryUnfortunately, the critical function does sometimes become hostage tnon-rational forces.  Then we get varieties of pathological scienceLysenko, Mirsky's opposition to DNA-as-gene, cold fusion, and so forth>If experimental design, hypotheses creation, and theory construction ar>subject to jealousies and petty hatreds, then this must be equally tru>of the application of any "critical function" concerning replication>This is what leads one (ala Feyerabend) to an "anything goes" view.I don't agree that this follows.  In fact, this is _exactly_ the point awhich I disagree with Feyerabend.  It is a most important part of thculture of science that one keeps one's jealousies out of the refereeinprocess.  Failures there are aplenty, but, on the whole, things work outAnother point: there are a couple of senses of the phrase ``experimentadesign''.  I'd say that the less rational part is in experimental _choice_not design.  Alexander Fleming (Proc. Royal Soc., 1922) chose to look fobacteriophage in his own mucus for strange reasons (Phage had previouslbeen found in locust diarrhea; Fleming probably thought runny bottom, runnnose, what the hell, it's worth a try.) but his method of looking for phagwas well-designed to detect anything phage-like; in fact, he found lysozyme>True, the generation part *can* be totally irrational.  But typically it i>*not*.  Anecdotes concerning instances where a hypothesis seems to hav>resulted in some way from a dream or from one's political views simpl>do not generalize well to the actual history of scienceIt is not clear to me what you mean by rational vs. irrational.  Perhapyou can give a few examples of surprising experiments that were tried oufor perfectly rational reasons, or interesting new theories that were firsadvanced from logical grounds.  The main examples I can think of are fromodern high-energy physics which is not typical of science as a whole--Mark A. Fulk\t\t\tUniversity of RochesteComputer Science Department\tfulk@cs.rochester.ed

>=Surprise surprise, different people react differently to different things. On>=slightly off the subject case in point. My brother got stung by a bee. I kno>=he is allergic to bee stings, but that his reaction is severe localize>=swelling, not anaphylactic shock. I could not convince the doctors of that>=however, because that's not written in their little rule book>Of course, bee venom isn't a single chemical.  Could be your brother i>reacting to a different component than the one that causes anaphylactic shoc>in other peopleHmmm.  The last time I got stung by a bee I experienced the same reactiothe first poster's brother did.  We went off to the doctor to see if should worry about the fact that my foot was now about 3 times it's normasize.  (And itched!!!  Ow!)  He basically said I shouldn't this time, buthat bee sting allergy was not something you tended to get aclimatized tobut were something that each time got progressively worse generally and thanext time could be the time I go into anaphylactic shock.  Admittedly thiwas many years ago when I was young.  Since then I just make sure I don'get stung.  I also should carry a bee sting kit with me, but I don't. This isn't scientific or proof, but this would lead me to believe it's not different reaction, just a different degree of reaction.  Allergies worthat way.  People have various reactions.  Sort of like diabetes, sompeople can get by with just monitoring their diet, others have to monitotheir diet and use insulin sometimes while others have to watch their dielike a hawk and use insulin regularly. I think MSG is probably similar...some people have allergic reactions tit.  Some people are allergic to fermented things and can't use sosauce...but the chinese have been using it for centuries... that doesn'necessarily mean that it's safe for everyone. \tJohannturner@reed.ed

|> Flights of fancy, and other irrational approaches, are common.  The crucia|> thing is not to sit around just having fantasies; they aren't of any us|> unless they make you do some experiments.  I've known a lot of scientist|> whose fantasies lead them on to creative work; usually they won't admi|> out loud what the fantasy was, prior to the consumption of a few beers|>|> (Simple example: Warren Jelinek noticed an extremely heavy band on a DN|> electrophoresis gel of human ALU fragments.  He got very excited, hoping tha|> he'd seen some essential part of the control mechanism for eukaryoti|> genes.  This fantasy led him to sequence samples of the band and carry ou|> binding assays.  The result was a well-conserved, 400 or so bp, sequencBut why do you characterize this as a "flight of fancy" or a "fantasy"While I am unfamiliar with the scientific context here, it appears obviouthat his speculation (for lack of a better or more neutral word) waat least in significant part a consequence of his knowledge of and acceptancof current theory coupled with his observations.  It would appear thasomething quite rational was going on as he attempted to fit his observatiointo that theory (or to tailor the theory to cover the observation).  Thidoes not seem like an example of what most would normally call a flight ofancy or a fantasy|>|> It is not clear to me what you mean by rational vs. irrational.  Perhap|> you can give a few examples of surprising experiments that were tried ou|> for perfectly rational reasons, or interesting new theories that were firs|> advanced from logical grounds.  The main examples I can think of are fro|> modern high-energy physics which is not typical of science as a wholeWell, I think someone else in this thread was the first to use the word (also"extra-scientific", etc.).  Nor am I prepared to give a general account orationality.  In terms of examples, there is some danger of beginning to quibblover what a "surprising" experiment is, what counts as "surprising", etcThe same may be said about "logical grounds".  My point is that quite frequentl(perhaps even most frequently) the roots of a new theory can be traced tpreviously existing theories (or even to previously rejected hypotheses osome other theory or domain).  I would offer some rather well known examplesuch as Toricelli\'s Puy de Dome experiment done for the sake of his "sea of airhypothesis.  Was this theory (and the resulting experimental test) "surprising"Well, given the *prior* explanations of the phenomena involved it certainly musbe counted as so.  Was the theory constructed (and the experiment designedout of "perfectly rational grounds"?  Well, there was a pretty successful anwell know theory of fluids.  The analogy to fluids by Toricelli is explicitThe novelty was in thinking of air as a fluid (but this was *quite* a noveltat the time).  Was the theory interesting?  Yes.  Was it "new"?  Well, oncould argue that it was merely the extension of an existing theory to a nedomain, but I think this begs certain questions.  We can debate that if yolike--Gary H. >can anyone give me more information regarding endometriosis?   i hear>it's a very common disease among women and if anyone can provide name>..>--NaomEndometriosis is where cells that would normally be lining the uteris exisoutside the uteris.  Sometimes this causes problems, often it doesn'tThere is generally no need to remove pockets of endometriosis unless they arcausing other problems.  One lady I know had Endometriosis in an ovary. This caused her a _great_ deal of pain.  Another lady I know has an    endometrial cyst in her abdominal wall; she is not having it removedThe American Fertility Society has information on this and they probablymaintain a list of physicians in all parts of the continent that deal witendometriosis. There is no dispute>                    --Dianne Murray    wcsbeau@ccs.carleton.cIn order to excitotoxin effects of MSG, MSG that in blood must go throughblood-brain barrier that I am not sure MSG can go through or not. In normal condition, the concentration of glutamate in the cerebrospinal fluid is about2 uM that is high enough to activate one type of glutamate receptor-the NMDreceptor. But the question is Neuron and glial cell in the brain have a lots of transport to get glutamate into Neuron or glial. So no one know exact concentration of glutamate is around neurons.Glutamate is most important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. It is involved in not only in daily life like the controling of movement, it is alsoinvolved in develpoment, memory and learn (it is involved in Logn-term potentialtion that be thought is the basis of learning).

Contents of file 58853
-*---I agree with everything that Lee Lady wrote in her previous post ithis thread.  In case this puzzles people, I would like to expanon two of her comments> Avoiding mistakes is certainly highly desirable.  However it is also> widely acknowledged that perfectionism is inimicable to creativity.> ... In the extreme case, a perfectionist becomes so paralyzed by al> the possible mistakes he might make that he is unable to even leav> the house. One of the most important (and difficult) aspects of reasoninabout empirical investigation lies in understanding the contextscope, and importance of the various arguments and pieces oevidence that are marshalled for a claim.  Some errors break thback of a piece of research, some leave a hole that needs to bfilled in, and some are trivial in their importance.  It is grave mistake to confuse thesePast snippets from this thread>>> I doubt if Einstein used any formal methodology.  ...>> He also proposed numerous experiments which if performed woul>> distinguish a universe in which special relativity holds fro>> one in which it does not. ..Back to Lee Lady> These are not the rules according to many who post to sci.med an> sci.psychology.  According to these posters  "If it\'s not supported b> carefully designed controlled studies then it\'s not science.These posters are making the mistake that I have previouslcriticized of adhering to a methodological recipe.  A "carefulldesigned and controlled study" is neither always possible noalways important.  (On the other hand, if someone is proposing remedy that supposedly alleviates a chronic medical problem, whave enough knowledge of the errors that have plagued *this* kinof claim to ask for a "carefully designed and controlled studyto alleviate our skepticism.Rules such as "support the hypothesis by a carefully designed ancontrolled study" are too narrow to apply to *all* investigationI think that the requirements for particular reasoning to bconvincing depends greatly on the kinds of mistakes that havoccurred in past reasoning about the same kinds of things.  (Treuse the previous example, we know that conclusions frouncontrolled observations of the treatment of chronic medicaproblems are notoriously problematic.) Russel

>|> genes.  This fantasy led him to sequence samples of the band and carry ou>|> binding assays.  The result was a well-conserved, 400 or so bp, sequenc>But why do you characterize this as a "flight of fancy" or a "fantasy"The fantasy was that he had found something of fundamental importance tone of the hot questions of the day ('77).  He really had very littlreason to believe it, other than raw hope.  By fantasy, I certainly don'mean Velikovskian manias>some other theory or domain).  I would offer some rather well known example>such as Toricelli's Puy de Dome experiment done for the sake of hi>"sea of air" hypothesisI'm not familiar with the history of this experiment, although, arguablyI should be>"surprising">Well, given the *prior* explanations of the phenomena involved it certainl>be counted as so.  Was the theory constructed (and the experiment designed>out of "perfectly rational grounds"?  Well, there was a pretty successful an>well know theory of fluids.  The analogy to fluids by Toricelli is explicit>The novelty was in thinking of air as a fluid (but this was *quite* a novelt>at the time).  Was the theory interesting?  Yes.  Was it "new"?  Well, on>could argue that it was merely the extension of an existing theory to a ne>domain, but I think this begs certain questions.  We can debate that if yo>likeI think that it is enough if his contemporaries found the result surprisingThat's not what I'd quibble about.  What I'd like to know are Toricelli'reasons for doing his experiment; not the post hoc _constructed_ reasonsbut the thoughts in his head as he considered the problem.  It may bimpossible to know much about Toricelli's thoughts; that's too bad iit is so.  One of Root-Bernstein's services to science is that he has gonrooting about in Pasteur's and Fleming's (and other people's) notes, and hadiscovered some surprising clues about their motivations.  Pasteur nevepublicly admitted his plan to create mirror-image life, but the dreams arright there in his notebooks (finally public after many years), ready foanyone to read.  And I and my friends often have the most ridiculoureasons for pursuing results; one of my best came because I was mad aa colleague for a poorly-written claim (I disproved the claim)Of course, Toricelli's case may be an example of a rarety: where thfantasy not only motivates the experiment, but turns out to be righin the endMar--Mark A.     INTENSIVE JAPANESE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH THIS SUMME    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^The University of Pittsburgh is offering two intensive Japanese languagcourses this summer.  Both courses, Intensive Elementary Japanese andIntensive Intermediate Japanese, are ten week, ten credit courseseach equivalent to one full year of Japanese language study.  They beginJune 7 and end August 13.  The courses meet five days per week, five hoursper day.  There is a flat rate tuition charge of $1600 per course. Fellowships available for science and engineering students.  ContactSteven Brener, Program Manager of the Japanese Science and TechnologManagement Program, at the University of Pittsburgh at the number oaddress below. ALL INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY, THIS IS NOT LIMITED TOUNIVERSITY STUDENTS #######################################################################################   New Program Announcement   #############################################################################################            JAPANESE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAThe Japanese Science and Technology Management Program (JSTMP) is a neprogram jointly developed by the University of Pittsbugh and Carnegie MellonUniversity.  Students and professionals in the engineering and scientificcommunitites are encouraged to apply for classes commencing in June 1993 andJanuary 1994PROGRAM OBJECTIVEThe program intends to promote technology transfer between Japan and theUnited States.  It is also designed to let scientists, engineers, and managerexperience how the Japanese proceed with technological development.  This isfacilitated by extended internships in Japanese research facilities anlaboratories that provide participants with the opportunity to develolong-term professional relationships with their Japanese counterpartsPROGRAM DESIGTo fulfill the objectives of the program, participants will be required todevelop advanced language capability and a deep understanding of Japan anits culture.  Correspondingly, JSTMP consists of three major components1. TRAINING IN THE JAPANESE LANGUAGSeveral Japanese language courses will be offered, including intensive coursedesigned to expedite language preparation for scientists and engineers in relatively short time2. EDUCATION IN JAPANESE BUSINESS AND SOCIAL CULTURA particular enphasis is placed on attaining a deep understanding of thcultural and educational basis of Japanese management approaches inmanufacturing and information technology.  Courses will be available in avariety of departments throughout both universities including AnthropologySociology, History, and Political Science.  Moreover, seminars and colloquiumwill be conducted.  Further, a field trip to Japanese manufacturing orresearch facilities in the United States will be scheduled3. AN INTERNSHIP OR A STUDY MISSION IN JAPAUpon completion of their language and cultural training at PITT and CMU,participants will have the opportunity to go to Japan and observeand participate in the management of technology.  Internships in Japawill generally run for one year; however, shorter ones are possibleFELLOWSHIPS COVERING TUITION FOR LANGUAGE AND CULTURE COURSES, AS WELL ASTIPENDS FOR LIVING EXPENSES ARE AVAILABLE        FOR MORE INFORMATION AND APPLICATION MATERIALS CONTACSTEVEN BRENER\t\t\t\tSUSIE BROWJSTMP\t\t\t\t\tCarnegie Mellon University, GSIUniversity of Pittsburgh\t\tPittsburgh, PA 15213-3894E25 Forbes Quadrangle\t\t\tTelephone: (412) 268-780Pittsburgh, PA 15260\t\t\tFAX:\t   (412) 268-816Telephone: (412) 648-7414\t\FAX:       (412) 648-2199\t\#######################################################################################################################################################Interested individuals, companies and institutions should respond by phone omail.  Please do not inquire via e-mailPlease note that this is directed at grads and professionals, however, advanceundergrads will be considered.  Further, funding is resticted to US citizenand permanent residents of the USSteve Brene

He was having about one seizure per week.  She reported thashe did this on Thursday (3/11), he had a seizure on Saturday and thewent 4 weeks without a seizure!!  On Easter he went to Grandma's and atecandy, pop - anything he wanted.  He had a seizure the next day.  Shesees sensitivity to nutrasweet, sugar, colors, caffine and corn.  Witcorn she says, he gets very nervous and aggresive. With my own daughter (age 7) , I think she is also sensitive and stayaway from those foods on her own.  She has never had gum, won't eacandy, prefers an apple to a cookie, doesn't like chocolate and won'even use toothpaste!!!  Her brother, on the other hand, is a junk fooaddict! Hope this helps. [From Kalat, J.W.. (1992):  _Biological Psychology_. Wadsworth Publishing CoBelmont, CA.  Pg. 219.  Reproduced without permission.Digression 6.1:  Miracle Berries and the Modification of Taste ReceptorAlthough the _miracle berry_, a plant native to West Africa is practicalltasteless, it temporarily changes the taste of other substances.  Miraclberries contain a protein, _miraculin_, that modifies sweet receptors isuch a way that they can be stimulated by acids (Bartoshuk, Gentile,Moskowitz, & Meiselman, 1974).  If you ever get a chance to chew a miraclberry (and I do recommend it), for about the next half an hour all acids(which are normally sour) will taste sweet.  They will continue to tastsour as wellMiraculin was, for a time, commercially available in the United States as diet aid.  The idea was that dieters could coat their tongue with a miraculipill and then eat and drink unsweetened, slightly acidic substances.  Sucsubstances would taste sweet without providing many caloriesA colleague and I once spent an evening experimenting with miracle berriesWe drank straight lemon juice, sauerkraut juice, even vinegar.  All tasteextremely sweet.  Somehow we forgot how acidic these substances are.  Weawoke the next day to find our mouths full of ulcers[... continued discussion of a couple other taste-altering substances ...Refs: Bartoshuk, L.M., Gentile, R.L., Moskowitz, H.R., & Meiselman, H.L.  (1974)   Sweet taste induced by miracle fruit (_Synsephalum dulcificum_).   _Physiology & Behavior_.  12(6):449-456------------Anyone ever hear of these things or know where to get them-marandersom@spot.colorado.ed

I posted this to sci.psychology on April 3, and after seeinyour post here on panice disorder thought it would brelevant----My research indicates that two schools of thought existthe literature promoting medication says it's the superiotreatment.  Not surprisingly, literature promoting cognitivtherapy also claims to be superiorWhat are the facts?  Early in my research I didn't have bias towards either medication or cognitive therapy.  was interested in a treatment that worked.  After readinjournals published after 1986, the cognitive therapy camclaims a higher success rate (approx 80%), a lower drop-ourate, and no side effects associated with medicationLars-Goran Ost published an excellent article title"Applied Relaxation: Description of a coping technique ana review of controlled studies."  This is from Behav. Res. Ther.vol. 25, no. 5, pp. 397-409, 1987.  The article provideinstructions on how to perform applied relaxation (AR)Briefly, you start with two 15 minute sessions daily, anprogress in 8-12 weeks to performing 10-15 thirty second sessiondailyI'll snail mail this article to anyone interested (USA only pleaseInternational please pay for postage)Marvonwaadn@kuhub.cc.ukans.ed

Contents of file 58868
russell.sinclair-day@canrem.com (russell sinclair-day) writes> What we are really worried about is not knowing the facts. The doctor> has stated that things will not be good if she is a carrier and avoids> further questions on the subject. We really would like to know so we> can take steps and plan in advance for any eventualities>> Thank-you for your very informative post. Right now I am just trying> to find out everything that I can>>                         RussUnfortunately, Hep B infection can eventuate in chronic hepatitis ansubsequent cirrhosis.  Although not many patients with Hep B go on tchronic hepatitis, it does still occur in a good number (20%?) and isomething to keep in mind.  Hepatitis C (was: non-A, non-B Hep) mucmore frequently leads to chronic hep and cirrhosis.  There is also aautimmune chronic hepatitis that affects mostly younger women whicalso leads to cirrhosis. Of course, cirrhosis is a most unkind disease.  The most dangeroueffects relate to portal hypertension and loss of liver function.Patients develop life-threatening variceal bleeds and hepatic comasamong many other problems, as a result of disturbances in hepaticirculation.  Less ominously, they can exhibit the effects ohyperestrogenemia which often characterize patients with cirrhosis.These effects include telangiactasias (small red skin lesions) and, imen, gynecomastia (breast development).  The only real treatment focirrhosis is liver transplantKeep in mind that cirrhosis is not expected, at least statistically, iyour friend's case.  Nevertheless you might want to bring up thsubject of chronic disease and cirrhosis with the doctor.  Hopefully hor she can then carefully explain these sequelae of Hep B infection tyou, and offer you supportSimon.

I haven'even seen anything anecdotal on it.  Given how common they are eate- do you know any child or adolescent who *doesn't* eat the stuff? I think that if there were a relationship we would know it by nowAlso, there's nothing weird in those cereals.  As far as the braiis concerned (except for a few infantile metabolic disorders such agalactosemia), sugar is sugar, regardless if it is coated on cerealsprinkled onto cereal, or dissolved in soda, coffee or whateverThere was some interest a few years ago in aspartame lowerinseizure thresholds, but I don't believe anything ever came of it-- . Contents of file 58872
>mhollowa@ic.sunysb.edu (Michael Holloway) writes>>Here's your error.  I really do think this shows some confusion on you>>part.  (Drum roll please)  Science isn't so much the gathering of evidenc>>to support an "assertion" (read: hypothesis) as it is the gathering o>>empirical observations IN ORDER TO MAKE AN HYPOTHESIS.  What shoul>>convince you (or not) shouldn't be the final product so much as *HOW* th>>product was made.>>Here's your error. There is no observation or hypothesis that is not tainte>by theory. I have a theory, I make observations, those observations will b>made with my theory in mind.Yes, absolutely, though I'd make the observation in a more general sense oall observations are made by human beings and therefore made with varioubiases.But here your message leaves talk of hypothesis and gets back, once again,to equating the business of science with the end result, the gizmo produced>Science works very well at developing theorie>within paradigms, but is very poor at dealing with paradigm shifts. If I>develop a novel paradigm that explains homeopathy, chinese medicine, or>spontaneous combustion. If the paradigm is useful it will show me the wa>to make observations that "prove" or "disprove" itMy point isn't so much whether or not you have a novel paradigm but *how*you come about developing it>The paradigm of modern medicine is that the body can be reduced to a set o>essentially mechanical operations wherein disease is seen as malfunctions i>the machinery, essentially the old Newtonian model of the world. It seem>likely that theories based upon this paradigm do not give a complete>discription of the universe, medicine, healing etc... Indeed we now>recognize an important psychological component to healing.Perhaps you'd admit that this is an oversimplification on your part (the topiof the philosophy of science is made for them, I'm making them too) but think that it also summarizes popular misconceptions of science and thebusiness of doing science.  Biomedical research doesn't make any basicassumptions that aren't the same as any other discipline of scientifiresearch.  That is, that you make empirical observations, form an hypothesiand test it.  Modern medicine has much more to do with biochemistry than"the old Newtonian model of the world".  And I doubt that many psychologistwould appreciate being put outside this empirical "world view".  Psychologalso has more to do with biochemistry than spoon bending.>It is also important to distinguish reason from science. Science may b>reasonable, but so are many non-scientific methodologies. Aristotle reasone>that frogs came from mud by observing one hop out of a puddle.Oversimplified, of course, but a good example.  This is an empirical observation.  It was then tested, though perhaps not by Aristotle, and eventuallyfound wanting.  In the meantime, some folk willhave continued to believe in the spontaneous generation of animal life. There's nothing at all surprising about this, it's the way the gathering oknowledge works.  There are probably more than a few things in my owndiscipline of molecular biology that will be found to be totally off-baseeven idiotic, to someone in the future.  These future people won't have comto these relevations because they had suddenly gone all Zen-like and hada vision in an LSD trip.  Someone will have thought of something new andtested it.  This is the bit that people who seem to relish misrepresentinscience and research can't seem to wrap their minds around.  Science is acreative process.  What I think of as factual and good research can be totallturned on its head tommorrow by new results and theories. Again, I think it gets down to defining what you mean by "science".  I oftedon't recognize what it is that I do, and am involved in, in the way sciencis portrayed by popular media or writings of people in the humanities.  Theportray science as a collection of immutable facts, pronouncements of TRUTin big gold letters.  That's silly.  Its as though we just go into the labturn over a stone, and come up with a mechanism for transcriptional regulation.  Its much more interesting than that.  It really is a very humaprocess

>>>For cites on MSG, look up almost anything by John W. Olney, >>toxicologist who has studied the effects of MSG on the brain and o>>development.  It is undisputed in the literature that MSG is a>>excitotoxic food additive, and that its major constituent, glutamat>>is essentially the premierie neurotransmitter in the mammalian brai>>(humans included).  Too much in the diet, and the system gets throw>>off.  Glutamate and aspartate, also an excitotoxin are necessary i>>small amounts, and are freely available in many foods, but the amount>>added by industry are far above the amounts that would normally b>>encountered in a ny single food.  By eating lots of junk food>>packaged soups, and diet soft drinks, it is possible to jack you>>blood levels so high, that anyone with a sensitivity to thes>>compounds will suffer numerous *real* physi9logical effects.>>Read Olney's review paper in Prog. Brain Res, 1988, and check *his>>sources. They are impecable. There is no dispute>>>                    --Dianne Murray    wcsbeau@ccs.carleton.c>In order to excitotoxin effects of MSG, MSG that in blood must go through>blood-brain barrier that I am not sure MSG can go through or notElevated levels of Glu and Asp in the blood are able to bypass thBlood-brain barrier through the circumventricular organs (or CVO), iparticular the adeno and neurohypophysis (pituitary gland) areas.  Tharcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus, and the median eminence regionare particularly effected.  CVO areas are not subject to thblood-brain barrier. These areas control the release of gonadotropinwhich controls the release and flux of steroids governing developmentespecially sexual development. Changes in adult rats, which are lessensitive to Glu than humans, have been observed: after ingesting Gluon a chronic basis, cycles of several steroids are disrupted. Bloolevels of somatostatin are significantly reduced, and cyclic releasof steroids becomes flattened                    Hope this helps                    --Dianne Murray: wcsbeau@ccs.carleton.c

There has been a steady exodus from 'synthetic' medicine for over a decade now, and it'll be just a matter of tim before more people on this continent will abandon their drug and white coat worship as well and visit different doctors for different needsGR>     You see Ron, the point isn't whether YOU and your patients arGR>  convinced that whatever it is you do works; it's whether what you do iGR>  MORE effective in similar cases (of whatever it is you think you arGR>  treating) than cupping, bloodletting, and placebo This is very interesting. >>>What is wrong with the above observation is that it explicitly gives th>>impression (and you may not in fact hold this view) that the common (perhap>>even the "correct") approach for a scientist to follow is to sit aroun>>having flights of fancy and scheming on the basis of his jealousies an>>petty hatreds>Flights of fancy, and other irrational approaches, are common.  The crucia>thing is not to sit around just having fantasies; they aren't of any us>unless they make you do some experiments.  I've known a lot of scientist>whose fantasies lead them on to creative work; usually they won't admi>out loud what the fantasy was, prior to the consumption of a few beersThe danger in philosophizing about science is that theory and generalizationcan end up being far removed from the actual day-to-day of the grunt at thbench.  Yes, its great to be involved in a process were I can walk into thlab after a heavy night of dreaming and just do something for the hell of i(as long as my advisor doesn't catch me - which is easy enough to do), butstamping out such behavior seems to be the purpose in life of grant reviewcommittees and the peer review process in general.  In today's world that'swhat determines what science is: what gets funded.  And a damn good thing toFlights of fantasy just don't have much chance of producing anything, atleast not in biomedical research.  The surest way for a graduate student truin their life is to work in a lab where the boss is more concerned withfleshing out his/her fantasies than with having the student work on a projecthat actually has a good chance of producing some results.  MD's seem tobe particularly prone to this aberrant behavior. >(Simple example: Warren Jelinek noticed an extremely heavy band on a DN>electrophoresis gel of human ALU fragments.  He got very excited, hoping tha>he'd seen some essential part of the control mechanism for eukaryoti>genes.  This fantasy led him to sequence samples of the band and carry ou>binding assays.  The result was a well-conserved, 400 or so bp, sequenc>that occurs about 500,000 times in the human genome.  Unfortunately fo>Warren's fantasy, it turns out to be a transposon that is present i>so many copies because it replicates itself and copies itself back int>the genome.  On the other hand, the characteristics of transposons wer>much elucidated; the necessity of a cellular reverse transcriptase wa>recognized; and the standard method of recognizing human DNA was created>Other species have different sets of transposons.  Fortunately for me>Warren and I used to eat dinner at T.G.I. Fridays all the time.I have to agree with Gary Merrill's response to this.  I've read alot of thAlu and middle repetitive sequence work and it's really very interesting,good work with implications for many fields in molecular genetics.  It'sreally an example of how a well reasoned project turned up interestingresults that were unexpectedMik

kathleen richards (kilty@ucrengr) wrote> My nearly-13 year old Pomeranian had a nasty reaction to this vaccination> ...  Suffice it to say, we will no> vaccinate her for Lyme disease again.  She's been camping through some > states and has backpacked with us as well and we are used to watching for tick> and dealing with them and we simply won't take her to really active Lym> disease areas...Not to drag this out anymore, but...Many veterinarians feel that Lyme Disease in dogs is so easy to treat thain an endemic area, they often just give the appropriate antibiotics to dogpresenting with lameness, swollen joints, +/- feverA recent paper (March 1993) has finally established that Lyme disease in dogcan be reproduced in a controlled experimentaly setting.  This has beean ellusive matter for researchers, and is one of the fundamental requirementfor many to acknowledge an agent as being causitive of a particular diseaseUp to now, only the vaccine manufacturer has been able to "prove" thathe disease existsThis paper is noteworthy in two other regards1) None of the animals they infected were treated in any way.  The doghad episodes of lameness during a 6-8 week period which occurred 2-months after exposure.  After this period, none showed any furtheclinical signs up to the 17 month observation period of the study.  Sthese are proven, clinically sick Lyme patients showing spontaneourecovery without the benefit of drug treatment. Of course, observationlonger than 17 months will be necessary to be sure the disease doesn'have the same chronicity that some see in humans2)  The addendum to the paper calls into question the techniques used by thvaccine manufacturer to validate the vaccine.  Of course, they wanthe world to use the model they developed in order to test vaccinefficacyAnyway, maybe we will see some independent, scientifically sound evaluationof this vaccine in the next year or so-Jeff Parke <jeffp@pgavin1.vetmed.wsu.edualso:   jeffp@WSUVM1.bitnet    AOL: JeffParkWashington State University College of Veterinary Medicine class of 199Pullman, WA  99164-701

> Keith is the only person I have ever heard of that keeps the weigh> off without any conscious effort to control eating behavior.  ... mos> of us have to diet a lot to keep from going back to morbid obesityI attribute my success to several factorsVery low fat.  Except when someone else has cooked a meal for meI only eat fruit, vegetables, and whole grain or bran cereals.  estimate I only get about 5 to 10 percent of my calories from fatVery little sugar or saltVery high fiber.  Most Americans get about 10 grams.  25 to 35 arrecommended.  I get between 50 and 150.  Sometimes 200.  (I've hearof people taking fiber pills.  It seems unlikely that pills cacontain enough fiber to make a difference.  It would be about alikely as someone getting fat by popping fat pills.  Tablets arjust too small, unless you snarf down hundreds of them daily.My "clean your plate" conditioning works *for* me.  Eating the las10% takes half my eating time, and gives satiety a chance to catcup, so I don't still feel hungry and go start eating something elseI don't eat when I'm not hungry (unless I'm sure I'll get hungrshortly, and eating won't be practical then)I bike to work, 22 miles a day, year round.  Fast.  I also bike tstores, movies, and everywhere else, as I've never owned a carI estimate this burns about 1000 calories a day.  It also helpbuild and maintain muscle mass, prevent insulin resistance (diabeteruns in my family), and increase my metabolism.  (Even so, mmetabolism is so low that when I'm at rest I'm most comfortablwith a temperature in the 90s (F), and usually wear a sweater iit drops to 80.)  Cycling also motivates me to avoid every excesounce.  (Cyclists routinely pay a premium for cycling products thaweigh slightly less than others.  But it's easier and cheaper to triweight from the rider than from the vehicle.There's no question in my mind that my metabolism is radicalldifferent from that of most people who have never been fat.  Fortunatelyit isn't different in a way that precludes excellent healthObviously, I can't swear that every obese person who does what I'vdone will have the success I did.  But I've never yet heard of one whdid try it and didn't succeed> I think all of us cycle.  One's success depends on how large th> fluctuations in the cycle are.  Some people can cycle only 5 poundsI'm sure everyone's weight cycles, whether or not they've ever been fatI usually eat extremely little salt.  When I do eat something saltymy weight can increase overnight by as much as ten pounds.  It comeoff again over a week or two--Keith Lynch, kfl@access.digex.cof p=2,3:2 s q=1 x "f f=3:2 q:f*f>p!\'q  s q=p#f" w:q p,?$x\\8+1*

Contents of file 58894
Phenylketonuria is a disease in which the body cannot process phenylalanineIt can build up in the blood and cause seizures and neurological damageAn odd side effect is that the urine can be deeply colored, like red winePeople with the condition must avoid Nutrasweet, chocolate, and anythinelse rich in phenylalanineAspartame is accused of having caused various vague neurological symptomsPat Robertson's program _The_700_Club_ was beating the drum againsaspartame rather vigorously for about a year, but that issue seems thave been pushed to the back burner for the last year or so.  Apparentlythe evidence is not very strong, or Pat would still be flailing away
