>>>\tHuman glucose: 70 - 110 mg./dL. (fasting) [2>Are these numbers for whole blood, or plasma\tSerum, actually, but plasma numbers are the same.  Whole bloo\tnumbers for humans tend to be somewhat lower (roughly 5 to 10\tpercent lower).  I find the following range for whole blood i\tFUNDAMENTALS OF CLINICAL CHEMISTRY: N. W. Teitz, editor; W. B\tSaunders, 1987\tHuman glucose (whole blood, fasting levels) --> 60 - 95 mg./dL>Which are the strips calibrated for?  (Obviously they measure whole blood\tIndeed, they do measure whole blood levels, although they are no\tas accurate as a serum test done in a laboratory.  One problem i\tthat cells in the sample continue to metabolize glucose after th\tsample is drawn, reducing the apparent level.  According to Teitz\thowever, results compare "reasonably well" with laboratory results\talthough "values below 80 mg./dL. tend to be lower with strip tests\twhereas values above 240 mg./dL. can be very erratic.>What is the conversion factor between human plasma glucose an>whole blood (pin prick) glucose concentration\tAs stated above, whole blood levels tend to be roughly 5 to 10\tpercent lower than serum levels.  Sample freshness will affec\twhole blood levels, however.  I don't believe there is a well\tdefined "conversion factor," since cell metabolism will affec\tsamples to varying degrees.  The serum/plasma test is much\tpreferred for any except general "ball park" testing-Rich Young (These are not Kodak's opinions.

Contents of file 58898
Nutrasweet is a synthetic sweetener a couple thousand times sweeter thasugar.  Some people are concerned about the chemicals that the  body produceswhen it degrades nutrasweet.  It is thought to form formaldehyde and known tfor methanol in the degredation pathway that the body uses to eliminatesubstances.  The real issue is whether the levels of methanol and formaldehydproduced are high enough to cause significant damage, as both are toxic tliving cells.  All I can say is that I will not consume it. Phenylalanine inothing for you to worry about.  It is an amino acid, and everyone uses smalquantities of it for protein synthesis in the body.  Some people have a diseasknown as phenylketoneurea, and they are missing the enzyme necessary todegrade this compound and eliminate it from the body.  For them, it willaccumulate in the body, and in high levels this is toxic to growing nervcells.  Therefore, it is Only a major problem in young children (until arounage 10 or so) or women who are pregnant and have this disorder.  It used tbe a leading cause of brain damage in infants, but now it can be easilydetected at birth, and then one must simply avoid comsumption of phenylalaninas a child, or when pregnant. -heathe

    (Gary Merrill) writes    (Mark Fulk) writes>|> Flights of fancy, and other irrational approaches, are common.  The crucia>|> thing is not to sit around just having fantasies; they aren't of any us>|> unless they make you do some experiments.  ...>|>>|> (Simple example: Warren Jelinek noticed an extremely heavy band on a DN>|> electrophoresis gel of human ALU fragments.  He got very excited, ....>But why do you characterize this as a "flight of fancy" or a "fantasy">While I am unfamiliar with the scientific context here, it appears obviou>that his speculation (for lack of a better or more neutral word) wa>at least in significant part a consequence of his knowledge of and acceptanc>of current theory coupled with his observations.  It would appear tha>something quite rational was going on as he attempted to fit his observatio>into that theory (or to tailor the theory to cover the observation).  ..Whether a scientific idea comes while one is staring out the window, odreaming, or having a fantasy,  or watching an apple fall (Newton), ositting in a bath (Archimedes) ... it is ultimately the result of a lot ointense scientific thinking done beforehand.  Letting one's mind roafreely and giving rein to one's intuition can be a useful way of cominup with new ideas, but only when one has done a lot of rational analysiof the problem first. Scientific intuition is not something one is born with.  It is somethinthat one learns.  Maybe we don't understand completely how it is learnedbut training in systematic scientific thinking is certainly one of thekey elements in developing it. Informal exploration is also often an important element in finding nescientific ideas.  One thinks, for instance, of Darwin's naturalististudies in the Galapagos islands, which led him to the ideas for thetheory of evolution. This is why I am offended by a definition of science that emphasizeempirical verification and does not recognize thinking and informaexploration as important scientific work.  I agree that mere speculatiodoes not deserve to be called science.  I also think that mere empiricastudies not directed by good scientific thinking are at best a verpoor kind of science.     (Russell Turpin) writes>    ..>I think that Lee Lady and I are talking at cross purposes>  ... Lady seems concerned with the contrast between grea>science that makes big advances in our knowledge and mediocr>science that makes smaller steps.  In most of this thread, I hav>been concerned with the difference between what is science an>what is not.I don't think that science should be defined in a way that some of thactivities that lead to really important science --- namely thinking aninformal exploration --- are not recognized as scientific work. -In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne

This will be the first of monthly postings of the newsletter ofthe Long Island Chapter of the Transplant RecipientsInternational Organization (TRIO).  Unfortunately, I was unableto post it before the date of this month's meeting.  I'mposting it anyway, and posting it world-wide instead ofregional, in the hopes that some of the information may beuseful or illustrative.  Also, I hope it can be used as anexample and inspiration for the posting of other newslettersand data related to organ transplantation and donation. MikTransplant RecipientInternational OrganizatioLong Island ChapteP.O. Box 92Huntington, NY 11743-0922\t\t NEWSLETTE516/421-325                                         APRIL 1993                                         VOLUME IV   No. NEXT MEETINThe next meeting is WEDNESDAY APRIL 14 at 8 pm at the Knightsof Columbus Emerald Manor, 517 Uniondale Avenue in Uniondale. Our guest speaker will be Dr. Lewis Teperman.  Dr. Tepermantrained in Pittsburgh under Dr. Starzl and is now the AssistantDirector of the Liver Transplant Program at New York UniversityMedical Center.  Dr. Teperman will discuss current trends intransplantation and treatment and will answer questions.  He isa long time friend of TRIO, surgeon to many of our members, andalways a gracious and delightful guest.   It is sure to be avery informative, interesting and engaging evening.  Ourhospitality committee,  Bette and Vito Suglia and Jim Spencewill be well prepared, and at last the weather should becooperative. We hope to see a very large gathering to welcomeDr. Teperman.          WEDNESDAY    APRIL 14  K of C   UNIONDALLAST MEETINIt has been noted here before that the Long Island Chapter ofTRIO has extraordinary power in predicting bad weather, beingable to forecast rain, sleet and snow fully a month in advance. No TV weatherman can match us. This time we not only scoredagain, but we were also able to disable the Long IslandRailroad, making travel REALLY difficult.  None the less, manybraved the snow and we had an interesting meeting and goodconversation.  Our scheduled speaker, Mrs. Elizabeth Linnehan,a professional nutritionist, had a family emergency and was notable to attend.  She hope she will be with us in the fall todiscuss diet and medications.  However,  Ms. Jennifer Friedman,an image consultant and sister of a liver transplant recipientwas kind enough to step in on very short notice.  Ms. Friedmangave us a lot of good advice about choosing clothes and makeup,(even a bit for men) to help us look well and healthy and tominimize some of the cosmetic effects of some of the medicineand drugs we take.  We are most grateful to Jennifer and thankher for an entertaining eveningANNUAL MEETINIn addition to welcoming Dr. Teperman, the April meeting isalso the Annual meeting of the Chapter.  This is the officialnotice of the meeting as required by our By-Laws. The mainpurpose of the meeting is to review the past year, solicitmember views and ideas for better ways to meet their needs, andto elect members of the Board of Directors for the coming twoyear term.  The nominating committee has prepared the followingslate for the Board         Anne (Liver Recipient) and Don Treffeise         Robert (Heart Recipient) and Eulene Smit         Vito (Kidney Recipient) and Bette Sugli         Kay Grenzig (Liver Recipient         Jan Schichtel (Kidney Recipient         Larry Juliano (Kidney Recipient         David Bekofsky (Director Public Education LITPThose remaining on the Board for another year are         Robert Carroll (Liver, Kidney & Pancreas Recipient         Jerry (Kidney Recipient) and Jeanne Eichhor         Ron (Kidney Donor) and Marie Heal         Peter Smith (Bone Marrow Recipient         Patricia Ann Yankus (Kidney and Pancreas Recipient         Walter Ruzak (Kidney RecipientThis may seem to be a big Board, but many hands make light workand with our various medical uncertainties, it is good to havebackups for all the jobs on the Board.  Therefore, in additionto the slate being presented for voting, nominations will alsobe accepted from the floor.  There is no set number of Boardmembers and there is plenty of work.In addition,  brief treasurer's and membership reports will begiven and the floor will be open for any new business,suggestions, or comments anyone would like to bring upWe will keep the formal meeting short so that we can spend themajority of the time with Dr. TepermanFUTURE MEETINGRemember the scheduled guests for the rest of the year.      May  12      Dr. Peter Shaprio, Chief of Psychiatr                  Columbia Presbyterian Medical Cente     June  9      Dr. Felix Rappaport, Director of the Stony                  Brook Kidney Transplant Program.Plan on being with us the second Wednesday of each monthNOTDAThe week of April 18-24 is National Organ and Tissue DonorAwareness Week. NOTDAW. While we are planning news releases,speaking engagements and meetings with Supervisors Gullata andGaffney, we have decided not to have our softball game  because of two year's experience with miserable weather.We all can help spread the word on donor awareness, however. Wehave found it effective to ask your pastor, or rabbi to publisha letter or announcement in the parish bulletin, allow you toaddress the congregation, or include mention of the gift oflife in his sermon.  Attached to this Newsletter is a sampleletter and fact sheet you can use.   Thank youDR. STARZL TO BE HONOREDThe Long Island Chapter of the American Liver Foundation willhold its annual Auction and Dinner Dance on May 7th at theFountainbleu  on Jericho Turnpike in Jericho.  Dr. ThomasStarzl will be the honored guest.  Tickets are $50 person andare going fast.  If you'd like to meet Dr. Starzl,  call AnneTreffeisen at (516) 421-3258 for detailsMEMBERSHIP NEWSCongratulations to Al Reese.  Al received his heart transplantin Pittsburgh after waiting 3 1/2 years.  He is home and doingwell after only 12 days in hospitalArthur Michaels, liver recipient, is planning to run the BostonMarathon in April. What fantastic proof that transplantationworks!  We hope the national press notices.    Bob McCormack, after a persistent bout with infection, had histransplanted kidney removed.  He is home now, back on dialysisand feeling better. Nicole Healy, kidney recipient and daughter of Ron and Marie,spent the past several weeks in hospital in Miami with problemsencountered on vacation.  Marie has been with her in Florida. They are back in New York where Nicole's treatment willcontinue.  We wish Nicole a speedy recovery.Kay Grenzig, liver recipient, is mending now after a bad fallthat resulted in a broken arm and a broken leg. Kay is acandidate for the Board so we need her well soonAnd best wishes to all coming out of the flu. Contents of file 58906
>Nutrasweet is a synthetic sweetener a couple thousand times sweeter tha>sugar.  Some people are concerned about the chemicals that the  body produces>when it degrades nutrasweet.  It is thought to form formaldehyde and known t>for methanol in the degredation pathway that the body uses to eliminate>substances.  The real issue is whether the levels of methanol and formaldehyd>produced are high enough to cause significant damage, as both are toxic t>living cells.  All I can say is that I will not consume it. Aspartame is the methyl ester of a dipeptide, so a product of ithydrolysis is going to be methanol, which can then be oxidized tformaldehyde.  The amounts of methanol formed from the ingestion oaspartame-containing foods are completely in the metabolic noisesince you're forming equally minute amounts of methanol from othecomponents of food all the time.  In studies involving administratioof high doses of the additive, blood methanol levels were undetectableMethanol is a poison only in quantities seen in human poisoningssay 5ml and above.  This is a consequence of its oxidation to formaldehydand formic acid, two quite reactive compounds which at high enough levelcan damage tissues like the retina and kidney, because at such high dosethe body's detoxification system is overwhelmed.  Interestingly, ontreatment for early methanol poisoning is to get the person drunk oethyl alcohol--vodka or an equivalent.  That's because ethanol imetabolized preferentially over methanol by the enzymes in the liverIf the methanol stays as methanol and isn't metabolized to formaldehydeit is actually relatively non-toxic--Steve Dyedyer@ursa-major.spdcc.com aka {ima,harvard,rayssd,linus,m2c}!spdcc!dye

>Does anyone know of any method to reduce this frequency? My younger brother>each tried a skin transplant (thigh to nose lining), but their nosebleed>soon returned. These have been popular, especially in Europeto treat "capillary fragility", and seemingly in even more extreme cases-a few months ago, a friend was visiting from Italy, and he said that he'had hemorrhoids, but his pharmacist friend sold him some pills.  IncredulouslyI asked to look at them, and sure enough these contained rutin as the activingredient.  I probably destroyed the placebo effect from my skepticasputtering.  I have no idea how he's doing hemorrhoid-wise these daysThe studies which attempted to look at the effect of these compounds ihuman disease and nutrition were never very well controlled, so threports of positive results with them is mostly anecdotalThis stuff is pretty much non-toxic, and probably inexpensive, so there'little risk of trying it, but I wouldn't expect much of a result--Steve Dyedyer@ursa-major.spdcc.com aka {ima,harvard,rayssd,linus,m2c}!spdcc!dye

Contents of file 58910
>-*--->I agree with everything that Lee Lady wrote in her previous post i>this thread. Gee!  Maybe I've misjudged you, Russell.  Anyone who agrees with somethingI say can't be all bad.  ;-Seriously, I'm not sure whether I misjudged you or not, in one respect. I still have a major problem, though, with your insistence that scienceis mainly about avoiding mistakes.  And I still disagree with yourcontention that nobody who doesn\'t use methods deemed "scientific"can possibly know what's true and what's not. >  [Deleted material which I agree with.] >Back to Lee Lady>> These are not the rules according to many who post to sci.med an>> sci.psychology.  According to these posters  "If it\'s not supported b>> carefully designed controlled studies then it\'s not science.>These posters are making the mistake that I have previousl>criticized of adhering to a methodological recipe.  A "carefully ..>     .... >Rules such as "support the hypothesis by a carefully designed an>controlled study" are too narrow to apply to *all* investigation>I think that the requirements for particular reasoning to b>convincing depends greatly on the kinds of mistakes that hav>occurred in past reasoning about the same kinds of things.  (T>reuse the previous example, we know that conclusions fro>uncontrolled observations of the treatment of chronic medica>problems are notoriously problematic.) Okay, so let's see if we agree on this: FIRST of all, there are degreesof certainty.  It might be appropriate, for instance, to demand carefullycontrolled trials before we accept as absolute scientific truth (to theextent that there is any such thing) the effectiveness of a certaintreatment. On the other hand, highly favorable clinical experience, evenif uncontrolled, can be adequate to justify a *preliminary* judgement thaa treatment is useful.  This is often the best evidence we can hope fofrom investigators who do not have institutional or corporate supportIn this case, it makes sense to tentatively treat claims as crediblbut to reserve final judgement until establishment scientists who arqualified and have the necessary resources can do more careful testingSECONDLY, it makes sense to be more tolerant in our standards ofevidence for a pronounced effect than for one that is marginal. I come to this dispute about what science is  not only as mathematician but as a veteran of many arguments in sci.psychology (anoccasionally in sci.med) about NLP (Neurolinguistic Programming).  Mucof the work done to date by NLPers can be better categorized ainformal exploration than as careful scientific research.  For yearnow I have been trying to get scientific and clinical psychologists tjust take a look at it, to read a few of the books and watch some othe videotapes (courtesy of your local university library).  Not fothe purpose of making a definitive judgement, but simply to look at thNLP methodology (especially the approach to eliciting information frosubjects) and look for ideas and hypotheses which might be oscientific interest.  And most especially to be aware of th*questions* NLP suggests which might be worthy of scientifiinvestigationOver and over again the response I get in sci.pychology is  "If thihasn't been thoroughly validated by the accepted form of empiricaresearch then it can\'t be of any interest to us." To me, the ultimate reducio ad absurdum of the extreme "There\'ve got tbe controlled studies" position is an NLP technique called the FasPhobia/Trauma CureSimple phobias (as opposed to agoraphobia) may not be the world's mostimportant psychological disorder, but the nice thing about them is thatit doesn't take a sophisticated instrument to diagnose them or tellwhen someone is cured of one.  The NLP phobia cure is a simplevisualization which requires less than 15 minutes.  (NLPers claim thait can also be used to neutralize a traumatic memory, and hence iuseful in treating Post-traumatic Stress Syndrome.)  It is essentialla variation on the classic desensitization process used by behavioratherapists.  A subject only needs to be taken through the technique onc(or, in the case of PTSD, once for each traumatic incident).  Thprocess doesn't need to be repeated and the subject doesn't need tpractice it over again at homeNow to me, it seems pretty easy to test the effectiveness of this cure.(Especially if, as NLPers claim, the success rate is extremely high.) Take someone with a fear of heights (as I used to have).  Take them upto a balcony on the 20th floor and observe their response.  Spend 15minutes to have them do the simple visualization.  Send them back up tothe balcony and see if things have changed.  Check back with them in afew weeks to see if the cure seems to be lasting.  (More long termfollow-up is certainly desirable, but from a scientific point of vieweven a cure that lasts several weeks has significance.  In any case,there are many known cases where the cure has lasted years.  To the bestof my knowledge, there is no known case where the cure has been reversedafter holding for a few weeks.)  (My own cure, incidentally, was donwith a slightly different NLP technique, before I learned of the FastPhobia/Trauma Cure.  Ten years later now, I enjoy living on the 17tfloor of my building and having a large balcony.) The folks over in sci.psychology have a hundred and one excuses not tmake this simple test.  They claim that only an elaborate outcome studwill be satisfactory --- a study of the sort that NLP practitioners,many of whom make a barely marginal living from their practice, can illafford to do.  (Most of them are also just plain not interested, becausethe whole idea seems frivolous.  And since they're not part of thscientific establishment, they have no tangible rewards to gainfrom scientific acceptance.)The Fast Phobia/Trauma Cure is over ten years old now and the clinicalpsychology establishment is still saying "We don\'t have any way ofknowing that it\'s effective." These academics themselves have the resources to do a study as elaborateas anyone could want, of course, but they say  "Why should I prove yourtheory?"  and  "The burden of proof is on the one making the claim." One academic in sci.psychology said that it would be completelyunscientific for him to test the phobia cure since it hasn'tbeen described in a scientific journal.  (It's described in a number ofbooks and I've posted articles in sci.psychology describing it in as muchdetail as I'm capable of.) Actually, at least one fairly careful academic study has been done (withfavorable results), but it's apparently not acceptable because it's doctoral dissertation and not published in a refereed journalTo me, this sort of attitude does not advance science but hinders it. This is the kind of thing I have in mind when I talk about "doctrinnaire"attitudes about science. Now maybe I have been unfair in imputing such attitudes to you, Russell. If so, I apologize.-In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne

Contents of file 58913
This reminds me of the last Graham Kerr cooking show I saw.  Today hsmoked meat on the stovetop in a big pot!  He used a strange techniquI'd never seen beforeHe took a big pot with lid, and placed a tray in it made from aluminum foilThe tray was about the size and shape of a typical coffee-table ash traymade by crumpling a sheet of foil around the edgesIn the tray, he placed a couple spoonfuls of brown sugar, a similaquantity of brown rice (he said any rice will do), the contents of twteabags of Earl Grey tea, and a few clovesOn top of this was placed an ordinary aluminum basket-type steamer, wittwo chicken breasts in it.  The lid was put on, and the whole assemblwent on the stovetop at high heat for 10 or 12 minutesLater, he removed what looked like smoked chicken breasts.  What surpriseand concerns me are1)  No wood chips.  Where does the smoke flavor come from2)  About 5 or 10 years ago, I remember hearing that carmel colo    (obtained by caramelizing sugar -- a common coloring and flavorin    agent) had been found to be carcinogenic.  I believe they injecte    it under the skin of rats, or something.  If the results were conclusive    caramel color would not be legal in the U.S., yet it is still bein    used.  Was the initial research result found to be incorrect, or what3)  About 5 or 10 years ago, I remember Earl Grey tea being implicate    as carcinogenic, because it contains oil of bergamot (an extrac    from the skin of a type of citrus fruit).  Does anyone know whateve    happened with that story?  If it were carcinogenic, Earl Grey te    could not have it as an additive, yet it apparently continues to d    soWRT natural wood smoke (I've smoking a duck right now, as it happens)I've noticed that a heavily-smoked food item will have an unpleasant tangtaste when eaten directly out of the smoker if the smoke has only recentlstopped flowing.  I find the best taste to be had by using dry wood chipsgetting lots of smoke right up at the beginning of the cooking processthen slowly barbequing for hours and hours without adding additional wood chipsMy theory is that the unpleasant tangy molecules are low-molecular weighstuff, like terpenes, and that the smoky flavor molecules are some sorof larger molecule more similar to tar.  The long barbeque time aftethe initial intensive smoke drives off the low-molecular weight stuffjust leaving the flavor behind.  Does anyone know if my theory is correctI also remember hearing that the combustion products of fat drippinon the charcoal and burning are carcinogenic.  For that reason, and becausit covers the product with soot and some unpleasant tanginess, I only grilnon-drippy meats like prawns directly over hot coals.  I do stuff like thiduck by indirect heat.  I have a long rectangular Weber, and I put the coalat one end and the meat at the other end.  The fat drops directly on thfloor below the meat, and next time I use the barbeque I make the firin that end to burn off the fat and help ignite the coalsAnd yet another reason I've heard not to smoke or barbeque meat is thasmoked cured meat, like pork sausage and bacon, containnitrosamines, which are carcinogenic.  I'm pretty sure this claim actuallhas some standing, don't know about the othersAn amusing incident I recall was the Duncan Hines scandal, when it wadiscovered that the people who make Duncan Hines cake mix were puttina lot of ethylene dibromide (EDB) into the cake mix to suppress weevilsThis is a fumigant which is known to be carcinogenicThe guy who represented the company in the press conference defendehimself by saying that the risk from eating Duncan Hines products every dafor a year would be equal to the cancer risk from eating two charcoalbroiled steaks.  What a great analogy!  When I first heard that, mimmediate reaction was we should make that a standard unit!  One charcoabroiled steak would be equivalent to 0.5 Duncans

Essential tremor is a progressive hereditary tremor that gets worswhen the patient tries to use the effected member.  All limbs, vocacords, and head can be involved.  Inderal is a beta-blocker anis usually effective in diminishing the tremor.  Alcohol and mysolinare also effective, but alcohol is too toxic to use as a treatment-----------------------------------------------------------------------------Gordon Banks  N3JXP      | "Skepticism is the chastity of the intellect, angeb@cadre.dsl.pitt.edu   |  it is shameful to surrender it too soon."---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Some people have a diseas>known as phenylketoneurea, and they are missing the enzyme necessary to>degrade this compound and eliminate it from the body.  For them, it will>accumulate in the body, and in high levels this is toxic to growing nerv>cells.  Therefore, it is Only a major problem in young children (until aroun>age 10 or so) or women who are pregnant and have this disorder. >>One problem is very few scientists are interested in alternative medicine>So Gordon, why do you think this is so>--Probably because most of them come packaged with some absurd theorbehind them.  E.G. homoeopathy: like cures like.  The more you dilutthings, the more powerful they get, even if you dilute them so mucthere is no ingredient but water left.  Chiropractic: all illnesstems from compressions of nerves by misaligned vertebrae.  Sucsystems are so patently absurd, that any good they do is accidentaand not related to the theory.  The only exception is probably herbalismbecause scientists recognize the potent drugs that derive from plantand are always interested in seeing if they can find new plantthat have active and useful substances.  But that isn't whatis meant by alternative medicine, usually.  If you get into the Qiaccupuntunce charts, etc, you are now back to silly theories thaprobably have nothing to do with why accupuncture works in some casesPerhaps another reason they are reluctant is the Rhine experienceRhine was a scientist who wanted to investigate the paranormaand his lab was filled with so much chacanery and fakery thatpeople don't want to be associated with that sort of thing. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------Gordon Banks  N3JXP      | "Skepticism is the chastity of the intellect, angeb@cadre.dsl.pitt.edu   |  it is shameful to surrender it too soon."---------------------------------------------------------------------------

The purpose of misc.health.diabetes is to provide a forum for th>discussion of issues pertaining to diabetes management, i.e.: diet>activities, medicine schedules, blood glucose control, exercise>medical breakthroughs, etc.  This group addresses the issues o>management of both Type I (insulin dependent) and Type II (non-insuli>dependent) diabetes. Postings to misc.heath.diabetes are intended to be for discussio>purposes only, and are in no way to be construed as medical advice>Diabetes is a serious medical condition requiring direct supervisio>by a primary health care physician. >-----(end of charter)----

:Does anybody know of any information regarding the implementaion of tota: quality management, quality control, quality assurance in the delivery o: health care service.  I would appreciate any information.  If there is enoug:interest, I will post the responsesThis is in fact a hot topic in medicine these days, and much of thmedical literature is devoted to this.  The most heavily funded studiethese days are for outcome research, and physicians (and others!) arconstantly questionning whether what we do it truly effective in any givesituation.  QA activities are a routine part of every hospital'administrative function and are required by accreditation agencies.  Therare even entire publications devoted to QA issues--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=  Kenneth Gilbert              __|__        University of Pittsburgh   =  General Internal Medicine      |      "...dammit, not a programmer!" =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

From THE TUFTS UNIVERSITY GUIDE TO TOTAL NUTRITION: Stanley Gershoff,   Ph.D., Dean of Tufts University School of Nutrition; HarperPerennial, 199   (ISBN #0-06-272007-4)\t"The greatest hazard of barbecuing is that the cook will not us\t enough caution and get burned.  Some people suggest that th\t barbecuing itself is dangerous, because the smoke, which is\t absorbed by the meat, contains benzopyrene, which, in its pure form\t has been known to cause cancer in laboratory animals.  However\t in order to experience the same results, people would have t\t consume unrealistically large quantities of barbecued meat at \t time.-Rich Young (These are not Kodak's opinions.

>Nutrasweet is a synthetic sweetener a couple thousand times sweeter tha>sugar.  Some people are concerned about the chemicals that the  body produces>when it degrades nutrasweet.  It is thought to form formaldehyde and known t>for methanol in the degredation pathway that the body uses to eliminate>substances.  The real issue is whether the levels of methanol and formaldehyd>produced are high enough to cause significant damage, as both are toxic t>living cells.  All I can say is that I will not consume it. [...   In the September 1992 issue of THE TUFTS UNIVERSITY DIET AND NUTRITIO   LETTER, there is a three page article about artificial sweeteners.  Wha   follows are those excerpts which deal specifically with Nutrasweet   [Reproduced without permission\t   The controversy [over aspartame] began six years ago in England\twhere a group of researchers found that aspartame, marketed unde\tthe tradename Nutrasweet, appears to stimulate appetite and\tpresumably, the eating of more calories in the long run than i\ta person simply consumed sugar.  When researchers asked a grou\tof 95 people to drink plain water, aspartame-sweetened water, an\tsugared water, they said that overall they felt hungriest afte\tdrinking the artificially sweetened beverage\t   The study received widespread media attention and stirred \tgood deal of concern among the artificial-sweetener-using public\tHowever, its results were questionable at best, since the researcher\tdid not go on to measure whether the increase in appetite di\tactually translate into an increase in eating.  The two do no\tnecessarily go hand in hand\t   In the years that followed, more than a dozen studies examinin\tthe effect of aspartame on appetite -- and eating -- were conducted\tAnd after reviewing every one of them, the director of th\tLaboratory of the Study of Human Ingestive Behavior at Johns Hopkin\tUniversity, Barbara Rolls, Ph.D., concluded that consuming aspartame\tsweetened foods and drinks is not associated with any increase i\tthe amount of food eaten afterward\t   One artificial sweetener that is not typically accused of causin\tcancer is aspartame.  But it most certainly has been blamed for \thost of other ills.  Since its introduction in 1981, the governmen\thas received thousands of complaints accusing it of causin\teverything from headaches to nausea to mood swings to anxiety\tStill, years of careful scientific study conducted both before an\tafter the sweetener's entering the market have failed to confir\tthat it can bring about adverse health effects.  That's why th\tCenters for Disease Control (the government agency charged wit\tmonitoring public health), the American Medical Association'\tCouncil on Scientific Affairs, and the Food and Drug Administratio\thave given aspartame, one of the most studied food additives, \tclean bill of health\t   Granted, the FDA has set forth an "acceptable daily intake" o\t50 milligrams of aspartame per kilogram of body weight.  To excee\tthe limit, however, a 120-pound (55 kg.) woman would have to tak\tin 2,750 milligrams of aspartame -- the amount in 15 cans o\taspartame-sweetened soda pop, 14 cups of gelatin, 22 cups of yogurt\tor 55 six-ounce servings of aspartame-containing hot cocoa,..\tA 175-pound (80 kg.) man would have to consume some 4,000 milligram\tof the sweetener -- the amount in 22 cans of soda pop or 32 cup\tof yogurt -- to go over the limit.  [chart with aspartame conten\tof selected foods omitted\t   Only one small group of people must be certain to stay awa\tfrom aspartame: those born with a rare metabolic disorder calle\tphenylketonuria, or PKU.  The estimated one person in every 12,00\tto 15,000 who has it is unable to properly metabolize an essentia\tamino acid in aspartame called phenylalanine.  Once a chil\tconsumes it, it builds up in the body and can ultimately caus\tsuch severe problems as mental retardation.  To help people wit\tPKU avoid the substance, labels on cans of soda pop and othe\taspartame-sweetened foods must carry the warning "Phenylketonurics\tContains Phenylalanine.-Rich Young (These are not Kodak's opinions.

Contents of file 58943
KS> From: keith@actrix.gen.nz (Keith StewartKS>My wife has become interested through an acquaintance in Post-Polio SyndromKS>This apparently is not recognised in New Zealand and different symptons ( eKS>chest complaints) are treated separately. Does anone have any informatioI\'m not sure that this condition is "recognised" anywhere (in thsense of a disease with diagnostic criteria, clear boundariebetween it and other diseases, unique pathologic or physiologifeatures, etc), but here goes with what many neurologists agree onPost-polio syndrome patients have evidence of motor neuron diseasby clinical examination, EMG, and muscle biopsy.  The abnormalitieare mostly chronic (due to old polio) but there is evidence oongoing deterioration.  Clinically, the patients complain odeclining strength and endurance with everyday motor tasksMusculoskeletal pain is a nearly universal feature that doubtlescontributes to the impaired performance.  The examination showmuscle weakness and atrophy.  The EMG shows evidence of oldenervation with reinnervation (giant and long-duration motor uniaction potentials) *and* evidence of active denervatio(fibrillation potentials).  The biopsy also shows old denervatiowith reinnervation (fiber-type grouping) *and* evidence of activdenervation (small, angulated fibers with dense oxidative enzymstaining) - but curiously, little or no group atrophyPost-polio patients do not have ALS.  In ALS, there is clinicallevident deterioration from one month to the next.  In post-poliothe patients are remarkably stable in objective findings from onyear to the next.  Of course, there are patients who had polibefore who develop genuine ALS, but ALS is no more common amonpolio survivors than among people who never had polioThe cause of post-polio syndrome is unknown.  There is littlevidence that post-polio patients have active polio virus odestructive immunologic response to virus antigenThere is no solid evidence that patients with post-polio havanything different happening to the motor unit (anterior horn cellsmotor axons, neuromuscular junctions, and muscle fibers) thapatients with old polio who are not complaining of deteriorationBoth groups can have the same EMG and biopsy findings.  The reasofor these "acute" changes in a "chronic" disease (old polio) iunknown.  Possibly spinal motor neurons (that have reinnervated hugnumbers of muscle fibers) start shedding the load after severayearsThere are a couple of clinical features that distinguish post-polisyndrome patients from patients with old polio who dendeterioration.  The PPS patients are more likely to have had severpolio.  The PPS patients are *much* more likely to complain of painThey also tend to score higher on depression scales oneuropsychologic testsMy take on this (I'm sure some will disagree):  after recovery frosevere polio there can be abnormal loading on muscles, tendonsligaments, bones, and joints, that leads to inflammatory and/odegenerative conditions affecting these structures.  The increasinpain, superimposed on the chronic (but unchanging) weakness, leadto progressive impairment of motor performance and ADL.  I aperhaps biased by personal experience of having never seen a PPpatient who was not limited in some way by pain.  I do not believthat PPS patients have more rapid deterioration of motor units thanon-PPS patients (i.e., those with old polio of similar severity buwithout PPS complaints)-- . SLMR 2.1 . E-mail: jim.zisfein@factory.com (Jim Zisfein                                           
Contents of file 58944
DN> From: nyeda@cnsvax.uwec.edu (David NyeDN> Briefly, this is a condition in which patients who have significanDN> residual weakness from childhood polio notice progression of thDN> weakness as they get older.  One theory is that the remaining motoDN> neurons have to work harder and so die soonerIf this theory were true, the muscle biopsy would show group atroph(evidence of acute loss of enlarged motor units); it doesn'tInstead, the biopsy shows scattered, angulated, atrophic fibersThis is more consistent with load-shedding by chronically overworkemotor neurons - the neurons survive, at the expense of increasingldenervated muscle-- . Subject: Re: Eugenic(Gordon Banks) writes;Probably within 50 years, a new type of eugenics will be possible.;Maybe even sooner.  We are now mapping the human genome.  We will;then start to work on manipulation of that genome.  Using geneti;engineering, we will be able to insert whatever genes we want;No breeding, no "hybrids", etc.  The ethical question is, shoul;weTwo past problems with eugenics have been1) reducing the gene pool and2) defining the status of the eugenizedInserting genes would not seem to reduce the gene pool unless the insertegenes later became transmissible to progeny. Then they may be able tcrowd out "garbage genes." This may in the future become possible. Even iit does, awareness of the need to maintain the gene pool would hopefullmean provisions will be made for saving genes that may come in handlater. Evidently the genes for sickle cell disease in equatorial Africand for diabetes in the Hopi *promoted* survival in some conditions. Wdon't really know what the future may hold for our environment. Threduced wilderness- and disease-survival capacity of our relatively inbredomesticated animals comes to mind. Vulcanism, nuclear winter, ice agemeteor impact, new microbiological threats, famine, global warming, etc.etc., are all conceivable. Therefore, having as many genes as possiblavailable is a good strategy for species survival.Of course, the status of genetically altered individuals would start ouas no different than anyone else's. But if we could mak"philosopher-kings" with great bodies and long lives, would we (or theywant to give them elevated status? We could. The Romans did it with theikings *without* the benefits of such eugenics. The race eventuallrealized and dealt with the problems which that caused, but for a whileit was a problem. Orwell introduced us to the notion of what might happeto persons genetically altered for more menial tasks. But there is nothinnew under the sun. We treated slaves the same way for millennia befor"1984."  I see no inherent problem with gene therapy which avoids at least these problems. Humans have always had trouble having the virtue and wisdom tuse any power that falls into their hands to good ends all the time. Thahasn't stopped the race as a whole yet. Many are the civilizations whichave died from inability to adapt to environmental change. However, alsmany are the civilizations which have died from the abuse of their owpower. The ones which survived have hopefully learned a lesson from thfates of others, and have survived by making better choices when theiturns cameNot that I don't think that this gene altering power couldn't wipe us ofthe face of the earth or cause endless suffering. Nuclear power or globawarming or whatever could and may still do that, too.The real issue is an issue of wisdom and virtue. I personally don't thinman has enough wisdom and virtue to pull this next challenge off anbetter than he did the for last few. We, as eugenists, may make it, an wmay not. If we don\'t, I hope there are reservoirs of "garbage" people ouin some backwater with otherwise long discarded "garbage" genes which wilpull us through.I believe that the real problem is and will probably always be the sameMan needs to accept input from the great spirit of God to overcome hilacks in the area of knowing how to use the power he has. Some men haveand I believe all men may, listen to and obey the still small voice of Goin their hearts. This is the way to begin to recieve the wisdom and virtuneeded to escape the problems consequent to poor choices. Peoples havdied out for many reasons. The societies which failed to accept enouginput from God to safely use the power they had developed have destroyethemselves, and often others in the process. It is self-evident that thones which survive today have either accepted enough input from the Spirito use their powers wisely enough to avoid or survive their own mistakethus far, or else haven't had enough power for long enough.In summary, I would say that the question of whether to use this netechnology is really an ancient one. And the answer, in some ways hard, isome ways easy, is the same ancient answer. It isn't the power, it is thSpiritSorry for the long post. Got carried awayBob (ruegg@med.unc.edu

    (Russell Turpin) writes>            ...>*not* imply that all their treatments are ineffective.  It *does>imply that those who rely on faulty methodology and reasoning ar>incapable of discovering *which* treatments are effective an>which are not.To start with, no methodology or form of reasoning is infallible.  Sthere's a question of how much certainty we are willing to pay for in given context.  Insistence on too much rigor bogs science down completeland makes progress impossible.  (Expenditure of sufficiently large sumof money and amounts of time can sometimes overcome this.)  On the othehand, with too little rigor much is lost by basing work on results whiceventually turn out to be false.  There is a morass of studiecontradicting other studies and outsiders start saying  "You people calTHIS science?"   (My opinion, for what it\'s worth, is that one sees botthese phenomena happening simultaneously in some parts of psychology.) Some subjective judgement is required to decide on the level of rigoappropriate for a particular investigation.  I don't believe it isever possible to banish subjective judgement from science. My second point, though, is that highly capable people can often makextremely reliable judgements about scientific validity even when usinmethodology considered inadequate by the usual standards.  I think thiis true of many scientists and I think it is true of many who approactheir discipline in a way that is not generally recognized as scientificWithin mathematics, I think there are several examples, especially beforthe twentieth century.  One conspicuous case is that of Riemann, who ifamous for many theorems he stated but did not prove.  (Latermathematicians did prove them, of course.) I think that for a good scientist, empirical investigation is often noso much a matter of determining what is true and what's not  as it is amatter of convincing other people.  (People have proposed lots ofincompatible definitions of science here, but I think the ability toobjectively convince others of the validity of one's results is aessential element.  Not that one can necessarily do that at every stepof the scientific process, but I think that if one is not moving towardthat goal then one is not doing science.When a person other than a scientist is quite good at what he does anseems to be very successful at it, I think that his judgements are alsworthy of respect and that his assertions are well worth furtheinvestigation. > Namely, is there really justification for the belief tha> science is a superior path to truth than non-scientific approaches? Admittedly, my question was not at all well posed.  A considerablamount of effort in a "serious scholarly investigation" such as suggested would be required simply to formulate an appropriatelyspecific question to try and answer. The "science" I was thinking of in my question is the actual sciencecurrently practiced now in the last decade of the twentieth century. I certainly wasn't thinking of some idealized science or the mere useof "reason and observation.One thing I had in mind in my suggestion was the question as to whethein many cases the subjective judgements of skilled and experiencepractitioners might be more reliable than statistical studies. Since Russell Turpin seems to be much more familiar than I am witthe study of scientific methodology, perhaps he can tell us if thereis any existing research related to this question. -In the arguments between behaviorists and cognitivists, psychology seemsless like a science than a collection of competing religious sects.  lady@uhunix.uhcc.hawaii.edu         lady@uhunix.bitne

As promised, below is a personal critique of a Pressure Point MassagerI recently bought from the Self Care Catalog.  I am very pleased withthe results.  The catalog description is as follows\tThe Pressure Point Massager is an aggressive physical massager\tthat actually kneads the tension out of muscles ... much like \tprofessional shiatsu masseur.  The powerful motor drives tw\tcounter-rotating "thumbs" that move in one-inch orbits -\treleasing tension in the neck, back, legs and arms\tPressure Point Massager    A2623   $10To order or receive a catalog, call (24 hours, 7 days) 1-800-345-3371 ofax at 1-800-345-4021*******NOTEWhen I ordered the massager, the item number was different, and the pricwas $179, not $109.  When I received it, I glanced thru the newer cataloenclosed with it to see anything was different from the first one.  I was QUITE annoyed to see a $70 difference in price.  I called them about itand the cust rep said that they had switched manufacturers, although ilooks and works exactly the same.  He told me to go ahead and return thfirst one and order the cheaper one, using the price difference as reason for return.  In fact, since the newer ones might take a while tship from the factory (I received this one in 3 days), he told me I coulduse the one I already have until the new one arrives, then return the oldone.  VERY reasonable people*******I have long-term neck, shoulder and back pain (if I were a building, Iwould be described as "structurally unsound :-) ).  I have stretchesand exercises to do that help, but the problem never really goes away. If, for whatever reason, I do not exercise for a while (illness, not enougtime, lazy, etc.), the muscles become quite stiff and painful and, thus,more prone to further strain.  Even with exercise, I sometimes requirephysical therapy to get back on track, which 1st requires a doctor visitto get the prescription for p.t. The tension in my neck, if not released, eventually causes a headach(sometimes confused with a sinus headache) over my left eye.  When myphysical therapist has massaged my neck, and the sub-occipital musclesin particular (the 2 knobby areas near the base of the skull), theheadache usually eased within a day, although it hurts like hell towhile it is being massagedI ordered this device because it seemed to be exactly what I was wishinsomeone would invent --a machine that would massage, NOT VIBRATE, myneck and sub-occipital muscles like my physical therapist has done inthe past, that I could use by myself.  No doctor visit or inconvenientp.t. appts for a week later would be needed to use it.  I could get upin the middle of the night and use it, if necessaryI have been using it for about a week or so now, and LOVE it.  The basunit is about a 14" x 9" rectangle, about 3-3/4" high, with handles on eacside, and it plugs into an average outlet.  The two metal "thumbs" are about1-1/2" in diameter and protrude about 2-1/2" above the base.  The thumbsare covered with a gray cloth that is non-removable.  They are located moretoward one end, rather than centered (see figure below).  They move ineither clockwise or counter-clockwise directions, depending on which sideof the switch is pushed, and are very quiet.  It can be used from eitheside.  For instance, the thumbs can be positioned at the base of the necor the top of the neck, depending on which direction you approach it                 ______________________________                |  __    _______________    __                  | |  |  |\t\t|  |  |                 | |  |  |  \\^^/   \\^^/  |  |  |                 | |  |  |   ||     ||   |  |  |                 | |  |  |\t\t|  |  |                 | |  |  |_______________|  |  |                 | |__|\t\t\t   |__|                 |_______________________________For the neck/head, the user varies the amount of pressure used by (iflaying down) allowing all or part of the full weight of the head and/orneck to rest on the thumbs.  The handles can also be used if sitting ostanding, applying pressure with the arms/wrists.  Since my wrists aralso impaired (I'm typing this over an extended period of time), and Idon't have someone living with me who can apply it, laying down workswell for meFor my back, I sit in a high-backed kitchen chair, position the massagebehind me at whatever point I want massaged, and lean back lightly (onot so lightly) against it.  The pressure of leaning back holds it in place. If I want to massage the entire spine, I simply move it down a few incheswhenever I feel like it.  For my back, this machine is far superior to usethan the commonly used "home-made" massager of 2 tennis balls taped together(with the balls, position (against a wall or door) them over the spine andmove the body up and down against them).  The tennis balls are better thannothing, but difficult to use for very long, especially if your quads arenot in good shape, and my long hair gets (painfully) in the way if I don'tpin it up first.  As far as I'm concerned, the easier something like thisis to use, the more likely I'll use/do it.  If there are multipleconsiderations/hassles, I'm more likely to not bother with itNot only has this machine helped with my headaches, but my range of motionfor my neck and back are greatly increased.  The first time I used it on mneck/sub-occipital muscles, however, I overdid it and pressed too haragainst it, which resulted in a very tender, almost bruised area for few days.  I laid off it for about 3 days and applied ice, which helped. After that, I was more gradual about applying pressure.  At this point,the pain in the sub-occipital area is now minimal while being massaged. I also learned to use VERY LIGHT pressure on my lower back, which is themost vulnerable point for meIt also eased some painful knots of tension between my shoulder bladesalthough, again, it took a few days of massaging (just a few minutes aa time) to really work it outI highly recommend this product if you have similar problems, although cannot vouch for its durability (it seems pretty sturdy), since I've hait such a short time.  I plan to use it not only to ease tension, but alsoto loosen the muscls BEFORE exercising (and maybe after, too).  I havbeen ill recently and not able to exercise much for a few weeks, so thiswas very timely  for meThis is the 1st product I've ordered from this company and only recentlbecame aware of it thru a co-worker.  The catalog states they have beein business since 1976.  It contains quite a few health care products andwhile they appear to be more expensive than the average health care cataloproducts, they also appear to be of much higher quality with more thoughput into what they actually do.  Definitely a step above some other oneI\'ve seen such as "Dr. Leonards Health Care Catalog" or "Mature Wisdom"I'm only 37, but have ended up on some geriatric-type mailing lists (nbig surprise here :-) ).  I consider many of those products to be rip-offs,particularly targeted toward the elderly, with dubious health benefitsI apologize for the length of this, but it's the kind of info _I_ wouldlike to know before ordering something thru the mailRobin Coutellier                  Northern Telecom, Mountain MyView, CINTERNET: robin@ntmtv.coUUCP:portal!ntmtv!robi

I know that the placebo effect is where a patient feels better oreven gets better because of his/her belief in the medicine andthe doctor administering it.  Is there also an anti-placeboeffect where the patient dislikes/distrusts doctors and medicineand therefore doesn't get better or feel better in spite of themedicineIs there an effect where the doctor believes so strongly in amedicine that he/she sees improvement where the is none or seesmore improvement than there is?  If so, what is this effectcalled?  Is there a reverse of the above effect where the doctordoesn't believe in a medicine and then sees less improvement thanthere is?      Following a series of miscarriages, my wife was given a transfusion omy white cells. (The theory as I understand it is that there is some kinof immune blocking that prevents the body from attacking the pregnancy ait normally would a "foreign" body. Following the transfusion, shsuccessfully carried the next pregnancy to term, and Jake is now an activ9 month-old who cannot wait to walk     We're now thinking about having another child, but no one (includinthe OBGYN who supervised the first transfusion) really seems to knowhether or not the transfusion process needs to be repeated for successivpregnancies     Is there anyone in net-land who has experience with thisThanks...Gene (and Jane and JakeP.S. |> I'm not familiar with the history of this experiment, although, arguably|> I should beFor a brief, but pretty detailed account, try Hempel's _Philosophy oNatural Science_|> I think that it is enough if his contemporaries found the result surprising|> That's not what I'd quibble about. It may bThis smacks a bit of ideology -- the supposition being that Toricelli'subsequent descriptions of his reasoning are not veridical.  It gets dangerouslclose to an unfalsifiable view of the history and methodology of science iwe deny that no subsequent reports of experimenters are reliable descriptionof their "real" reasons|> impossible to know much about Toricelli's thoughts; that's too bad i|> it is so.  One of Root-Bernstein's services to science is that he has gon|> rooting about in Pasteur's and Fleming's (and other people's) notes, and ha|> discovered some surprising clues about their motivations.  Pasteur neve|> publicly admitted his plan to create mirror-image life, but the dreams ar|> right there in his notebooks (finally public after many years), ready fo|> anyone to read.  And I and my friends often have the most ridiculou|> reasons for pursuing results; one of my best came because I was mad a|> a colleague for a poorly-written claim (I disproved the claim)|>|> Of course, Toricelli's case may be an example of a rarety: where th|> fantasy not only motivates the experiment, but turns out to be righ|> in the endBut my point is that this type of case is *not* a rarity.  In fact, I wagoing to point to Pasteur as yet another rather common example -- particularlthe studies on spontaneous generation and fermentation.  I will readilconcede that "ridiculous reasons" can play an important role in hoscientists spend their time.  But one should not confuse motivation witmethodology nor suppose that ridiculous reasons provide the impetus in thmajority of cases based on relatively infrequent anecdotal evidence--Gary H. >This reminds me of the last Graham Kerr cooking show I saw.  Today h>smoked meat on the stovetop in a big pot! The lid was put on, and the whole assembl>went on the stovetop at high heat for 10 or 12 minutes>>Later, he removed what looked like smoked chicken breasts.  What surprise>and concerns me are>>1)  No wood chips.  Where does the smoke flavor come from>>2)  About 5 or 10 years ago, I remember hearing that carmel colo>    (obtained by caramelizing sugar -- a common coloring and flavorin>    agent) had been found to be carcinogenic.  I believe they injecte>    it under the skin of rats, or something.  If the results were conclusive>    caramel color would not be legal in the U.S., yet it is still bein>    used. Does anyone know whateve>    happened with that story?  If it were carcinogenic, Earl Grey te>    could not have it as an additive, yet it apparently continues to d>    so>>WRT natural wood smoke (I've smoking a duck right now, as it happens)>I've noticed that a heavily-smoked food item will have an unpleasant tang>taste when eaten directly out of the smoker if the smoke has only recentl>stopped flowing.  I find the best taste to be had by using dry wood chips>getting lots of smoke right up at the beginning of the cooking process>then slowly barbequing for hours and hours without adding additional wood chips>>My theory is that the unpleasant tangy molecules are low-molecular weigh>stuff, like terpenes, and that the smoky flavor molecules are some sor>of larger molecule more similar to tar.  The long barbeque time afte>the initial intensive smoke drives off the low-molecular weight stuff>just leaving the flavor behind.  Does anyone know if my theory is correct>>I also remember hearing that the combustion products of fat drippin>on the charcoal and burning are carcinogenic.  For that reason, and becaus>it covers the product with soot and some unpleasant tanginess, I only gril>non-drippy meats like prawns directly over hot coals.  I do stuff like thi>duck by indirect heat.  I have a long rectangular Weber, and I put the coal>at one end and the meat at the other end.  The fat drops directly on th>floor below the meat, and next time I use the barbeque I make the fir>in that end to burn off the fat and help ignite the coals>>And yet another reason I've heard not to smoke or barbeque meat is tha>smoked cured meat, like pork sausage and bacon, contain>nitrosamines, which are carcinogenic.  I'm pretty sure this claim actuall>has some standing, don't know about the others>>An amusing incident I recall was the Duncan Hines scandal, when it wa>discovered that the people who make Duncan Hines cake mix were puttin>a lot of ethylene dibromide (EDB) into the cake mix to suppress weevils>This is a fumigant which is known to be carcinogenic>The guy who represented the company in the press conference defende>himself by saying that the risk from eating Duncan Hines products every da>for a year would be equal to the cancer risk from eating two charcoal>broiled steaks.  What a great analogy!  When I first heard that, m>immediate reaction was we should make that a standard unit!  One charcoa>broiled steak would be equivalent to 0.5 DuncansI don't understand the assumption that because something is found tbe carcinogenic that "it would not be legal in the U.S.".  I think thanaturally occuring substances (excluding "controlled" substances) arpretty much unregulated in terms of their use as food, food additiveor other "consumption".  It\'s only when the chemists concoct (sp?) aingredient that it falls under FDA regulations.  Otherwise, if theyreally looked closely they would find a reason to ban almost everythingHow in the world do you suppose it\'s legal to "consume" tobacco product(which probably SHOULD be banned)\tDave Alle\tSpace Science & Engr. Contents of file 58966
-*----> Is there an effect where the doctor believes so strongly in a> medicine that he/she sees improvement where the is none or sees> more improvement than there is?  If so, what is this effect> called?  Is there a reverse of the above effect where the doctor> doesn't believe in a medicine and then sees less improvement than> there is?  What would this effect be called?  Have these effects> ever been studied?  How common are these effects?  Thank you in> advance for all replies.These effects are a very real concern in conducting studies of netreatments.  Researchers try to limit this kind of effect byperforming studies that are "blind" in various ways.  Some of thesare  o  The subjects of the study do not know whether they receive a     placebo or the test treatment, i.e., whether they are in th     control group or the test group  o  Those administering the treatment do not know which subjects     receive a placebo or the test treatment  o  Those evaluating individual results do not know which subject     receive a placebo or the test treatmentObviously, at the point at which the data is analyzed, one has todifferentiate the test group from the control group.  But the analysiis quasi-public: the researcher describes it and presents the data owhich it is based so that others can verify it. It is worth noting that in biological studies where the subjects aranimals, such as mice, there were many cases of skewed results becausthose who performed the study did not "blind" themselves.  It is noconsidered so important to make mice more ignorant than they alreadare, though it is important that in all respects except the one testedthe control and test groups are treated alikeRussel

Contents of file 58981
-*---I think that part of the problem is that I have proposed definition of science that I intended to be interpreted broadland that Lee Lady has interpreted fairly narrowly.  My definitiois this: Science is the investigation of the empirical that avoidmistakes in reasoning and methodology discovered from previouwork.  Lee Lady writes> I don't think that science should be defined in a way that some> of the activities that lead to really important science --- namel> thinking and informal exploration --- are not recognized a> scientific work. Unless one classifies "thinking and informal exploration" as mistake, they fall under my definition.  I hope no one woulconsider speculation, thinking, and informal exploration aunscientific. > Seriously, I'm not sure whether I misjudged you or not, in one respect. > I still have a major problem, though, with your insistence that science> is mainly about avoiding mistakes. ..Here is where I think we are talking at cross-purposes.  It is noclear to me that the kind of definition I have proposed should btaken as describing what "science is mainly about."  Considerfor example, a definition of invertebrates as all animals lackina backbone.  This fairly tells what is an invertebrate anwhat is not an invertebrate, but it hardly tells you whainvertebrates are all about.  One can read this definition anstill not know that 95% of all animal species are invertebratesthat invertebrates possess a remarkably broad range of form, thasome invertebrate groups -- such as insects and nematodes -- arubiquitous in all ecosystems, etc.  In short, knowing thdefinition of invertebrates does *not* tell one what they ar"mainly about.The misunderstanding here is my fault.  I did not give sufficiencontext for people to understand my proposed definition> Okay, so let's see if we agree on this: FIRST of all, there are degrees> of certainty.  It might be appropriate, for instance, to demand carefully> controlled trials before we accept as absolute scientific truth (to the> extent that there is any such thing) the effectiveness of a certain> treatment. On the other hand, highly favorable clinical experience, even> if uncontrolled, can be adequate to justify a *preliminary* judgement tha> a treatment is useful. ..> SECONDLY, it makes sense to be more tolerant in our standards of> evidence for a pronounced effect than for one that is marginal. I agree on both counts.  As an example of the second, it would onltake a few cases of curing rabies to convince most veterinarianthat a treatment was effective, despite a lack of controls. As to the first, I do not think it is useful to talk abou"absolute scientific truth."  I think it is more useful to talabout the kinds of evidence that various claims have and thkinds of evidence IN PARTICULAR FIELDS that in the past havproven faulty or reliable.  The latter is obviously a matter odegree, and in each field, practitioners try to discover threlevance of different kinds of evidence. One of the primary mistakes that marks the advocacy of an idea apsuedo-science is that the advocacy lacks any sense of proportioregarding the kinds of evidence related to the proposed claimthe kinds of evidence that are actually relevant to it, and thhistorical reasons in the field that certain kinds of evidencare given more weight than others.  It is perfectly alright tspeculate.  I have read quite a few refereed papers thaspeculated left and right.  But the authors were careful tidentify the notions as speculative, to list what little evidencwas presently available for them, and to describe how researccould proceed to either put the notion on more firm footing or tuncover its problems.  Often what distinguishes whether a papeof this sort passes muster is the thoughtfulness with which thauthor sets the context and paves the way for future work.  (Iis in this area that many proponents of speculative ideas fail.> The folks over in sci.psychology have a hundred and one excuses not t> make this simple test.  They claim that only an elaborate outcome stud> will be satisfactory --- a study of the sort that NLP practitioners,> many of whom make a barely marginal living from their practice, can ill> afford to do.  (Most of them are also just plain not interested, because> the whole idea seems frivolous.  And since they're not part of th> scientific establishment, they have no tangible rewards to gain> from scientific acceptance.)I think a lot of scientists steer away from things that -deserving or not -- garner a patina of kookiness.  Wheproponents of some practice see no value in more carefuinvestigation of that practice, that sets alarms ringing in manresearchers' minds. This is unfortunate, because there is undoubtedly somintersection between things that are worth investigating anthings that are advocated by those who seem careless ounreasonable in their advocacy.  On the other hand, I caunderstand why many scientists would just as soon select othedirections for research.  As Gordon Banks has pointed out, no onwants to become this generation's Rhine> One academic in sci.psychology said that it would be completely> unscientific for him to test the phobia cure since it hasn't> been described in a scientific journal. ..I think this is absurd. > Actually, at least one fairly careful academic study has been done> (with favorable results), but it's apparently not acceptable becaus> it's a doctoral dissertation and not published in a refereed journalI wonder why the results were not published.  In my fielddissertation results are typically summarized in papers that arsubmitted to journals.  Often the papers are accepted fopublication before the dissertation is finished.  (This certainleases one's defense.Finally, I hope Lee Lady will forgive me from commenting eitheon NLP or the discussion of it in sci.psychology.  I know littlabout either and so have nothing to offerRussel

Thanks>>There is an "eyedness" analogous to handedness but it has nothing to d>with refractive error.  To see whether you are right or left eyed, rol>up a sheet of paper into a tube and hold it up to either eye like >telescope.  The eye that you feel more comfortable putting it up to i>your dominant eye.  Refractive error is often different in the two eye>but has no correlation with handedness>>David Nye (nyeda@cnsvax.uwec.edu). That seems a bihard to evaluate.  At least for me it is. Stare straight Point with both hands together and clasp so that only thpointer fingers are pointing straight forward to a a spot on the wall aboueight feet away.  First stare at the spot with both eyes open.  Noclose your left eye.  Now open your left eye.  Now close your right eyenow open your right eyeIf the image jumped more when you closed your right eye, you are righeye dominantIf the image jumped more when you closed your left eye, you are left eydominantDeanth

:I recently had a case of shingles and my doctors wanted to give m:intravenous Acyclovir:It was a pain finding IV sites in my arms...can I have some facts abou:how advantageous it is to give intravenous antibiotics rather than oralI think some essential information must be missing here, i.e., you must bsuffering from a condition which has caused immunosuppression.  There ino indication for IV acyclovir for shingles in an otherwise healthperson.  The oral form can help to reduce the length of symptoms, and maeven help prevent the development of post-herpetic neuralgia, but certainly would not subject someone to IV therapy without a good reasonTo address your more general question, IV therapy does provide higher anmore consistently high plasma and tissue levels of a drug.  For treating serious infection this is the only way to be sure that a patient igetting adequate drug levels--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=  Kenneth Gilbert              __|__        University of Pittsburgh   =  General Internal Medicine      |      "...dammit, not a programmer!" =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-|-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Contents of file 59002
> I don't understand the assumption that because something is found t> be carcinogenic that "it would not be legal in the U.S.".  I think tha> naturally occuring substances (excluding "controlled" substances) ar> pretty much unregulated in terms of their use as food, food additive> or other "consumption".  It\'s only when the chemists concoct (sp?) a> ingredient that it falls under FDA regulations.  Otherwise, if they> really looked closely they would find a reason to ban almost everything> How in the world do you suppose it\'s legal to "consume" tobacco product> (which probably SHOULD be banned)No, there is something called the "Delany Amendment" which makes carcinogenifood additives illegal in any amount.  This was passed by Congress in th1950's, before stuff like mass spectrometry became available, which increasedetectable levels of substances by a couple orders of magnitudeThis is why things like cyclamates and Red #2 were banned.  They are verweakly carcinogenic in huge quantities in rats, so under the Act they arbannedThis also applies to natural carcinogens.  Some of you might remember time back in the 1960's when root beer suddenly stopped tasting so goodand never tasted so good again.  That was the time when safrole was bannedThis is the active flavoring ingredient in sassafras leavesIf it were possible to market a root beer good like the old days, someonwould do it, in order to make money.  The fact that no one does it indicatethat enforcement is still in effectAn odd exception to the rule seems to be the product known as "gumbo file\'"This is nothing more than coarsely ground dried sassafras leaves.  Thiis not only a natural product, but a natural product still in its naturaform, so maybe that's how they evade Delany.  Or maybe a special exemptiowas made, to appease powerful Louisiana Democrats

[Newsgroups: m.h.a added, followups set to most appropriate groups.In <1993Apr19.205615.1013@unlv.edu> todamhyp@charles.unlv.edu (Brian MHuey) writes>I am looking for any information/supplies that will allo>do-it-yourselfers to take Krillean Pictures(It\'s "Kirlian".  "Krillean" pictures are portraits of tiny shrimp. :[...>One might extrapolate here and say that this proves that every objec>within the universe (as we know it) has its own energy signatureI think it's safe to say that anything that's not at 0 degrees Kelviwill have its own "energy signature" -- the interesting questions arwhat kind of energy, and what it signifiesI'd check places like Edmund Scientific (are they still in business?) -or I wonder if you can find ex-Soviet Union equipment for sale somewherin the relcom.* hierarchySome expansion on Kirlian photographyFrom the credulous side: [Stanway, Andrew, _Alternative Medicine: A GuidTo Natural Therapies_, ISBN 0-14-008561-0, New York: Viking Penguin, 1986p211, p188.  A not-overly critical but still useful overview of 3alternative health therapies.  ...the Russian engineer Semyon Kirlian and his wife Valentina during th  1950s.  Using alternating currents of high frequency to 'illuminate  their subjects, they photographed them.  They found that if an objec  was a good conductor (such as a metal) the picture showed only it  surface, while the pictures of poor conductors showed the inne  structure of the object even if it were optically opaque.  They foun  too that these high frequency pictures could distinguish between dea  and living objects.  Dead ones had a constant outline whilst living one  were subject to changes.  The object's life activity was also visible i  highly variable colour patterns  High frequency photography has now been practised for twenty years i  the Soviet Union but only a few people in the West have taken it u  seriously.  Professor Douglas Dean in New York and Professor Philips a  Washington University in St Louis have produced Kirlian photographs an  others have been produced in Brazil, Austria and Germany  Using Kirlian photography it is possible to show an aura around people'  fingers, notably around those of healers who are concentrating o  healing someone.  Normally, blue and white rays emanate from the finger  but, when a subject becomes angry or excited, the aura turns red an  spotty.  The Soviets are now using Kirlian photography to diagnos  diseases which cannot be diagnosed by any other method.  They argue tha  in most illnesses there is a preclinical stage during which the perso  isn't actually ill but is about to be.  They claim to be able t  foretell a disease by photographing its preclinical phase  But the most exciting phenomenon illustrated by Kirlian photography i  the phantom effect.  During high frequency photography of a leaf fro  which a part had been cut, the photograph gave a complete picture of th  leaf with the removed part showing up faintly.  This is extremel  important because it backs up the experiences of psychics who can 'see  the legs of amputees as if they were still there.  The important thin  about the Kirlian phantoms though is that the electromagnetic patter  can't possibly represent a secondary phenomenon -- or the field woul  vanish when the piece of leaf or leg vanished.  The energy gri  contained in a living object must therefore be far more significant tha  the actual object itself  [...  Kirlian photography has shown how water mentally 'charged' by a heale  has a much richer energy field around it than ordinary water..From the incredulous side: [MacRobert, Alan, "Reality shopping; consumer\'s guide to new age hokum.", _Whole Earth Review_, Autumn 1986vNON4 p4(11).  An excellent article providing common-sense guidelines foevaluating paranormal claims, and some of the author's favorite exampleof hokum.  The crank usually works in isolation from everyone else in his field o  study, making grand discoveries in his basement.  Many paranorma  movements can be traced back to such people -- Kirlian photography, fo  instance.  If you pump high-voltage electricity into anything it wil  emit glowing sparks, common knowledge to electrical workers an  hobbyists for a century.  It took a lone basement crank to declare tha  the sparks represent some sort of spiritual aura.  In fact, Kirlia  photography was subjected to rigorous testing by physicists John O  Pehek, Harry J. Kyler, and David L. Faust, who reported their finding  in the October 15, 1976, issue of Science.  Their conclusion: Th  variations observed in Kirlian photographs are due solely to moisture o  the surface of the body and not to mysterious "auras" or eve  necessarily to changes in mood or mental state.  Nevertheless  television shows, magazines, and books (many by famou  parapsychologists) continue to promote Kirlian photography as proof o  the unknown--Peter Kaminskkaminski@netcom.co
