Contents of file 59321
The following is based on copies I was given of some articles published iHearing Instruments. I would appreciate any comments about this and othe'new' technology for hearing aidsThe ReSound system was developed on the basis of some research at AT&T anappears to take a different approach from other aids. It appears to me thaa new 'programmable' aid like the Widex just uses a more flexible (anprogrammable) version of the classical approach of amplifying some parts othe spectrum more than others and adding some compression to try and helout in 'noisy' situationsThe major difference in the ReSound approach is that it divides thspectrum into low and high frequencies (splitting point is programmable)apparently based on the fact that lots of vowel information can be found ithe low frequencies, while the important consonant informatio(unfortunately for me) is in the high frequencies. The two bands then artreated with different compression schemes which are programable. They havalso developed a new fitting algorythm that builds on what they cal'abnormal growth of loudness'This latter is interesting and fits my own personal experience, though think the phrase is missleading. What appears to be the case is that as yoexceed the minimum threshold for a person with hearing loss, the deficibecomes progresslively less compared to normals and by the time you reacthe 'too loud' point the sensitivity curves appear to converge.  This meanthat if you just boost all sound levels, you are overloading at the higend for people with hearing losses. Hence what you want is progressivelless amplification as the signal get closer to the maximum tolerable pointYou want to boost low volume sounds more than high and do so potentialldifferently for the low and high frequency parts of the spectrum (speciallfor someone like me who is relatively normal up to 1000 cps and then falloff a cliff)Aids with simple compressors don't descriminate between energy in the loand high frequencies and can therefor 'compress' useful high frequencinformation because of high volume of low frequency componentsParticularly impressive was the ReSound performance with whispered speecand in simulated restaurant noise situations.-Rich Haller <rhaller@ns.uoregon.edu>   University of Oregon, Eugene, ORUS
Contents of file 59322
banschbach@vms.ocom.okstate.edu writes>to candida blooms following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics?  Gorden>Rubenfeld, through e-mail, has assured me that most physicians recognize>the chance of candida blooms occuring after broad-spectrum antibiotic use>and they therefore reinnoculate their patients with *good* bacteria to>restore competetion for candida in the body.  I do not believe that this is>yet a standard part of medical practice.   Nor is it mine.  What I tried to explain to Marty was that it is clearlunderstood that antibiotic exposure is a risk factor for fungal infection- which is not the same as saying bacteria prevent fungal infections.Marty made this sound like a secret  known only to veternarians anbiochemists.  Anyone who has treated a urinary tract infection knownthis. At some centers pre-op liver transplant patients receive bowedecontamination directed at retaining "good" anaerobic flora in an attempto prevent fungal colonization in this soon-to-be high risk group.  I alsuse lactobacillus to treat enteral nutrition associated diarrhea (that mabe in part due to alterations in gut flora).  However, it is NOT part omy routine practice to "reinnoculate" patients with "good" bacteria afteantibiotics.  I have seen no data on this practice preventing or treatinfungal infections in at risk patients.  Whether or not it is a "logicaextension" from the available observations I\'ll leave to those of you whbase strong opinions and argue over such speculations in the absence oclinical trials.  One place such therapy has been described is in treating particularlrecalcitrant cases of C. difficile colitis (NOT a fungal infection). Therare case reports of using stool (ie someone elses) enemas to repopulatthe patients flora.  Don't try this at home.>not give give her advise to use the OTC anti-fungal creams.  Since candida>colonizes primarily in the ano-rectal area, GI symptoms should be more common>than vaginal problems after broad-spectrum antibiotic use  Except that it isn't. At least symptomatically apparent disease>Medicine has not, and probalby never will be, practiced this way.  There>has always been the use of conventional wisdom.  A very good example is>kidney stones.  Conventional wisdom(because clinical trails have not been>done to come up with an effective prevention), was that restricitng the>intake of calcium and oxalates was the best way to prevent kidney stones>from forming.  Clinical trials focused on drugs or ultrasonic blasts to>breakdown the stone once it formed.  Through the recent New England J of>Medicine article, we now know that conventional wisdom was wrong,>increasing calcium intake is better at preventing stone formation than is>restricting calcium intake  Seems like this is an excellent argument for ignoring anecdotaconventional wisdom (a euphemism for no data) and doing a good clinicatrial, like:AU   Dismukes-W-E.  Wade-J-S.  Lee-J-Y.  Dockery-B-K.  Hain-J-DTI   A randomized, double-blind trial of nystatin therapy for th     candidiasis hypersensitivity syndrome [see commentsSO   N-Engl-J-Med.  1990 Dec 20.  323(25).  P 1717-23     psychological tests. RESULTS. The three active-treatment regimen     and the all-placebo regime     significantly reduced both vaginal and systemic symptoms (P less tha     0.001), but nystatin did not reduce the systemic symptom     significantly more than placebo. [ . . .      CONCLUSIONS. In women with presumed candidiasi     hypersensitivity syndrome, nystatin does not reduce systemic o     psychological symptoms significantly more than placebo. Consequently     the empirical recommendation of long-term nystatin therapy for suc     women appears to be unwarranted  Does this trial address every issue raised here, no.  Jon Noring was nosurprised at this negative trial since they didn't use *Sporanox* (despitCrook's recommendation for Nystatin).  Maybe they didn't avoid thoscarbohydrates . . .>The conventional wisdom in animal husbandry has been that animals need to>be reinnoculated with *good* bacteria after coming off antibiotic therapy>If it makes sense for livestock, why doesn't it make sense for humans>David?  We are not talking about a dangerous treatment(unless you consider>yogurt dangerous).  If this were a standard part of medical practice, as>Gordon R. says it is, then the incidence of GI distress and vaginal yeast>infections should decline  Marty, you've also changed the terrain of the discussion from empiriitraconazole for undocumented chronic fungal sinusitis with systemihypersensitivity symptoms (Noring syndrome) to the yoghurt and vitamitherapy of undocumented candida enteritis (Elaine Palmer syndrome) witsystemic symptoms.  There is significant difference between the cost anrisk of these two empiric therapeutic trials.  Are we talking about "realcandida infections, the whole "yeast connection" hypothesis, the efficacof routine bacterial repopulation in humans, or the ability of anecdotalleffective therapies (challenged by a negative randomized trial) to confiran etiologic hypothesis (post hoc ergo propter hoc).  We can't seem tfocus in on a disease, a therapy, or a hypothesis under discussion.                                    I'm lost
Contents of file 59323
This question came up in Sci. Med. Nutrition and I'm posting my answerhere.  Only 22 medical schools in the U.S. teach courses on humannutrition.  We have already seen what a lack of nutrition education can dowhen candida and kidney stones present themselves to the medical communityI think that the best example of where U.S. medicine is really missing themark when it comes to a knowledge of nutrition is PMS.  So many women(andtheir husbands) suffer from this disorder that it is really criminal thatmost physicians in the U.S. are not taught that PMS is primarily caused bydiet and diet changes can prevent it from ever happpening.  Before shootingyour flames, read the entire article and then decide if flaming isjustifiedFrom A Poster In Sci. Medi. Nutrition> \tIn a psychological anthropology course I am taking, we got> sidetracked onto a short conversation about PMS.  Some rumors share> by several of the students included ideas that vitamin levels, suga> intake, and caffeine intake might affect PMS symptoms> \tIs there any data on this, or is it just so much hooey>> Many thanks>> Michael, I've wanted to reply to this post ever since I saw it but I gotside-tracked with candida.  PMS is a lot like Candida blooms, mostphysicians don\'t recognize it as a specific "disease" entity.  Here iseverything that you would ever want to know about PMSPremenstrual syndrome has been divided into four specific subgroups\tPMT-A(Anxiety)\t\tPMT-D(depression\tanxiety\t\t\tdepressio\tirritability\t\tforgetfulnes\tinsomnia\t\tconfusio\tdepression\t\tletharg\tPMT-C(Craving)\t\tPMT-H(Hyperhydration\tcraving for sweets\tweight gai\tincreased appetite\tbreast congestion and tendernes\tsugar ingestion causes: abdominal bloating and tendernes\t 1. headache\t\tedema of the face and extremitie\t 2. palpitation\t 3. fatigue or faintinPMT-A is characterized by elevated blood estrogen levels and lowprogesterone levels during the luteal phase of a women's cyclePMT-C is caused by the ingestion of large amounts of refined simplecarbohydrates.  During the luteal phase of a women's cycle, there isincreased glucose tolerance with a flat glucose curve after oral glucosechallenge.  The metabolic findings believed to be responsible for PMT-C area low magnesium and a low prostaglandin E1.  This condition of hypoglycemiais not unique to PMS but there are a number of different causes ofhypoglycemia, magnesium and PGE1 seem to be specific to PMS hypoglycemia\tA. Am. J. Psychiatry 147(4):477-80(1990)Unrefined complex carbohydrate should be substituted for sugar, magnesiumsupplementation and alpha linoleic acid supplementation(increased to 5-6% ofthe total calories) using safflower oil or evening primrose oil as sourcesof alpha linoleic acidPMT-D is characterized by elevated progesterone levels during the midlutealphase of a women's cycle.  Another cause of PMT-D has been found to be leadtoxicity(in women without elevated progesterone levels during the midlutealphase). "Effect of metal ions on the binding of estridol to humanendometrial cystol" Fertil. Steril. 28:312-18(1972)PMT-H is associated with water and salt retention along with an elevatedserum aldosterone level.  Salt restriction, B6, magnesium and vitamin Efor breast tenderness have all been effective in treating PMT-This general discussion of the PMS syndromes came form\tA. "Management of the premenstrual tension sundromes: Rational for\t    a nutritional approach". 1986, A Year in Nutritional Medicine.\t    J. Bland, Ed. Keats, Publishing, 1986\tB. "Nutritional factors in the etiology of premenstrual tension\t    syndromes", J. Reprod. Med.28(7):446-64(1983)\tC. "Premenstrual tension", Prob. Obstet. Gynecol. 3(12):1-39(1980Treatment has traditionally involved progesterone administration if you canfind a doctor who will treat you for PMS(just about as hard as finding onethat will treat you for candida blooms).  While progesterone will work,supplementation with vitamins and minerals works even better.  There reallyhas been an awful lot of research done on PMS(much more than candidablooms).  Many of these studies have been what are called experimentalcontrolled studies(the type of rigorous clinical studies that doctors like tosee done)Here are a few of these studies\tCARBOHYDRATE: Experimental Controlled Study, "Effect of a low-fat,\thigh-carbohydrate diet on symptoms of cyclical mastopathy" Lancet\t2:128-32(1988).  21 pts with severe persistent cyclical mastopathy\tof at least 5 years duration were randomly selected to receive\tspecific training to reduce dietary fat to 15% of total calories\tand increase complex carbohydrate ingestion or given general dietary\tadvise with no training.  After 6 months, there was a significant\treduction in the severity of the breast swelling and tenderness in\tthe trained group as reported by self-reported symptoms as well as\tphysical exams which quantitated the degree of breast swelling,\ttenderness and nodularity\tVITAMIN A: Experimental Controlled Study, "The use of Vitamin A in\tpremenstrual tension" Acta Obstet. Gynecol Scand. 39:586-92(1960). \t218 pts with severe recurring PMS received 200,000 to 300,000IU\tvitamin A daily or a placebo.  Serum retinol levels were monitored\tand high dose supplementation was discontinued when evidence of\ttoxicity occured(serum retinol above 450ug/ml).  The intent of the\tstudy was to load the liver up with vitamin A and get a normal pool\tsize(500,000IU to 1,000,000IU) and then see if this\tnormal vitamin A pool could prevent PMS.  48% getting the high dose\tvitamin A had complete remission of the symptoms of PMS.  Only 10%\tgetting the placebo reported getting complete relief of PMS sysmptoms  \t10% of the vitamin A treated group reported no improvement in PMS\tsymptoms\tExperimental Controlled Study, "Premenstrual tension treated with\tvitamin A" J. Clinical Endocrinology 10:1579-89(1950). 30 pts\treceived 200,000IU of vitamin A daily starting on day 15 of their\tcycle with supplementation continuing until the onset of PMS symptoms  \tAfter 2-6 months, all 30 pts reported a significant improvement in\tPMS symptoms.  Vitamin A supplementation was stopped once evidence of\ttoxicity was demonstrated and all 30 pts were followed for one year\tafter high dose vitamin A supplementation was stopped.  PMS symptoms\tdid not reoccur in any of these 30 pts for upto one year after the\tvitamin A supplementation was stoppedMost Americans do not have a normal store of vitamin A in their liver. These studies and several others were designed to see if getting a normalstore of vitamin A into the liver could eliminate PMS.  Of all the vitaminsgiven for PMS(vitamin A, B6, and vitamin E), vitamin A has shown the bestsingle effect.  This is probably because vitamin A is involved in steroid(estrogen/progesterone) metabolism in the liver.  Getting your liver fullof vitamin A seems to be one of the best things that you can do to preventthe symptoms of PMS.  But vitamin A is toxic and you don't want to be tryingto do this without being seen by a physician who can monitor you for vitaminA toxicity\tVITAMIN B6: Experimental Double-blind Crossoverr Study, "Pyridoxin\t(vitamin B6) and the premenstrual syndrome: A randomized crossover\ttrial"J.R. Coll. Gen. Pract. 39:364-68(1989).  32 women aged 18-49\twith moderate to severe PMS randomly received 50mg B6 daily or placebo  \tAfter 3 months the groups were switched and followed for another\t3 months.  B6 had a significant effect on the emotional aspects of\tPMS(depression, irritability and tiredness).  Other symptoms of PMS\twere not significanttly affected by B6 supplementation\tExperimental Double-blind Study, "The efects of vitamin B6\tsupplementation on premenstrual sysmptoms" Obstet. Gynecol\t70(2):145-49(1987).  55 pts with moderate to severe PMS received\t150mg B6 daily or placebo for 2 months.  Analysis of convergence\tshowed that B6 significantly improved premenstrual symptoms related\tto the autonomic nervous system(dizziness and vomiting) as well as\tbehavior changes(poor mental performance, decreased social interaction  \tAnxiety, depression and water retention were not improved by B6\tsupplementationVitamin B6 is below the RDA for both American men and women.  Birth controlpills and over 40 different drugs increase the B6 requirement in man. Women on birth control pills should be supplemented with 10-15 mg of B6 perday.  The dose should be increased if symptoms of PMS appear.  Dr. David R.Rubinow who heads the biological psychiatry branch of NIMH was quoted inClin. Psychiatry News, December, 1987 as stating that B6 should beconsidered the "first-line" drug for PMS(over progesterone) and if thepatient does not respond, then other treatments should be tried.  VitaminB6 can be toxic(nerve damage) if consumed in doses of 500mg or more eachday.\tVITAMIN E: Experimental Double-blind Study, "Efficacy of alpha\ttocopherol in the treatment of premenstrual syndrome" J. Reprod.\tMed. 32(6):400-04(1987). 35 pts received 400IU vitamin E daily for 3\tcycles or a placebo.  Vitamin E treated pts had 33% who reported a\tsignificant reduction in physical symptoms(weight gain and breast\ttenderness) while the placebo group had 14% who reported a significan \treduction in physical symptoms. The vitamin E group reported that 38%\thad a significant reduction in anxiety versus 12% for the placebo\tgroup.  For depression, the vitamin E group had 27% with a significan\tdecrease in depression compared with 8% for the placebo group\tExperimental Double-blind Study, "The effect of alpha-tocopherol on\tpremenstrual symptomalogy: A double blind study" J. Am. Coll. Nutr.\t2(2):115-122(1983). 75pts with benign breast disease and PMT randomly\treceived vitamin E at 75IU, 150IU, or 300IU daily or placebo.  After\t2 months of supplementation, 150IU of vitamin E or higher significantly\timproved PMT-A and PMT-C.  The 300IU dose was needed to significantly\timprove PMT-D.  No dose of vitamin E significantly improved PMT-\t(other studies have shown that a higher vitamin E doses will relieve\tPMT-H symptoms)\\tMAGNESIUM: Experimental Double-blind Study, "Magnesium prophylaxis\tof menstrual migraine: effects on itracellular magnesium" Headache\t31:298-304(1991). 20 pts with perimenstrual headache received 360 mg\tdaily of magnesium as magnesium pyrrolidone carboxylic acid or a\tplacebo.  Treatment was started on the 15th day of the cycle and\tcontinued until menstruation. After 2 months, the Pain Total Index\twas significantly lower in the magnesium group.  Magnesium treatment\twas also assocoiated with a significant reduction in the Menstrual\tDistress Questionnaire scores.  Pretreatment magnesium levels in \tlymphocytes and polymorphonuclear leukocytes were significantly lower\tin this group of 20 pts compared to control women who did not suffer\tfrom PMS.  After treatment, magnesium levels in these cells was raised\tinto the normal range\tExperimental Double-blind Study, "Oral Magnesium successfully\trelieves premenstrual mood changes" Obstet. Gynecol 78(2):177-81(1991).\t32pts aged 24-39 randomly received either magnesium carboxylic acid\t360mg of Mg per day or a placebo from the 15th day of the cycle to the\tonset of the menstrual flow.  After 2 cycles, both groups received\tmagnesium.  The Menstrual Distress Questionnaire score of the cluster\tpain was significantly reduced during the second cycle(month) for the\tmagnesium treatment group as well as the placebo group once they were\tswitched to magnesium supplementation.  In addition, the total score on\tthe Menstrual Distress Questionnaire was significantly decreased by\tmagnesium supplementation.  The authors suggest that magnesium\tsupplemenation should become a routine treatment for the mood changes\tthat occur during PMSThere are numerous observational studies that have been published in themedical literature which also suggest that PMS is primarily a disorderthat arises out of a hormone imbalance that is dietary in nature.  Butsince observational studies are considered by most physicians in Sci. Med.to be anecdotal in nature, I have not bothered to cite them.  There arealso over a half dozen good experimental studies that have been done onmultivitamin and mineral supplementation to prevent PMS.  I've chosen thebest specific studies on individual vitamins and minerals to try to point outthat PMS is primarily a nutritional disorder.  But doctors don't recognizenutritional disorders unless they can see clinical pathology(beri-beri,pellagra, scruvy, etc.).  PMS is probably the best reason why every doctorbeing trained in the U.S. should get a good course on human nutrition.  PMSis really only the tip if the iceberg when it comes to nutritionaldisorders.  It's time that medicine woke up and smelled the rosesHere's some studies which show the importance in multivitamin/mineralsupplementation and/or diet change in preventing PMS\tExperimental Study, "Effect of a nutritional programme on\tpremenstrual syndrome: a retrospective analysis", Complement. Med.\tRes.5(1):8-11(1991).  200pts were given dietary instructions and\tsupplemented with Optivite(R) plus additional vitamin C, vitamin E,\tmagnesium, zinc and primrose oil.  The dietary instructions were to\ttake the supplements and switch to a low fat, complex carbohydrate\tdiet.  On a retrospective analysis, 96.5% of the 200pts reported an\timprovement in their PMS symptoms with 30% of the sample stating that\tthey no longer suffered from PMS.\tExperimental Double-blind Study, "Role of Nutrition in managing\tpremenstrual tension syndromes", J Reprod. Med. 32(6):405-22(1987). \tA low fat, high complex carbohydrate diet along with Optivite\tsupplementation significantly decreased PMS scores compared with diet\tchange and placebo.  After 6 months on the experimental program, the\tvitamin/mineral supplementated group had significantly decreased\testradiol and increased progesterone in serum during the midlutel\tphase of their cycle\tExperimental Double-blind Study, "Clinical and biochemical effects\tof nutritional supplementation on the premenstrual syndrome", J.\tReprod. Med. 32(6):435-41(1987). 119pts randomly given Optivite(12\ttablets per day) or a placebo.  The treated groups showed a\tsignificant decrease in PMS symptoms compared to the placebo.  Anothe \tgroup of 104pts got Optivite(4 tablets per day) or placebo.  For this\tsecond group of patients, no significant effect of supplementation on\tPMS symptoms was observedMartin Banschbach, Ph.DProfessor of Biochemistry and ChairmaDepartment of Biochemistry and MicrobiologOSU College of Osteopathic Medicin1111 W. 17th StTulsa, Ok 7410"Without discourse, there is no remembering, without remembering, there isno learning, without learning, there is only ignorance"

Contents of file 59330
> Does anyone here know anything about chelation therapy using EDTA?  M> uncle has emphesema, and a doctor wants to try it on him.  We ar> wondering if>> 1.  Is there any evidence EDTA chelation therapy is beneficial for hi> condition, or any condition>> 2.  What possible side effects are there.  How can they be mimimized>> Please respond via e-mail to    rme1@cornell.ed>> Thanks> ReneEDTA(chelation therapy) has been used by some physicians to try to removecalcium from calcified plaques in the arterial system(not approved for suchuse).  There is also the possibility that lung tissue in patients with lungdisease has become calcified(chest x-rays would show this).  There are sid-effects to the use of EDTA because it is not specific for calcium(it alsobinds other minerals).  I think that there have been some deaths whenEDTA chelation therapy has been used because of mineral imbalances thatwere not detected and corrected.  In animal studies, the best way to removecalcium from plaques in rabbits was to supplement the rabbits with vitamin Cand magnesium(rabbits already synthesize their own vitamin C, the extravitamin C was given in their diets to help the magnesium displace the calciumfrom the plaques)The calcification process that occurs in both plaques and the lung probablycan be prevented if magnesium is used in supplemental form.  Most patietnswith calcium deposits are found to be deficient in calcium\t1. "Magnesium interrationships in ischemic heart disease: A review\t   Am J Clin Nutr 27(1):59-79(1974).  Supplementation with\t   magnesium will prevent clacification of blood vessels.\t2. "The importance of magnesium deficiency in cardiovascular\t    disease" Am. Heart J 94:649-57(1977).  The need to measure the\t    serum concentration in all patients with heat disease cannot be\t    overemphasized.  This is a review article\t3. "Effect of dietary magnesium on development of atherosclerosis\t   in cholesterol-fed rabbits" Atherosclerosis 10:732-7(1990). \t   Magnesium supplementation greatly decreased the formation of\t   plaques in rabbits feed a diet that had 1% by weight cholesterrol\t   added to their normal foodSince EDTA will also bind magnesium, I've never really liked it's use forthe reversal of athersclerosis or now apparently in emphesema patientsMarty B

Contents of file 59332
>  banschbach@vms.ocom.okstate.edu writes>>are in a different class.  The big question seems to be is it reasonable to>>use them in patients with GI distress or sinus problems that *could* be due>>to candida blooms following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics>> I guess I\'m still not clear on what the term "candida bloom" means> but certainly it is well known that thrush (superficial candida> infections on mucous membranes) can occur after antibiotic use> This has nothing to do with systemic yeast syndrome, the "quack> diagnosis that has been being discussed>>>>found in the sinus mucus membranes than is candida.  Women have been known>>for a very long time to suffer from candida blooms in the vagina and a>>women is lucky to find a physician who is willing to treat the cause and>>not give give her advise to use the OTC anti-fungal creams>> Lucky how?  Since a recent article (randomized controlled trial) o> oral yogurt on reducing vaginal candidiasis, I've mentioned to a> number of patients with frequent vaginal yeast infections that the> could try eating 6 ounces of yogurt daily.  It turns out most woul> rather just use anti-fungal creams when they get yeast infections>>>yogurt dangerous).  If this were a standard part of medical practice, as>>Gordon R. says it is, then the incidence of GI distress and vaginal yeast>>infections should decline>> Again, this just isn't what the systemic yeast syndrome is about, an> has nothing to do with the quack therapies that were being discussed> There is some evidence that attempts to reinoculate the GI tract wit> bacteria after antibiotic therapy don't seem to be very helpful i> reducing diarrhea, but I don't think anyone would view this as > quack therapy> --> David RinYogurt contains Lactobacillus acidophilus and L. bulgaricus.  L.acidophilus is the major bacteria in the vaginal tract and is primarilyresponsible for keeping the vaginal tract acidic and yeast free.  Most ofthe commercial yogurt sold in the U.S. has a very low L. acidophilus and L.bulgaricus count.  Neither of these bacteria are obligate anaerobes with aremuch more important in dealing with the diarrhea problem.  Gordon R. has toldme through e-mail that he gives his patients L. acidophilus and severaldifferent obligate anaerobes(which set-up shop in the colon) but he hasn'ttold me which ones yet.  The Lactobacillus genera are mostly facultativeanaerobes and will set-up shop where they have access to oxygen if given achance(mouth, anus, sinus cavity and vagina).  Having these good bacteriaaround will greatly decrease the chance of candida blooms in the analregion or the vagina.  I have not proposed a systemic action for candidablooms.  I know that others swear that all kinds of symptoms arise fromthe evil yeast blooms in the body.  I'm not ready to buy that yet.  I dobelieve that complications at specific sites(vagina, anal and maybe lowercolon, sinus and mouth) can result from antibiotic use which removes thecompeting bacteria from these sites and thus lets candida grow uncheckedRestoring the right bacterial balance is the best way(in my opinion) to getrid of the problem.  Anti-fungals, a low carbohydrate diet and vitamin Asupplementation may all help to minimize the local irritation until thegood bacteria can take over control of the food supply again and lower thepH to basically starve the candida outMarty B

> banschbach@vms.ocom.okstate.edu writes>>>to candida blooms following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics?  Gorden>>Rubenfeld, through e-mail, has assured me that most physicians recognize>>the chance of candida blooms occuring after broad-spectrum antibiotic use>>and they therefore reinnoculate their patients with *good* bacteria to>>restore competetion for candida in the body.  I do not believe that this is>>yet a standard part of medical practice. >>   Nor is it mine.  What I tried to explain to Marty was that it is clearl> understood that antibiotic exposure is a risk factor for fungal infection> - which is not the same as saying bacteria prevent fungal infections.> Marty made this sound like a secret  known only to veternarians an> biochemists.  Anyone who has treated a urinary tract infection known> this. At some centers pre-op liver transplant patients receive bowe> decontamination directed at retaining "good" anaerobic flora in an attemp> to prevent fungal colonization in this soon-to-be high risk group.  I als> use lactobacillus to treat enteral nutrition associated diarrhea (that ma> be in part due to alterations in gut flora).  However, it is NOT part o> my routine practice to "reinnoculate" patients with "good" bacteria afte> antibiotics.  I have seen no data on this practice preventing or treatin> fungal infections in at risk patients.  Whether or not it is a "logica> extension" from the available observations I\'ll leave to those of you wh> base strong opinions and argue over such speculations in the absence o> clinical trials.>   One place such therapy has been described is in treating particularl> recalcitrant cases of C. difficile colitis (NOT a fungal infection). Ther> are case reports of using stool (ie someone elses) enemas to repopulat> the patients flora.  Don't try this at home.>>>not give give her advise to use the OTC anti-fungal creams.  Since candida>>colonizes primarily in the ano-rectal area, GI symptoms should be more common>>than vaginal problems after broad-spectrum antibiotic use>>   Except that it isn't. At least symptomatically apparent disease>>>Medicine has not, and probalby never will be, practiced this way.  There>>has always been the use of conventional wisdom.  A very good example is>>kidney stones.  Conventional wisdom(because clinical trails have not been>>done to come up with an effective prevention), was that restricitng the>>intake of calcium and oxalates was the best way to prevent kidney stones>>from forming.  Clinical trials focused on drugs or ultrasonic blasts to>>breakdown the stone once it formed.  Through the recent New England J of>>Medicine article, we now know that conventional wisdom was wrong,>>increasing calcium intake is better at preventing stone formation than is>>restricting calcium intake>>   Seems like this is an excellent argument for ignoring anecdota> conventional wisdom (a euphemism for no data) and doing a good clinica> trial, like:>> AU   Dismukes-W-E.  Wade-J-S.  Lee-J-Y.  Dockery-B-K.  Hain-J-D> TI   A randomized, double-blind trial of nystatin therapy for th>      candidiasis hypersensitivity syndrome [see comments> SO   N-Engl-J-Med.  1990 Dec 20.  323(25).  P 1717-23>      psychological tests. RESULTS. The three active-treatment regimen>      and the all-placebo regime>      significantly reduced both vaginal and systemic symptoms (P less tha>      0.001), but nystatin did not reduce the systemic symptom>      significantly more than placebo. [ . . . >      CONCLUSIONS. In women with presumed candidiasi>      hypersensitivity syndrome, nystatin does not reduce systemic o>      psychological symptoms significantly more than placebo. Consequently>      the empirical recommendation of long-term nystatin therapy for suc>      women appears to be unwarranted>>   Does this trial address every issue raised here, no.  Jon Noring was no> surprised at this negative trial since they didn't use *Sporanox* (despit> Crook's recommendation for Nystatin).  Maybe they didn't avoid thos> carbohydrates . . .>>>The conventional wisdom in animal husbandry has been that animals need to>>be reinnoculated with *good* bacteria after coming off antibiotic therapy>>If it makes sense for livestock, why doesn't it make sense for humans>>David?  We are not talking about a dangerous treatment(unless you consider>>yogurt dangerous).  If this were a standard part of medical practice, as>>Gordon R. says it is, then the incidence of GI distress and vaginal yeast>>infections should decline>>   Marty, you've also changed the terrain of the discussion from empiri> itraconazole for undocumented chronic fungal sinusitis with systemi> hypersensitivity symptoms (Noring syndrome) to the yoghurt and vitami> therapy of undocumented candida enteritis (Elaine Palmer syndrome) wit> systemic symptoms.  There is significant difference between the cost an> risk of these two empiric therapeutic trials.  Are we talking about "real> candida infections, the whole "yeast connection" hypothesis, the efficac> of routine bacterial repopulation in humans, or the ability of anecdotall> effective therapies (challenged by a negative randomized trial) to confir> an etiologic hypothesis (post hoc ergo propter hoc).  We can't seem t> focus in on a disease, a therapy, or a hypothesis under discussion.>          >                            I'm lostCandida can do that to you. :-)  Gordon, I think that the best clinicaltrial for candida blooms would involve giving women with chronic vaginalcandida blooms L. Acidophilus orally and see it it can decrease thefrequency and extent of candida blooms in the vagina since most of thecandida seems to be migrating in from the anal region and L. acidophilusshould be able keep the candida in check if it can make it through theintestinal tract and colonize in the anus where it will have access tooxygen(just like it does in the vagina).  As much stuff as there is in thelay press about L. acidophilus and vaginal yeast infections, I'm reallyamazed that someone has not done a clinical trial yet to check it outThe calcium and kidney stone story is not a good reason to throw allconventional wisdom out the window.  Where would medicine be ifconventional wisdom had not been used to develop many of the standardmedical practices that could not be confirmed through clinical trialsThe clinical trial is a very new arrival on the medical scene(and a veryimportant one).  The lack of proof that reinnoculation with good bacteriaafter antibiotic use is important to the health of a patient is no reasonto dismiss it out-of-hand, especially if reinnoculation can be done cleaplyand safely(like it is in animal husbandry)Marty B

|> When I was a school boy, my biology teacher told us of an inciden|> in which a couple were very passionate without actually havin|> sexual intercourse.  Somehow the girl became pregnent as sper|> cells made their way to her through the clothes via persperation|>|> Was my biology teacher misinforming us, or do such incidents actuall|> occurSperm deposited near the entrance of the vagina has been known to causpregnancy, even in the presence of a hymen. I doubt that sperm could makeit through a layer of cloth then find the right path to a waiting ovumbut it might be possibleSo, it is possible for a woman to be both virgin and pregnantAlso, some hymens are sufficiently loose to allow near-normal intercourswithout rupturing. The problem when investigating these phenomenae isof course, getting an honest account of what exactly happened-philipp

Contents of file 59337
Here is a press release from the American Federation of State,County and Municipal Employees Unions Point To Deadly Workplaces; AFSCME, Other UnionCommemorate Workers Memorial Da To: National Desk, Labor Write Contact: Janet Rivera of the American Federation of State, Countand Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO, 202-429-113   WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The American Federation of State,County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) and other unionof the AFL-CIO on Wednesday, April 28, will commemorate the fiftannual Workers Memorial Day -- a day to pay homage to the million workers who are killed, injured, or diseased on the job   This year, AFSCME will focus its Workers Memorial Day efforts athe dangerous environment in which corrections officers must workEarlier this month, an AFSCME corrections officer, RoberVallandingham, was killed by inmates who overtook the correctionfacility in Lucasville, Ohio   The law and order agenda of the 1980s has resulted in a steadincrease in the prison population for the past five years.  OJn. 1, 1992, the prison population was 709,587. Projectionshow a continued increase in the number of inmates, with aexpected prison population of 811,253 in 1994   The conditions which this burgeoning prison population hacreated for corrections officers is partially reflected in thnumber of assaults by inmates against staff.  Assaults againsstaff increased dramatically between 1987 and 1989, and remaihigh.  In 1987, there were 808 assaults by inmates against staffcompared to 9,961 such assaults in 1991   The increased number of inmates has brought on the dangeroucombination of overcrowding and understaffing.  For example in Ohiofficer-to-inmate ratio is 1 to 8.4 -- the second worst ratio ithe nation. The national average is 1 to 5.3.  Other health ansafety issues facing corrections officers include AIDS, HepatitiB, tuberculosis, stress, and chemical hazards   AFSCME has more than 50,000 members who work in the nation'federal, state and local correctional facilities   Correction officers are not alone in performing their jobs undelife-threatening conditions.  Every year, 10,000 American workerdie from job-related injuries, and tens of thousands more die frooccupational disease.  Public employees do some of the nation'most dangerous jobs. Perilous occupations include   -- Highway Workers - Highway workers are often injured an      frequently killed by moving traffic because work zones ar      not barricaded or don't have proper lighting   -- Health Care Workers - Hospitals have the highest number o      job-related injuries and illnesses of any private secto      employer and nursing homes ranked fifth.  There were mor      than 325,000 job-related illnesses and injuries in privat      sector hospitals in 1991, up almost 10 percent over th      previous year.  It is generally believed that health car      workers employed at public sector hospitals and nursing home      have a significantly higher rate of injuries and illnesse      than do their private sector counterparts.  Health and safet      issues facing health care workers include exposure t      tuberculosis and the HIV virus, back injuries, and hig      levels of stress   -- Social Workers - Social workers who work in mental healt      institutions are often the victims of assaults and      sometimes, fatal attacks.  For instance, last October, a ma      carrying a semiautomatic handgun walked into the Schuyle      County Social Services Building in Watkins Glenn, N.Y      and fatally shot social services workers, before turning th      gun on himself.  There are two basic problems.  First is       growing lack of support services for people who don't hav      the help they need.  Because workers are overworked, som      clients are not given the adequate amount of counselling      Such conditions may cause clients to become more frustrated      The "quality" of the clients is also becoming more violent      as more are moved out of the institutions   Nearly 2 million workers have been killed by workplace hazardsince OSHA was passed.  Moreover, as AFSCME President Gerald WMcEntee explains, OSHA does not provide workplace safetprotections for public employees   "More than 1,600 public employees are killed each year on thjob, yet 27 states still provide no federally-approved OSHcoverage for public employees," said McEntee.  "This, despite thfact that public employees -- highway workers, health care workerscorrections officers, to name but a few -- do some of the mosdangerous work in our society.  This year we are fighting fopassage of OSHA reform legislation to give all workers greaterights and protections, and finally guarantee all public employeesafe workplaces.  We need the public support to be successful.   Government workers suffer 25 percent more injuries than privatsector workers, and these injuries are almost 75 percent morsevere   Public employees were exempted from OSHA when the law was passein 1970 and today, public employees in more than half the statehave no OSHA coverage -30-Canada Remote Systems - Toronto, Ontari416-629-7000/629-704
Contents of file 59338
>  Marty, you've also changed the terrain of the discussion from empiri>itraconazole for undocumented chronic fungal sinusitis with systemi>hypersensitivity symptoms (Noring syndrome) to the yoghurt and vitami>therapy of undocumented candida enteritis (Elaine Palmer syndrome) wit>systemic symptoms.  There is significant difference between the cost an>risk of these two empiric therapeutic trials.  Are we talking about "real>candida infections, the whole "yeast connection" hypothesis, the efficac>of routine bacterial repopulation in humans, or the ability of anecdotall>effective therapies (challenged by a negative randomized trial) to confir>an etiologic hypothesis (post hoc ergo propter hoc).  We can't seem t>focus in on a disease, a therapy, or a hypothesis under discussion.>         >                           I'm lostPoint 1I'm beginning to see that *part* of the disagreements about the whol"yeast issue" is on differing perceptions and on differing meaningof words.  Medical doctors have a very specific and specialized "jargon"necessary for precise communication within their field (which I'm fullcognizant of since I, too, speak "jargonese" when with my peers).  For thsituation in sci.med, many times the words or phrases used by doctors cahave a different and more specific meaning than the same word used in thworld at large, causing significant miscommunication.  One example wordand very relevant to the yeast discussion, is the exact meaning of "systemic"It is now obvious to me that the meaning of this word is very specific, mucmore so than its meaning to a non-doctor.  There is also the observation othis newsgroup that both doctors and non-doctors come together on essentiallequal terms, which, when combined with the jargon issue, can further fathe flames.  This is probably the first time that practicing doctors gereally "beat up" by non-doctors for their views on medicine, which theotherwise don't see much of in their practice except for the occasiona"difficult" patientPoint 2I understand the viewpoint among many practicing doctors that they will noprescribe any treatments/therapies for their patients unless such treatmenthave been shown to be effective and the risks understood from well-constructeclinical trials (usually double-blind), or that such treatments/therapies arpart of an approved and funded clinical trial.  To these doctors, to do andifferently would, in this belief system, be unethical practice.  And ifollows that any therapy not on the "accepted" list is therefore a nontherapy - it does not even exist, nor does the underlying hypothesis otheory have any validity, even if it sounds very plausible by extrapolatioof what is currently known.  Anecdotal evidence has no value, either, froa treatment point-of-viewAnd by and large, as a scientist myself, I am glad that medical practicescience takes such a rigorous approach to medical treatment.  However, aalso being a human being (last I checked), and having been one of those peoplthat has been significantly helped by a currently unaccepted treatment, wher"standard" medicine was not able to help me, has caused me to sit back anwonder if holding such an extreme and rigid "scientific" viewpoint is iitself unethical from humanitarian considerations.  After all, the underlyinintent of the "scientific" approach to medicine is to protect the health othe patient by providing the best possible care for the patient, so thpatient should come first when considering treatmentWhat we need is a slightly modified approach to treatment that satisfies botthe "scientific" and the "humanitarian" viewpoints.  In an earlier post outlined a crazy idea for doing just that.  The gist of it was to give anphysician freedom and encouragement by the medical community to prescribalternate, not yet proven therapies (maybe supported by anecdotal evidencefor patients who *all* avenues of accepted therapies have been exhauste(and not until then).  The patient would be fully informed that suctherapies/treatments are not supported by the proper clinical trials and thathere are real potential risks with real possibilities of no benefit derivefrom themThis approach satisfies the need for scientific rigor.  It also satisfiethe humanitarian needs of the patient.  And the reality is that many patientwho have reached a dead-end in the treatment of their symptoms using acceptemedicine *will* go outside the orthodox medical community:  either to thdoctors who are brave enough to prescribe such treatments at the risk of losintheir license, or worse, to non-doctors who have not had the proper medicatraining.  This approach also recognizes this reality and keeps the contromore within orthodox medicine, with the benefits that the information gleanecould help focus limited resources towards future clinical trials in the mosproductive way.  Everybody wins in this admittedly rose-colored approach - I'sure there are real problems with this approach as well - it is presentemore as a strawman to stimulate discussionHopefully what I write here may give the sci.med doctors a better idea as twhy I am "open" to alternative therapies, as well as why I have readifficulty (read "apparent hostility") with the "coldness" of the 99.9% pur"scientific" approach to medicine.  I believe the best approach to medicatreatment is one where both the "humanitarian" aspects are balanced with anby the "scientific" aspects.  Anything else is just not good medicine, imhoJust my 'NF' leanings, I guess.  :^CommentsJon Norin--Charter Member --->>>  INFJ ClubIf you're dying to know what INFJ means, be brave, e-mail me, I'll send info============================================================================| Jon Noring          | noring@netcom.com        |                          | JKN International   | IP    : 192.100.81.100   | FRED'S GOURMET CHOCOLATE | 1312 Carlton Place  | Phone : (510) 294-8153   | CHIPS - World's Best!    | Livermore, CA 94550 | V-Mail: (510) 417-4101   |                          ============================================================================Who are you?  Read alt.psychology.personality!  That's where the action is

*****************************************************************************                  Lyme Disease Electronic Mail Network                     *                          LymeNet Newsletter                               ****************************************************************************                      Volume 1 - Number 09 - 4/26/9I.    IntroductioII.   AnnouncementIII.  News from the wireIV.   Questions 'n' AnswerV.    Op-Ed SectioVI.   Jargon IndeVII.  How to Subscribe, Contribute and Get Back IssueI. ***** INTRODUCTION ****In this issue of the Newsletter, we learn of the CDC's announced concern fothe "resurgence of infectious diseases" in the United States.  Thanks tJonathan Lord for sending me the UPI release.  The CDC announced they woulfeature a new series of articles in the Morbidity and Mortality WeeklReport on these infectious diseases (LD is one of them).  We will keep youp to date on this seriesIn addition, we feature a The Wall Street Journal article on the legal issuesurrounding LD.  We also look at Lyme's effects from the perspective ourologists in an abstract entitled "Urinary Dysfunction in Lyme Disease.Finally, Terry Morse asks an intriguing question about a tick's habitat-MarcII. ***** ANNOUNCEMENTS ****SOURCE: The Lyme Disease UpdatSUBJECT: Call for ArticleAttention Health Care ProfessionalsThe Lyme Disease Update would like to publish your articles on Lyme diseasdiagnosis, Lyme treatment, and the effects on Lyme on Lyme patients' physicaand mental healthThe LDU has a monthly circulation of 6,000.  Our mailing list includes Lympatients, physicians, researchers, county health departments, and over 10Lyme support groups nationwide.  We strive to give our readers up-to-datinformation on Lyme disease prevention, diagnosis, and treatment, and source for support and practical advice on living with Lyme diseaseArticles for the LDU should be approximately 900 to 1200 words and shouladdress Lyme disease issues in non-scientific language.  To submit youarticle, mail to: Lyme Disease Updat                  P.O. Box 15711-071                  Evansville, IN 4771      or FAX to:  812-471-199One year subscriptions to the Lyme Disease Update are $19 ($24 outside thUS).  Mail your subscription requests to the above address, or cal812-471-1990 for more informationIII. ***** NEWS FROM THE WIRES *****Sender: Jonathan Lord <jml4s@uva.pcmail.virginia.eduSubject: RESURGENCE OF INFECTIOUS DISEASE CONCERNS CDDate: Thursday April 15, 199ATLANTA (UPI) --   A resurgence of infectious diseases blamed on newlemerging viruses and bacteria pose a major challenge for the nation'health care system, federal health officials said ThursdayThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, reporting its latesfindings in an investigation of contaminated hamburger meat thasickened hundreds in 4 states and killed at least four, said it wilput renewed emphasis on battling infectious diseasesPart of that emphasis includes a new series titled "EmerginInfectious Diseases" to be featured in the CDC\'s Morbidity & MortalitWeekly Report, which has a wide circulation in the health communityThe issue also will top the agenda of a two-day meeting of scientificounselors to update the CDC's draft plan for dealing with the growinthreat of infectious ailments"This is an issue that has been coming and we do have a responsibilitto deal with it," said Dr. Ruth Berkelman, deputy director of the CDC\'National Center for Infectious DiseasesThere were more cases of malaria in the U.S. in 1992 than in any yeasince the 1960s, and Latin America is experiencing a cholera epidemicthe first in this century, she saidResistance of disease-causing agents to antibiotics is also a problem"We are seeing much more antibiotic resistance than we have in the pastBerkleman said.  She said even common ear infections frequently seen ichildren are becoming resistant to antibiotic treatment"Despite predictions earlier this century that infectious  diseasewould soon be eliminated as a public health problem, infectious diseaseremain the major cause of death worldwide and a leading cause of illnesand death in the United States," the CDC saidIt  cited  the  emergence since the 1970s of a "myriad" of newlidentified pathogens and syndromes, such as Escherichia coli O157:H7, deadly bacterial infection; the hepatitis C virus; HIV, the virus thacauses AIDS; Legionnaires disease; Lyme disease; and toxic shock syndrome"The incidences of many diseases widely presumed to be under controlsuch as cholera, malaria and tuberculosis, have increased in many areas,the CDC said.  It said efforts at control and prevention have beeundermined by drug resistance=====*====SOURCE:  WALL STREET JOURNAREFERENCE: 04/15/93, pBHEADLINE: Lyme-Disease Ruling Raises Liability IssueThe tick that causes Lyme disease may have found a new way to causdamage: legal liabilityA federal judge's decision holding a property owner liable for nodoing enough to protect workers from Lyme disease is getting as mucattention as the latest medical study on the disease, a flu-likillness that can cause severe physical and mental disabilities and irare instances death. The decision last week has put property owneron notice that they may have to do more than protect themselves frothe ticks-they also may have to protect themselves from litigation isomeone becomes infected while on the propertyThe decision by U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward in New York camafter a week-long trial in a case involving four track workers for thLong Island Railroad. Judge Ward found that the workers contracted thdisease after they were bitten by ticks while on the job. He orderethe New York state-owned commuter line to pay the workers more tha$560,000 to compensate for pain and suffering, in addition to medicaexpenses and lost wagesSummer camps, schools, companies with facilities in rural osemirural areas, and homeowners who rent to vacationers are among thgroups that need to be worried about this ruling, says Stephen LKass, an attorney at New York law firm Berle, Kass & Case, who wrote legal article three years ago warning property owners of the potentialiability. Even a family that invites friends over for a backyarbarbecue might be potentially liableLawsuits for insect bites, while rare, aren't unheard-of. A summevacationer in Southampton, N.Y., last year sued the owner of the homshe rented, claiming that a tick on the property gave her RockMountain spotted fever. In 1988, also on Long Island, a jury orderean outdoor restaurant to pay more than $3 million to a patron who wastung by a bee, causing an allergic reaction and permanenquadriplegia. The judge later threw out the award, citing no evidencthat a beehive was near the restaurantBut lawyers say that the attention to Lyme disease throughout thcountry -- it's most prevalent in New England, the Middle Atlantistates, Wisconsin, Minnesota and the Northwest -- may make thiparticular insect bite a particularly litigious oneThe illness already has proved to be a source of controversy in thcourtroom over such issues as the type of medical care insurers wilcover and medical malpractice claims against doctors for nodiagnosing the diseaseLawyers say worker's-compensation claims related to Lyme diseashave become common in some states in recent years. Payments iworker's-compensation cases, however, are limited to medical costs anlost earningsThe case before Judge Ward dealt with a potentially much morlucrative avenue for damages, because it involved the question onegligence. Unlike the worker's compensation process, the law governininjuries to rail workers allows for a finding of negligence and, as result, for additional payments for pain and suffering. Propertowners and lawyers say that negligence claims can be made in manother situations where people are exposed to the ticks that carry thdiseaseIra M. Maurer, a partner at New York law firm Elkind, Flynn Maurer, who represented the rail workers, says the decision will helto establish "the duty of all sorts of property owners to protecagainst Lyme disease.Lawyers caution that despite Judge Ward's decision, winning lawsuit for damages caused by Lyme disease may prove difficult. Foone thing, victims have to demonstrate that they have pinned down wheand where they got the tick bite. Judge Ward found that the plaintiffin the railroad case got Lyme disease while working on property owneby the railroad, even though none of the men remembered being bittenThe workers, who weren't outdoorsmen likely to be exposed elsewhere tthe insects, said they saw ticks in the high grass that surroundesome work sitesA spokeswoman for the railroad says that there was no proof thathe four men were bitten while on the job and that the railroad iconsidering an appeal. The railroad also disputes Judge Ward's findinthat it didn't do enough to protect employees. The spokeswoman saythe railroad provides track workers with insect repellent and speciapants to protect against bug bitesDebate in the scientific community over Lyme disease could open usome legal defenses for property owners, such as questioning whether victim actually has the disease rather than some other illnessEarlier this week, the Journal of the American Medical Associatioreported that doctors overly diagnose patients as having Lyme diseaseAnd damages awarded to a victim also might be influenced by medicadisputes over the degree of harm that Lyme disease causesBecause of health and safety concerns, some groups and companiealready take special measures to protect against Lyme disease. Lasyear, at its headquarters in Franklin Lakes, N.J., Becton, Dickinson Co. began using Damminix, a pesticide made by EcoHealth Inc. of Bostothat is designed to kill ticks carrying the disease. The medicalsupply company's headquarters include a 120-acre park, and the companwas worried that employees who walk on its trails for recreation mighget infectedRuth Lister, a spokeswoman for the American Camping Association iIndianapolis, says that many youth camps accredited by heorganization also have begun to check children for ticks. And CarolKatz, a member of the board of the Fire Island Pines Property OwnerAssociation, says her group spends $30,000 each year to treat thei100-acre site off the coast of New York with the tick-killinpesticide=====*====TITLE: Urinary dysfunction in Lyme diseaseAUTHORS: Chancellor MB; McGinnis DE; Shenot PJ; Kiilholma P; Hirsch IHDepartment of Urology, Jefferson Medical College, Thomas JeffersoUniversity, Philadelphia, PennsylvaniaREFERENCE: J Urol 1993 Jan; 149 (1): 26-3Lyme disease, which is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, iassociated with a variety of neurological sequelae.  We describe 7 patientwith neuro-borreliosis who also had lower urinary tract dysfunctionUrodynamic evaluation revealed detrusor hyperreflexia in 5 patients andetrusor areflexia in 2.  Detrusor external sphincter dyssynergia was nonoted on electromyography in any patient.  We observed that the urinary tracmay be involved in 2 respects in the course of Lyme  disease: 1) voidindysfunction may be part of neuro-borreliosis and 2) the spirochete madirectly invade the urinary tract.  In 1 patient bladder infection by thLyme spirochete was documented on biopsy.  Neurological and urologicasymptoms in all patients were slow to resolve and convalescence waprotracted.  Relapses of active Lyme disease and residual neurologicadeficits were common.  Urologists practicing in areas endemic for Lymdisease need to be aware of B. burgdorferi infection in the differentiadiagnosis of neurogenic bladder dysfunction.  Conservative bladdemanagement including clean intermittent catheterization guided by urodynamievaluation is recommendedIV. ***** QUESTIONS 'N' ANSWERS ****Note: If you have a response to this question, please forward it to theditorSender: Terry Morse <morset@ccmail.orst.eduSubject: Question on Lyme Vectors and Compost Pile  When I visited my sister on Long Island, NY, I was cautioned to avoid thcompost heap in her back yard, as she thinks this is where she becaminfected  A friend of mine here in Oregon who has a compost heap would like me tback that claim up with documentation.  Do lyme-carrying ticks hang out icompost heapsThank youV. ***** OP-ED SECTION ****This section is open to all subscribers who would like to express an opinionVI. ***** JARGON INDEX ****Bb - Borrelia burgdorferi - The scientific name for the LD bacteriumCDC - Centers for Disease Control - Federal agency in charge of trackin      diseases and programs to prevent themCNS - Central Nervous SystemELISA - Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assays - Common antibody tesEM - Erythema Migrans - The name of the "bull\'s eye" rash that appears i     ~60% of the patients early in the infectionIFA - Indirect Fluorescent Antibody - Common antibody testLD - Common abbreviation for Lyme DiseaseNIH - National Institutes of Health - Federal agency that conducts medica      research and issues grants to research interestsPCR - Polymerase Chain Reaction - A new test that detects the DNA sequenc      of the microbe in question.  Currently being tested for use i      detecting LD, TB, and AIDSSpirochete - The LD bacterium.  It's given this name due to it's spira      shapeWestern Blot - A more precise antibody testVII. ***** HOW TO SUBSCRIBE, CONTRIBUTE AND GET BACK ISSUES ****SUBSCRIPTIONSAnyone with an Internet address may subscribeSend a memo to    listserv@Lehigh.EDin the body, typesubscribe LymeNet-L <Your Real NameFAX subscriptions are also available. hoss@panix.com  writes> hi all, Ive applied for the class of 93 at quite a number of schools (20> and have gotten 13 rejects, 4 interviews and 3 no responsesThree possible results after interview1) rejection outrigh2) acceptance outrigh3) the infamous 'wait list'...If you are on a 'wait list', your entrance into medical schoois dependent upon some other applicant withdrawing theiacceptance.  This can happen as late as day -1 of startinclasses. > Any one know when the heck these people send out their acceptance letters> According to the med school admissions book theyre supposed to send ou> the number of their class in acceptances by mid March. Whats going on... > am losing my sanity checking my mailbox every dayYou can always call the admissions office.  The secretarieshould have some idea of when a decision might be made on youapplication.  Be calm, respectful, and friendly; secretariehave more power than you might realize, and you never knowcould be the dean of admissions answering the phone> Also does anyone have some useful alternatives in case i dont get in, If you don't get in this year, sit down and re-evaluatyourself: your motives, desires, and goals that are directinyou into medicine; your academic and extracurriculaaccomplishments.  Make a decision about whether you *reallywant to be a medical doctor.  I had classmates who dropped ouin the first semester of med school because they found it wanot what they wanted to do; I have friends who applied fouyears in a row before they were accepted.  Medicine as career is a choice you must make for yourself; DON'T bpushed into it because of your parents/family/significanother. If you still want to be a medical doctor, determine how yocan improve your application.  A letter of recommendation froa professor who knows you well and can give an honest positivrecommendation is far better than one from a 'big-shot' famouprofessor who only vaguely remembers your face.  Also, don'be afraid to ask these people if they can give you an honesand positive recommendation; give them a chance to say 'nosorry' instead of the medical school saying 'no, sorry'.  have turned down writing recommendations for some studentbecause I did not know them well enough to make any meaningfucomments, and some because I honestly could not recommend theat that point. Rewrite your personal statement; take it by an Englisprofessor or some other friendly person with skill anexperience in writing and proof-reading and get theicriticism, both about what you are saying as well as how yosay itReview your academic accomplishments.  If your grades are pooin some area, don't be afraid to spend some time in furthecoursework.  Evidence of determined committment will helhere.  If you filled your pre-medicine curriculum with gucourses, it usually showsLook at your extracurricular involvements.  Participating ilocal philanthropic or service organizations is a plussubstantial leadership roles in an organization help alsoBeware of 'resume padding'; such things are not difficult tspot and weed outOverall, a clear conception of where you wish to head and whyou want to get there, combined with an honest self-appraisaof skills and aptitude, will be the best path to take iapplying to any program, medical or what-have-youGood luck with the process -- as Tom Petty says, 'the waitinis the hardest part', at least emotionally. :Bob Schmie

Contents of file 59357
I think you must have the same hygiene teacher I had in 1955.  Thereis a story about the Civil War about a soldier who was shot in thgroin.  The bullet, after passing through one of his testes, then enterethe abdomen of a young woman standing nearby.  Later,  when she (a younwoman of unimpeachible virtue) was shown to be pregnant; the soldier dithe honorable thing of marrying her.  According to this story, they livehappily ever after. Perhaps the most famous of Mr. Rau's classes was the time he would cominto class brandishing an aluminum turning mandrel  (tapering from abou3/8" to 1/2" over a 10 inch length).  He would say, "Boys, do you knowhat this is?  It's a medical instrument called a 'cock reamer' and it'used to unclog your penis when you have VD.  They just ram it up therwithout an anesthetic!"  Needless to say this had a chilling effectI didn't have lascivious thoughts for at least an hour.  Later in lifas I perused medical instrument catelogs and saw the slender flexiblurethral sounds that are actually used, I could not escape thinkinthat I might one day see, "Reamer, Cock (style of Rau) ."

-*---> I need information on the medical (including emotional :-) pros an> cons of circumcision (at birth). ..I pity those who hope that medical knowledge can resolve issuesuch as this.  This issue has been rehashed in sci.med time antime again.  The bottom line is this: in normal circumstancesboth the medical advantages of and the medical risks ocircumcision are minor.  This means that the decision is left tthe religious, cultural, ethical, and aesthetic mores of thparents, at best, or to the habit of the concerned hospital ocaregivers, at worst.As (prospective) parents, you should do what you want in thiregard and not worry about it too much.  In terms of decisionyou make for your child, it will have far less importance thamany -- such as which schools you choose -- that most parentthink about only a little.This question will undoubtedly push the buttons of people whfeel that the decision to circumcise your infant or not is momentous medical decision.  It is notRussel

Contents of file 59371
First off, if I'm not mistaken, only hibernating animals have brown fatnot humansSecondly, your description sounds just like 2,4-dinitrophenol.  This is auncoupler of respiratory chain oxidative phosphorylation.  Put in layman'terms, it short-circuits the mitochondria, causing food energy to bturned into heat2,4-DNP was popular in the 1930's for weight reduction.  In controlleamounts, it raises body temperature as the body compensates for threduced amount of useful energy available.  It is very dangerousIt would be wiser to adjust to your present body form, rather thaplay around with 2,4-DNPBut if you insist, I suggest you look up the literature in your owuniversity library.  You can obtain 2,4-DNP by taking a first yeaorganic chemistry lab course and swiping it from the supplies (it'a commonly-used reagent)

 banschbach@vms.ocom.okstate.edu writes>oxygen(just like it does in the vagina).  As much stuff as there is in the>lay press about L. acidophilus and vaginal yeast infections, I'm really>amazed that someone has not done a clinical trial yet to check it outI've mentioned this study a couple of times now: Ingestion of yogurcontaining Lactobacillus acidophilus as prophylaxis for candidavaginitis, Annals of Internal Medicine, 3/1/92 116(5):353-7.  Do yohave a problem with the study because they used yogurt rather thacapsules of lactobacillus (even though it had positive results)The study was a crossover trial of daily ingestion of 8 ounces oyogurt.  There was a marked decrease in infections while women weringesting the yogurt.  Problems with the study included very smalnumbers (33 patients enrolled) and many protocol violations (onl21 patients were analyzed).  Still, the difference in rates of infectiobetween the two groups was so large that the study remains fairlbelievable--David Rinrind@enterprise.bih.harvard.ed

Contents of file 59377
>I heard that a certain disease (toxoplasmosys?) is transmitted by cats whic>can harm the unborn fetus. Does anybody know about it? Is it a problem to>have a cat in the same apartmentThe disease you are talking about is toxoplasmosis.  It is a protozoan thatlives and multiplies within cells.  In cats, the protozoan multiplies in thintestinal cells and eggs are shed in the cat's feces.  The protozoa cacross the placenta to infect the fetus.  The disease may be asymptomatiafter the baby is born, or it may be very severe.  Toxo may cause blindnesand mental retardationHaving a cat in the same apartment should not be a problem; however, pregnanwomen should not scoop or change the cat's litterbox.  In addition, whoevedoes empty the litterbox should thoroughly wash his/her hands before handlinanything else, especially foodInformation came from _The Merck Manual, 15th Ed.I hope this information is helpful to youElispicl25@fsphy1.physics.fsu.ed

The demonstration to which you refer consists of placing a leaf betweethe plates, and taking a Kirlian photograph of it.  You then cut off part othe leaf, put the top plate back on, and take another Kirlian photograph.  Yosee pretty much the same image in both cases.  Turns out the effect isn'nearly so striking if you take the trouble to clean the plates betweephotographs.  Seems that the moisture from the leaf that you left on the placconducts electricity. Lawrence Curcio (lc2b+@andrew.cmu.edu) wrote: I've seen people in their forties and fifties become disoriented an: demented during hospital stays. In the examples I've seen, drugs wer: definitely involved.: My own father turned into a vegetable for a short time while in th: hospital. He was fifty-three at the time, and he was on 21 separat: medications. The family protested, but the doctors were adamant, tellin: us that none of the drugs interact. They even took the attitude that, i: he was disoriented, they should put him on something else as well! Wit: the help of an MD friend of the family, we had all his medicatio: discontinued. He had a seizure that night, and was put back on one drug: Two days later, he was his old self again. I guess there aren't man: medical texts that address the subject of 21-way interactionsI saw the same thing happen to my father, and I can more or less validate youtake on hospitals.  It seems to me that medical science understands precioulittle about taking care of the human machine.  Drugs are given as response to symptoms (and I guess that makes sense since all the studies thatvalidate the effectiveness of those drugs are based on a narroassessment of the degree of particular symptoms).  But there seemto be very little appreciation for the well-being of a persooutside of the numbers that appear on a test.  I watched my dawither away and lose huge amounts of body fat and muscles tissuwhile in the hospital.  There is something a little crazy about system in which there is more attention paid to giving you everlatest drug available than there is attention paid to whether yohave had enough to eat to prevent loss of muscle tissue.  It ireally, really bizarre.   --Will Estes\t\tInternet: westes@netcom.co

In fact, somschools screen out applicants based on these numbers and never even looat your other qualities.  Of course, when this happens, don't expect a refunon your $50 application feeBut, the fact that you got four interviews tells me that you have the numberand are very well qualified academically. Hodid your interviews goAs for how long you have to wait, I've called a few schools who never contacteme for anything. Don't becomfixated on the mailbox, go out, have fun, be very proud of yourselfWhat do people think of the medical school admissions process? Contents of file 59395
>  banschbach@vms.ocom.okstate.edu writes>>oxygen(just like it does in the vagina).  As much stuff as there is in the>>lay press about L. acidophilus and vaginal yeast infections, I'm really>>amazed that someone has not done a clinical trial yet to check it out>> I've mentioned this study a couple of times now: Ingestion of yogur> containing Lactobacillus acidophilus as prophylaxis for candida> vaginitis, Annals of Internal Medicine, 3/1/92 116(5):353-7.  Do yo> have a problem with the study because they used yogurt rather tha> capsules of lactobacillus (even though it had positive results)>> The study was a crossover trial of daily ingestion of 8 ounces o> yogurt.  There was a marked decrease in infections while women wer> ingesting the yogurt.  Problems with the study included very smal> numbers (33 patients enrolled) and many protocol violations (onl> 21 patients were analyzed).  Still, the difference in rates of infectio> between the two groups was so large that the study remains fairl> believable> --> David RinDavid, this study looks like a good one.  Gordon Rubenfeld did a Medlinesearch and also sent me the same reference through e-mail.  Sincecommercial yogurt does not always have a good Lactobacillus a. orbulgaricus culture, a negative finding would not have been too informativeThis is often the reason why Lactobacillus acidophilus tablets arerecommended rather than yogurtI guess the next question is why would this introduction of "good" bacteriaback into the gut decrease the incidence of vaginal candida blooms if theanus was not serving as a candida reservoir(a fact that Gordon R. vehementdenys)?  I see two possible theories.  One, the L. acidophilus, which is afacultatively anaerobic bacterium, could make it through the gut andcolonize the rectal area to overgrow the candida.  This would not explainthe reoccurance of candida blooms in the vagina after the yogurt ingestionwas stopped though.  The other is that the additional bacteria in theintestinal tract remove most of the glucose from the feces and candidalooses it's major food sourceGetting Lactobacillus acidophilus to colonize the vaginal tract(where it isnormally found) would have a much better effect on the recurrance of vaginalyeast blooms though.  An acetic acid, Lactobacillus acidophilus douche hasbeen used to get this effect but I've not seen any such treatment reported inthe medical literature.  This would be an example of physicians conductingtheir own clinical trials to try to come up with treatments that help theirpatients.  When this is done in private practice, the results are rarely, ifever published.  It was the hallmark of medicine until the modern ageemerged with clinical trials.  It really raises a big question.  Does themedical profession cast out the adventerous few who try new treatments tohelp patients or does it look the other wayThis particular issue is really a very simple one since no real dangeroustherapy is involved(even the anti-fungals are not all that dangerous).  Butthere are some areas(like EDTA chelation therapy), where the fire is prettyhot and somebody could get burned.  It's really tough.  Do I follow onlywell established protocols and then give up if they don't work that well ordo it try something that looks like it will work but hasn't been proven towork yetMy stand is to consider other treatment possibilities, especially if theyinvolve little or no risk to the patient.  Getting good bacteria back intothe gut after antibiotic treatment is one treatment possibility.  The otheris getting L. acidophilus into the vaginal tract of a woman who is having aproblem with recurring yeast infectionsMarty B

Surprise, surprise\tThis is true, but it's not quite the whole story.  There were\tactually some people who were more careful in their methodolog\twho also replicated the 'phantom leaf effect.    One of the most influential critics of Kirlian Electrophotograph    is a Theosophist (and threfore presumably willing to entertain th    hypothesis of scientific evidence for a human aura, electromagneti    or otherwise), professor of electrical engineering at London'    City University, and a past president of the Society for Psychic Research    named A. J. Ellison    After years of studying the method and the claims, Elliso    came to the conclusion that the photographic images are what w    calls 'Lichtenberg Figures,' an effect of intermittent ionization o    the air around the object.  It's a bit more complicated tha    'not wiping off the plates,' but it comes down to the same thin    in the end, Kirlian electrophotography has much more limite    value (if any) than was previously widely thought.  Electrical an    magnetic fields generated by the body are much too small to b    of much use diagnostically without very elaborate equipment an    usually also tracer chemicals\t\t\t\t\tkind regards\t\t\t\t\ttod+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| Todd I. >>Greg:Flame definitely intended here.  Bill was making fun of the misspelling.>>Go look up the word "krill."  Also, the correct spelling is Kirlian.  I>>involves taking photographs of corona discharges created by attaching th>>subject to a high-voltage source, not of some "aura."  It works equally wel>>with inanimate objects>True.. but what about showing the missing part of a leaf?  Is thi>"corona discharge"I think I can explain the "missing part of a leaf" storyI have actually seen a reproduction of that particular Kirliaphotograph, in a book compiled by people who were enthusiasts oKirlian photography.  "That particular photograph" ... ?  That\'right, the effect has been observed only once.  Even the writers othe book were inclined to disbelieve in it. I conjecture that the maker of that photograph began by placina whole leaf between two plates and taking its Kirlian photoFor his next experiment, he cut the leaf in half, put one half dowbetween the same two plates, and took another K. p.  Th"missing half" effect was created by water, oils, etc. left behindafter the first photoThis explanation must be tentative, because after all I wasn't therwhen it happened. RegardsChris Henric

=>Yup.  The demonstration to which you refer consists of placing a leaf betwee=>the plates, and taking a Kirlian photograph of it.  You then cut off part o=>the leaf, put the top plate back on, and take another Kirlian photograph.  Yo=>see pretty much the same image in both cases.  Turns out the effect isn'=>nearly so striking if you take the trouble to clean the plates betwee=>photographs.  Seems that the moisture from the leaf that you left on the plac=>conducts electricity.  Surprise, surprise=\tThis is true, but it's not quite the whole story.  There were=\tactually some people who were more careful in their methodolog=\twho also replicated the 'phantom leaf effect.You can also replicate the effect with a rock:  Take your first Kirliaphotograph.  Then moisten one edge of the rock.  Lo! and behold!  Phantom rock-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Carl J Lydick | INTERnet: CARL@SOL1.GPS.CALTECH.EDU | NSI/HEPnet: SOL1::CARDisclaimer:  Hey, I understand VAXen and VMS. The Schatzkring, on the other hand, is causing swallowing difficulty. In particularif I'm not careful about eating slowly, and thoroughly chewing foodfood occasionally gets "stuck" before reaching my stomach. This resultin a period of painful spasms as the food attempts to pass the obstructionFortunately, the food has always managed to pass, but this is annoyingand causes frequent discomfortMy doctor wants to "dilate" the ring using thfollowing procedure: use an endoscope to examine the esophagus and stomacfor any inflammation, then cut through the ring and dilate it by passinsome kind of balloon or something thru the esophagous. In particular, during the past month or so therhas been a dramatic increase-a Holter monitor recently showed 50 PVC's in 2hrs, along with a few PAC's.
